In response to the continuing high level of accidents the Taoiseach on 21 October 1997 called a meeting of the inter agency high level group on road safety, which operates under the aegis of the Minister for the Environment and Local Government and which includes representatives of my Department and the Garda Síochána. This group was mandated to prepare a national strategy on road safety. This strategy entitled “The Road to Safety”, was launched by the Taoiseach on 31 July 1998.

MainHeading.P: The principal aim of the strategy is to reduce road fatalities by 2002 by a minimum of 20 per cent on their 1997 level and to achieve a similar reduction of at least 20 per cent in the number of serious injuries from road accidents. This strategy is designed to improve our road safety record vis-a-vis our European partners, Supporting targets of the strategy by 2002 are to reduce the incidence of excessive speed by 50 per cent from current levels, to increase the wearing rate of front and rear seat belts to at least 85 per cent, to reduce by 25 per cent the number of fatal road accidents, commonly drink related, occurring during the hours of darkness and to implement specific accident reduction measures at more than 400 national road locations.

Speed and alcohol have been identified as the major causes of accidents. Not wearing seat belts is also a contributory cause. These offences are also the primary focus of Operation Lifesaver to which Deputy Higgins referred which was launched on 14 July 1997.

I assure the House that the Garda is committed to vigorous enforcement of the speeding regulations. During 1997 the Garda issued 71,337 on the spot fines for speeding of which 58,458 were paid, that is, a 75 per cent rate of voluntary payment. There were 22,801 convictions for speeding in 1997. One of the aims of the national strategy is to reduce incidences of excessive speeding by 50 per cent from current levels.

Research has shown that alcohol is an important factor in up to 25 per cent of road accidents and 33 per cent of fatal accidents. The enforcement of the drink driving laws are given a high priority by the Garda Síochána. A total of 5,975 prosecutions were taken in respect of drink driving offences in 1996 and the total increased to 7,616 in 1997.

Under the road safety strategy the Garda and the Medical Bureau of Road Safety are to work towards the phased introduction of evidential breath testing, which is allowed under the Road Traffic Act, 1994. This will mean that persons will undergo a breath test at a Garda station instead of a blood and urine sample test following arrest for suspected drink driving. It is expected that evidential breath testing will lead to an increase in convictions.

Not wearing seat belts has also been identified as a major factor in road deaths and serious injury accidents. The House may be assured that the enforcement of the seat belt regulations is also given a high priority by the Garda. In 1997 there were 9,280 prosecutions for this offence compared to 6,293 in 1996. In addition, as part of Operation Lifesaver, 48,848 seat belt offences were detected from 1 January 1998 to 16 August 1998. In all these areas, the levels of detection and prosecution have increased. The national strategy aims to increase seat belt wearing by car users to 85 per cent by 2002. The strategy also envisages extending the on the spot fine system for failure to wear a seat belt.

The Garda has confirmed that Operation Lifesaver, which was introduced in the Louth-Meath area in July 1997, will continue in 1999. It was designed to increase the enforcement capacity of the Garda in relation to the key offences of excessive speed, drink driving and not wearing seat belts.

The Garda has the necessary resources in terms of manpower and equipment to help it in its road traffic enforcement role. It has the most up to date speed detection technology. The equipment in use in enforcing speed limits includes hand held radar, tripod mounted lasers, in-car video cameras as well as the GATSO unit, which, as Members are aware, is a mobile speed detection unit with on board cameras and computer facilities. The Garda has two of these units with a further three due to be delivered soon. In addition, the provision of fixed speed cameras and the development of the penalty points system are an integral part of the national strategy on road safety.

I have outlined the Government's commitment to reducing the levels of road deaths and serious injuries on our roads. The House can be assured the Government is determined to make progress as set out in the national strategy. The House may also be assured that the Garda is similarly committed. It will continue to use all available resources and to co-operate with all agencies involved to make our roads safer and to reduce the number of deaths and injuries. However, it must be stressed that additional resources and enforcement alone cannot succeed unless the public makes a serious effort to obey the law. There were more than 250,000 prosecutions for road traffic offences during 1997 and this sends a clear message about our observance of these laws. As Deputy Higgins said, perhaps an attitude change is required. Undoubtedly, the laws are there to be obeyed and it is in everyone's interest in terms of safety on our roads to play our part.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Higher Education Grants.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deenihan Mr. Deenihan
Speaker.P: I wish to share time with Deputy Naughten.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: Is that agreed? Agreed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Deenihan Mr. Deenihan
Speaker.P: This debate is opportune. Earlier today the president of the USI, Mr. Dermot Lohan, and members of its executive who are in the public galllery, lobbied Deputies on the serious matter of the hardship caused for thousands of young students by the inadequacy of maintenance grants.

MainHeading.P: Despite the fact that the rainbow coalition Government introduced free tuition fees for all third level students in 1995 it is becoming increasingly difficult for many parents to send their children to third level colleges because of high rental accommodation costs and the increased cost of living. According to the USI poverty survey for 1997-98 it costs a student from outside Dublin £466.24 per month to live and study in the city. This will increase to at least £550 per month or £137.50 per week for the 1998-99 academic year because of the spiralling cost of accommodation which works out at between £50 and £55 per week on average and the increased cost of living, including travelling expenses, college book fees, food, clothes, course materials and other essential items. The total cost to parents to send their children to university in Dublin, based on a 36-week year, is now in the region of £5,000. Traditionally, UCD and Trinity College have attracted large numbers of Kerry students. I can see this tradition dying because of parents' inability to pay.

The maximum maintenance grant is £1,652 and is paid to students whose parents earn less than £18,308 and have three children. A family earning more than £19,525 with fewer than four children receives no assistance. The burden on low income families and those on social welfare is particularly onerous. The maximum maintenance grant is hopelessly inadequate and meets only 33 per cent of actual living costs for 1998-99. Many students may be forced to abandon third level education as a result.

Professor Pat Clancy of UCD found that students' chances of attending college depend on their socio-economic background. In his publication, Access to College — Patterns of Continuity and Change, he shows that students whose parents are classed as higher professionals are six times more likely to attend college than students whose parents are classed as semi-skilled or unskilled manual workers. Speaking recently at the conferral ceremony in Dublin City University the president of the college said that he was ashamed to admit that universities in Ireland were still almost exclusively for the relatively well off. There are approximately 6,000 students in full-time third level education from semi-skilled or unskilled manual worker backgrounds. They are finding it increasingly difficult to make ends meet and survive on the paltry maintenance grant.

There have been many calls for radical reform of the maintenance grants scheme. In 1994 the Higher Education Authority steering committee on the future of third level education recommended that the adjacent rate should be increased to £1,500 and the non-adjacent rate to £3,000. Many middle and lower income families are unable to send their children to college. The recommendations of the Butler committee should be implemented. Accommodation should also be provided on campus.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Naughten Mr. Naughten
Speaker.P: Maintenance grants need to be increased dramatically if we are to encourage young people from disadvantaged backgrounds to attend third level. CIE is proposing to increase its charges while it costs up to £80 per week to stay in digs in Dublin. It costs young people more than £5,000 on average to live in Dublin. The maintenance grant meets only a small percentage of this. Income limits must also be increased. They were increased by 77p per week in the budget. This did not match inflation. If we are serious about developing our economy we must look seriously at the maintenance grants system.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Education and Science (Mr. Treacy) Minister of State at the Department of Education and Science (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Education and Science (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.P: Ar an gcéad dul síos ba mhaith liom fáilte a chur roimh Uachtarán agus oifigigh Chumann na Mac-Léinn Aontaithe.

MainHeading.P: Tá súil agam go mbainfidh siad taithneamh as a gcuairt anseo agus go mbeidh breis eolais acu ag deireadh na díospóireachta.

The higher education grants scheme with the vocational education scholarship scheme and the ESF-aided maintenance grants scheme comprise the third level maintenance grants schemes. Sixty per cent of certificate and diploma students in the technological sector and 40 per cent of students in the university sector are eligible for maintenance grants. In the 1996-97 academic year almost 48,000 students received grants under these schemes at a cost of £91 million in 1996.

We are engaged in an ongoing review of all aspects of the third level maintenance grants schemes. It has been the practice in recent years to increase maintenance grants in line with inflation as measured by the change in the consumer price index. The inflation figure provided by the Central Statistics Office for the period mid-February 1997 to mid-February 1998 was 1.7 per cent. The value of the maintenance grant was therefore increased by 1.7 per cent for the 1998-99 academic year.

It has also been the practice in recent years to increase the reckonable income limits in line with movements in the average industrial wage. The figures provided by the Central Statistics Office are computed in each case to March of the previous year. The average industrial wage increase for the period March 1996 to March 1997 was 3.2 per cent. The reckonable income limits for the 1998-99 academic year were therefore increased by 3.2 per cent. This increase was also applied to the allowance by which the income limits may be increased in respect of other family members pursuing a course of study. The definition of eligible courses has also been extended to include those family members attending a recognised PLC course, student nurse training, student Garda training, those participating in certain CERT courses and those attending full-time Teagasc courses in an agricultural college. In each such case the reckonable income limits are increased by £2,060. The full maintenance grant for the current academic year has been increased to £1,652 at the non-adjacent rate and £660 at the adjacent rate.

Our priority in relation to student support has been to honour the commitment given in the Programme for Government, An Action Programme for the Millennium, to introduce equitable support for students attending PLC courses. We have honoured that commitment by way of introducing a maintenance grants scheme for students attending post-leaving certificate courses. The scheme was issued to vocational education committees in August and it is anticipated that the first payment to students, which will be retrospective to September, will be made not later than January next. The grants payable under this scheme will be at the same level as the third level maintenance grants.

We are committed to ongoing improvements to the third level student support schemes, including increasing the value of maintenance grants and income limits as resources permit. The Deputies will appreciate that such improvements must have regard to overall resource constraints and competing demands in the third level sector. In this regard the creation of additional places at third level is critical. We have increased the number of places significantly and will continue to do so, particularly in the context of skills shortages to ensure that those who attend third level will virtually be guaranteed a job.
I thank the Deputies for raising this important matter. The record of my party in investing in education will be maintained in perpetuity.
The Dáil adjourned at 9.50 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Thursday, 1 October 1998.

Qst.hpid: Ms O. Mitchell Ms O. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: the way in which she intends to respond to the recommendations of the Dublin Transportation Office in its report outlining the immediate short-term measures required to cater for the transportation deficit and to alleviate congestion.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The bulk of the public transport recommendations of the DTO Action Plan have already been given the go ahead for implementation. As part of the reallocation of EU aid for the Luas project, approval was given to Bus Átha Cliath to acquire 50 additional buses at a total cost of £8.5 million.

A range of rail measures was also approved including the upgrading of the Maynooth rail service, purchase of additional DART and suburban rolling stock and platform lengthening. All but one of the rail measures (DART signalling) proposed by the action plan have been included in the reallocation of the Luas funding. Consequently £61.5 million of the £65.5 million investment proposed in the action plan is already committed.

Additional funding has also been provided to accelerate the completion of the quality bus corridor network. Bus Átha Cliath will also replace more than 120 buses in 1998 and 1999 from its own resources, as recommended in the DTO Action Plan.

The DTO Action Plan also recommended the acquisition by Bus Átha Cliath of a further 100 buses and the provision of additional State subvention to support expanded peak hour bus and rail services. These recommendations will be considered by Government as part of the Estimates and budget process.

Qst.Quest: if she has received the integrated study on public transport in Cork city from CIE; if so, her views on the study; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In the context of developing proposals for inclusion in Ireland's application for post-1999 EU funding, CIE recently submitted to my Department a review which it carried out of its bus and rail transport investment needs in the greater Cork area. This submission is currently being considered by my Department, in conjunction with the Department of Finance which has the lead role in the preparation of the overall application. That Department will also be engaging in a consultative process with the regional authorities and the social partners before finalising Ireland's application to the European Commission.

Qst.Quest: the resources, if any, she has made available to Bus Atha Cliath to provide more buses at the same time as the new quality bus corridors will come into operation; the number of additional buses proposed; when they will be delivered; and the future assessment of additional buses to be made available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As part of the reallocation of the Luas EU assistance, approval has been given for the acquisition by Bus Átha Cliath of an additional 50 buses at a total cost of £8.5 million. These buses, which are expected to be delivered in autumn 1999, will be used on the quality bus corridors and will increase morning rush hour capacity by 3,500. This is the first occasion on which we have succeeded in obtaining the agreement of the European Commission to co-finance the purchase of buses. The balance of the funding for the acquisition of these buses is to be provided by the Exchequer.

In line with the DTO Short Term Action Plan, Bus Átha Cliath will also acquire, from its own resources, over 120 double decker buses in 1998 and 1999 to replace an equivalent number of old single decker and double decker buses. This will increase capacity by some 2,450 passenger trips.

In addition to these measures the DTO Short Term Action Plan has identified a requirement for 100 extra buses and the need for additional State subvention to support expanded peak hour bus services. These recommendations will be considered by Government as part of the Estimates and budget process.

The action plan also proposes that Bus Átha Cliath subcontract some school bus services. This would release buses for use in the morning peak commuter services and provide capacity for an extra 4,200 passenger trips. This measure is part of the wider restructuring negotiations and these proposals are being considered by the Labour Court at present.

The various initiatives to increase bus capacity are being taken in tandem with the acceleration of the quality bus corridor network. This network will be extended to 12 routes with the addition of a QBC to Ballymun. Additional funding of over £9.4 million as part of the reallocation of the Luas aid means that approximately £12 million will be allocated in DTO traffic management grants in 1999 and 2000 for the implementation of QBCs.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Allocation of Television Channels.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the communication received by members of the Oireachtas from RTE expressing concern at the allocation of television channels arising from the broadcasting of TV3; whether she has given any indication of the nature of these inquiries to the Director of Telecommunications Regulation; if she has satisfied herself that the Director has organised channel allocation in a way which reflects customer needs; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I have seen recent press articles concerning legal action taken by RTE in relation to the allocation of television channels by a cable TV company but I have received no correspondence on the matter.

The redistribution of television signals by multichannel television operators is subject to the terms of their licences which are enforced by the Director of Telecommunications Regulation and I have no function in the matter. I understand that, provided the licensees redistribute the television signals for the channels which they are obliged to carry within specified broadcasting bands, it is a matter for the licensees themselves to allocate the channels as they see fit and to advise their customers of this.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Aer Lingus Privatisation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Higgins (Dublin West) Mr. Higgins (Dublin West)
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to secure a strategic partner for Aer Lingus including the percentage holding the Government intends the State to retain in the company; and her views on the concerns of Aer Lingus employees in relation to the security of their jobs and working conditions.

her views on the proposal to privatise a large section of Aer Lingus; the way in which this will assist the airline to achieve long-term viability; the way in which the proceeds of this privatisation will be utilised; the way in which the employees of Aer Lingus will be involved in the process; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
if she will confirm that Shannon Airport's trans-Atlantic operations will not be sacrificed to cement a strategic alliance for Aer Lingus; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the position regarding a strategic partner for Aer Lingus; the nature of the partnership proposed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
her views on a strategic alliance partner for Aer Lingus; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 75, 93, 107, 111 and 275 together.

MainHeading.P: Deputies will be aware that, in 1997, my predecessor mandated the board of Aer Lingus to explore the possibility of entering into a major strategic alliance, with or without equity, and to submit proposals to the shareholder.
On Friday 4 September 1998 I received a report from the executive chairman of Aer Lingus in response to that mandate.

Having examined a number of strategic options, Aer Lingus concluded that the commercial future of the airline could only be secured through participation in a major strategic alliance, of which a strong US partner would be a key component.
I submitted that report to Government on Tuesday 8 September 1998 which agreed that it should be published. All Members of the
Oireachtas received a copy and it was freely distributed to staff representatives, the media and other interested parties.

Arising from their consideration of that report, the Government agreed, in principle, that Aer Lingus should seek a partner, that the partnership could be equity based and that the process could move to the next stage.

The current position is that the executive chairman of Aer Lingus will undertake discussions over the coming weeks and months with prospective partners and he will report back to me on developments from time to time, on an interim basis. He has told me however, that this stage could take up to six months. Depending on the outcome, there will be a number of issues which will fall to be considered in detail. These could include the way in which the proceeds of any equity sale, if the Government were to decide on such a course, would be utilised.

It is much too soon to speculate on the outcome of the next phase and all the issues that may or may not arise. I assure the House there will be careful and detailed consideration and consultation in order to ensure the best outcome for the airline, its employees and the taxpayer.
There is no intention of sacrificing Shannon Airport's transatlantic operations to achieve a strategic alliance for Aer Lingus.

Since I received the report I have had the following meetings: on Tuesday 8 September 1998 following a ceremony to mark the commencement of work on a £40 million extension to the terminal buildings at Shannon, I met signal representatives in Shannon to discuss their specific concerns about the report; on Wednesday 9 September 1998 I met the chairman and senior executives of Aer Lingus to advise on the Government decision and to agree a way forward; and on Wednesday, 16 September 1998, I met the Aer Lingus Central Representative Council. I assured it this process would be conducted on the basis of the partnership approach that is already established in Aer Lingus, that its concerns would be taken on board throughout the process and that I would be available to meet it as appropriate.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Duty Free Sales.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the position in relation to the campaign to retain duty free facilities; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

the position regarding efforts to have duty free facilities retained; if she will report on the meeting with Mr Andre Capet, Transport Deputy of the Calais region; the new initiatives, if any, she is planning to have duty free facilities retained; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the position regarding efforts to have duty free facilities retained; the plans, if any, she has to take any new initiatives in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 76, 92 and 118 together.

Because the link between duty free facilities and transport is significant, and all the more so in the case of Ireland, I, as Minister for Public Enterprise, will continue my endeavours to raise the profile of the duty free facilities issue at home and abroad and to press for an open-ended deferral at every possible opportunity.
Last Monday I met my French counterpart, Mr. Jean-Claud Gayssot, in Dublin to discuss the options in relation to the planned abolition of duty-free sales at the end of June 1999.

The French Transport Minister provided me with a copy of the recently completed study of the impact of the abolition of duty-free sales in France. The study was carried out by Mr. André Capet, Deputy for the Calais region. Mr. Capet visited me in June of this year when he was researching his report. The report concludes that the abolition would have a major impact on French aviation and airports, the maritime sector and on the cognac, champagne and perfume manufacturers.
The Taoiseach has written to the French Prime Minister, M. Lionel Jospin, suggesting that the Capet report could provide a basis for a series of options for action on the duty free facilities issue.

At the European level the European Commission is preparing a report on the possible mechanisms and aids to counter the negative economic effects of the abolition of duty free sales. This report will be tabled at a future ECOFIN meeting where my colleague, the Minister for Finance, will have an opportunity, once more, to put forward the Irish case for deferral of the decision.

MainHeading.P: As we approach the countdown to June 1999 neither myself nor the Minister, Deputy McCreevy, will be found wanting in our efforts to pursue the case at every possible opportunity, particularly in our endeavours to convince the larger member states to take up the running. This is now the key requirement. Ireland has brought the proposed abolition of duty free sales onto the agenda of the European Council, the larger member states need to come forward and actively carry the campaign to a positive conclusion. Ireland cannot do it alone.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if her Department has any role in the public procurement procedures of commercial State companies under EU rules; if the social and economic impact of switching control from indigenous suppliers in disadvantaged areas can be factored into such decisions under EU rules; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The procurement processes of all State bodies are subject to the EU Public Procurement Directives, which set out detailed rules on the procurement of goods and services. State bodies in the energy, transport and telecommunications sectors are subject to special procurement directives — the “Utilities Directives”— which recognise the commercial character of their operations. The actual implementarion of the directives, and the purchasing arrangements for goods and services adopted, are matters for the individual bodies themselves.

It is a basic principle of public procurement policy that a procedure based on competitive tendering should always be used. The directives preclude any form of regional or national preference which is discriminatory or anti-competitive.

However in certain circumstances special preferences may be taken into account in the execution of a contract but only where they do not breach Community legislation or the principles of the Treaty of Rome.
The Minister for Finance has overall responsibility for the Procurement Directives.

Qst.Quest: if CIE has submitted its economic and financial appraisal on its investment plans for the mainline rail network for the post-1999 period; the discussions, if any, she has had with the Department of Finance to secure matching Exchequer funding for CIE in relation to its investment proposals; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: CIE has submitted proposals for substantial investment in the mainline network. A full economic and financial appraisal of the proposals is not yet complete. My Department has made an initial submission on EU funding for public transport projects in the post-1999 period. The submission takes account of proposed investments for mainline rail identified by CIE.

In addition an independent safety review of railway infrastructure was carried out earlier this year for Iarnród Éireann by consultants A.D. Little. The consultants identified a number of areas where investment will be required over the coming years.

I also commissioned a strategic review of all aspects of rail safety to be carried out by consultants, International Risk Management Services. The review, which will take into account the A.D. Little findings, is expected to be completed in October and it is my intention to publish it.

Arising from the A.D. Little Report, I asked CIE to prepare a railway safety investment plan which I will consider in conjunction with the IRMS report when it comes to hand. When I have completed my consideration of these reports I will make appropriate recommendations to Government at an early date. The Minister for Finance will be consulted in the preparation of these recommendations.

Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in proceeding with the refurbishment of the Ferbane peat fire station; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A feasibility study carried out during 1995 and 1996 examined the question of building a new peat fired power station in west Offaly. The study was managed by a steering group chaired by a senior officer of my Department with representatives of ESB, Bord na Móna, Offaly County Enterprise Board, and local employees from Bord na Móna and ESB.

The group examined a number of options, including the building of a new 30MW station on a green field site, a new station on the existing Ferbane site, and/or the refurbishment of one or more of the existing units.

The main conclusion of the study, finalised on 31 May 1996, was that the refurbishment of the 30MW unit at Ferbane, and its operation with competitive manning levels, was the best of the options available.

The refurbishment would ensure the continued generation of electricity at Ferbane, thus sustaining employment in the station and on the bogs supplying it. The boards of both Bord na Móna and ESB endorsed the report.

Competitive manning levels and new work practices are vital to the future of Ferbane as the ESB face into competition under the new Electricity Directive. The necessary changes were an integral part of the CCR agreement and were agreed both nationally and locally. Unfortunately, it has not proved possible to reach agreement with some of the workforce to implement the relevant changes already agreed in the CCR.

The management of ESB, therefore, notified the station workforce on 24 September that it could not proceed with refurbishment of the station in the circumstances. I understand that a recommendation for closure of the station at an early date will be put to the ESB board at its meeting on 16 October 1998.
I now understand the ESB Joint Industrial Council has invited all the parties involved to a meeting tomorrow, 1 October, and the outcome of that meeting will be awaited with interest.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made at EU level with the proposal to provide a high speed train from Belfast to Dublin and further to Cork; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The route from Belfast to Dublin and Cork has been included as part of the Trans European Network. This decision facilitated the approval of EU funding as a result of which the Belfast to Dublin line has benefited from a major investment programme which includes the upgrading of track to continuous welded rail on concrete sleepers, major infrastructure works, signalling upgrade and rolling stock replacement. This investment programme, costing approximately £124 million, of which about £66 million has been spent on the southern section of the line, received financial assistance from both the European Regional Development Fund and from the Cohesion Fund. Work is now complete on the southern side of the Border. As a result of this investment the new Enterprise service was officially launched on 21 October 1997.

The Dublin to Cork line has likewise benefited from substantial EU co-financed investment. The line has received aid of £10.2 million from the Structural Fund 1993-99. By the end of next year the complete line will have been upgraded to continuous welded rail.

The services on this route operate between Belfast and Dublin, Connolly and from Dublin, Heuston to Cork. The provision of services is a matter for the transport companies but there are no proposals to provide a high speed train service from Belfast through to Cork. However, the option of upgrading the link between Connolly and Heuston stations is being kept under review.

Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 88, 98, 102, 109 and 123 together.

The first phase of the extended light rail project approved by Government includes two lines: Tallaght to Connolly Station and Sandyford to Ballymun and Dublin Airport. The estimated cost of this phase is in excess of £400 million and when further detailed technical work has been carried out a firm cost estimate will be available.

MainHeading.P: Consultants commissioned by the Department of Finance, to analyse the possibilities for publicprivate partnerships in Ireland, recommended that a pilot approach to PPPs should be adopted and this was accepted by the Government. Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: In the light of the accelerating demand for natural gas, a study is being jointly undertaken by my Department and Bord Gáis Éireann of natural gas demand and infrastructure requirements to the year 2025. The objective of this study is to determine the optimal long-term transmission infrastructure necessary to meet gas demand projections, taking into account the various gas demand scenarios that might develop. Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)

MainHeading.P: As to the Ministerial Committee on Nuclear Safety, there have been three meetings since the committee was established in February this year. I am Chairman of the committee and the other members of the committee are: Deputy Byrne, Minister of State at the Department of Marine and Natural Resources; Deputy Moffat, Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children; Deputy Wallace, Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government; Deputy Molloy, Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government; Deputy O'Donnell, Minister of State at the Department of Foreign Affairs.
The committee also includes representatives from the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland and the Attorney General's office and officials from various Government Departments.

The committee has adopted a work programme encompassing a wide range of nuclear safety and radiological protection issues, including the campaign against Sellafield. A copy of the work programme was made available to a number of Deputies including Deputy Gilmore in June. The main activities under the work programme come within the area of responsibility of my Department and the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland. Over the coming months, in addition to issues directly relating to the Government's ongoing campaign against Sellafield and the UK nuclear industry generally, the committee's work programme will include a review of the National Emergency Plan for Nuclear Accidents; discussion on radon-related matters; issues arising in regard to the County Louth Residents' legal action against British Nuclear Fuels and a review of progress in regard to implementation of the EU Basic Safety Standards Directive on the protection of workers and the general public against the dangers of ionising radiation.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Communications Masts.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to introduce legislation to ensure mobile phone companies share their telecommunications masts following her review of the rules governing internconnection regulation as promised on 3 June 1998 in Dáil Éireann; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I will reiterate the points I made in my reply to the question he refers to — Question No. 22 of 3 June 1998.

I fully support the principle of sharing masts and other telecommunications infrastructure to reduce the impact of telecommunications infrastructure on the environment and to promote economic efficiency.

As I explained in my earlier reply, the Director of Telecommunications Regulation is empowered to intervene to resolve disputes over facility sharing among telecommunications operators, including mobile phone companies, under the Interconnection Regulations (S. I. No. 15 of 1998), which I signed into law earlier this year.

MainHeading.P: A Bill which will provide for an up to date and balanced regulatory regime in the development of telecommunications infrastructure is currently in preparation in my Department. I propose to incorporate in the Bill the facility sharing provisions which are included in the Interconnection Regulations and to extend those provisions to certain other facilities.
The final decision on the contents of the Bill will be made in consultation with my Cabinet colleagues. I hope to be in a position to publish the Bill during the current Dáil session.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Railway Freight Transport.

Qst.Quest: her views on the benefits to be obtained from the greater use of rail transportation in the bulk transport of mineral ores; her views on whether the progressive liberalisation of the transport sector since 1971 has led to measurable environmental benefits; her projections in relation to a desirable market share of the freight market to be held by the railways; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

the consideration, if any, she has given to the provision of supports to industry by way of grant-aid with the objective of transferring freight volumes away from our overcrowded roads and onto our under-utilised railway system in view of the National Minerals Policy Review Group report entitled, A New Minerals Policy, published in 1995; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

the steps, if any, she will take to address the competitive disadvantage suffered by the rail sector in the bulk freight market in view of the fact that road hauliers have their infrastructure installed by the State at no direct cost to their operations whereas rail carriers must pass on capital costs to their customers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 99, 130 and 138 together.

The trend across the European Union has been towards road freight transport. This has been driven more by the speed and flexibility of this mode rather than by the impact of liberalisation in the road transport sector.

In Ireland there are a number of additional factors which militate against significant growth in the railway's share of the freight market. International experience suggests that rail freight comes into its own for journeys in excess of 200 kilometers and very few freight journeys in Ireland would exceed that length. There are also areas which are geographically remote from a railhead. Ireland's island status and the absence of a fixed link to mainland Europe makes railbased combined transport a less effective option than in the rest of the EU.

MainHeading.P: Notwithstanding these constraints, the railway still has approximately a 10 per cent share of the overall freight market in Ireland.

Policies are being pursued by the EU aimed at counteracting the negative environmental impact of road freight transport and promoting the increased use of rail freight and combined transport. These policies include a balanced mix of measures aimed at improved vehicle design, fuel efficiencies, transport logistics and information systems. They also include the liberalisation of the rail freight market and the internalisation of the external costs of transport.

Ireland adopts a constructive approach to legislative and policy measures proposed by the Commission in these areas, but we also have to ensure that the implementation of these measures does not adversely impact on the competitiveness of our economy. Because of our peripheral location, the length of journeys to our main export markets, our dependence on sea and air access transport and the fact that rail is often not a viable alternative for many businesses, we have to pay particular attention to the impact of EU proposals on transport costs.

The annual State subvention to CIE covers the entire expenditure on rail infrastructure as well as contributing to railway operating costs. Consequently rail freight is not at a disadvantage due to the need to cover infrastructure costs.

On the question of transporting mineral ores and other freight by rail, I should explain that this is an operational issue for Iarnród Éireann, taking into account commercial and other considerations. I have no statutory function in this area. In view of the environmental benefits I would, in general, be in favour of an increase in the share of the freight market held by the railways provided it can be done on a commercial basis without distortion of competition in the freight market and without adversely affecting the competitive position of Irish industry. The EU proposal to establish a common infrastructure charging framework is aimed at eliminating competitive distortions between transport modes and there are, therefore, no plans to subsidise rail freight.

The issues regarding rail freight addressed in the document “A New Minerals Policy” relate to the potential to alleviate potential adverse impacts on the environment due to road carriage of minerals. I have no doubt that these matters are fully considered by local authorities during the planning approval process.

Qst.Quest: if she has succeeded in obtaining probability risk assessments from BNFL or the United Kingdom's Government in relation to the high level waste storage plants at Sellafield; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I should point out that my concerns about the storage of High Level Waste at Sellafield have been conveyed to the UK Authorities on a number of occasions. In recent correspondence with the UK Minister for Energy, Mr. John Battle, MP, I called for the vitrification programme to be accelerated to facilitate a much earlier target date than 2015 for the clearance of the backlog of the waste.

Up to now, BNFL has refused to release publicly probabilistic risk assessment on grounds of commercial confidentiality. I have written to UK Ministers in support of the RPII's request for access to the probabilistic assessments. Since then the RPII has been in discussions with BNFL about alternative means of reassuring the RPII about safety standards which would overcome BNFL's misgivings about commercial confidentiality. To date these contacts have not yet concluded.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to deal with the enforcement of road transport legislation in respect of out of State hauliers; if a new directive concerning access to the profession of road haulage and road passenger transport operations has been finalised; the further plans, if any, she has to reintroduce the Road Transport Bill; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I intend to include measures in the Road Transport Bill to deal effectively with the enforcement of the road transport legislation in respect of out-of-State hauliers when I reintroduce this Bill.
The new directive dealing with access to the profession of road haulage operator and road passenger transport operator has not yet been finalised.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Ryan Mr. S. Ryan
Qst.Quest: her views on the privatisation of Aer Rianta; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will indicate her preference for the future of Aer Rianta to the board of the company when she orders the fundamental review of the company; her views on the likely outcome of the review; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the terms of reference of the review of the options open to Aer Rianta ordered by her on 12 August 1998; if the review will take account of the strategic importance of the airports operated by Aer Rianta, especially in the context of the tourism industry; when the report will be completed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.
the purpose and substance of the proposed review of Aer Rianta; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 104, 116, 117 and 125 together.

Aer Rianta faces significant challenges in the years immediately ahead. It faces heavy demands on its resources arising from the formidable but necessary capital programme currently proposed for the three State airports. I am aware that to take advantage of international investment opportunities in airports and airport related business, where Aer Rianta has demonstrated special abilities in the past, substantial funds will be required. All this will place a heavy strain on the finances of this successful company.

There are, moreover, major changes taking place in the markets in which all State companies under my aegis operate. In light of this, it is now appropriate to undertake a fundamental review of the future development of the company. This is why I wrote to the Chairman on 11 August last and asked the board to give serious consideration to the full range of future development options, which present themselves. I have specifically asked the board of Aer Rianta to reflect on what might be the most appropriate strategic direction for Aer Rianta in the years ahead.

My view is that we need to take an open and pragmatic approach to the question of the best way forward for all the commercial State companies operating under my aegis, including Aer Rianta. I am satisfied that Aer Rianta has, in the past, faced complex challenges and proven itself to be a vibrant and successful operator, both at home and abroad and I am fully confident that the board of the company can now address new challenges with the same openness and energy. In requesting the board to conduct the review, I have not attempted to influence their deliberations in any way, nor have I ruled any future development options in or out. I am aware that the board has commenced the review in partnership with staff in line with the spirit of co-operation integral to Aer Rianta's Compact for Constructive Participation and I fully endorse this approach.

I would expect Aer Rianta to be in a position to report to me with the results of its review within six months. Ultimately, any decision about the future of Aer Rianta will be one for Government to take, following a recommendation by myself. It would not be helpful or appropriate for me to speculate at this point as to the likely outcome of the review.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Ryan Mr. S. Ryan
Qst.Quest: if she will report on the possibility of providing a direct mainline rail or DART connection to the airport from the Dublin to Belfast rail line in view of the growth in the number of passengers using Dublin Airport and the difficulty in accessing the airport for private transport.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Córas Iompair Éireann and Aer Rianta set up a working group to examine the feasibility of a rail connection from Dublin airport to the mainline rail network. The draft final report of this group was submitted to my Department in December 1997. It concluded against a rail link to the Dublin-Belfast line for operational and capacity reasons and instead proposed a diesel rail link to the Sligo line at a capital cost of £140 million. The report also identified a number of matters which required further evaluation. One of the matters requiring further evaluation is the traffic inter-relationship between this rail link and the planned light rail line to the airport.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Natural Gas Grid.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that 205 million ECU has been approved in funding by the EU Commission to provide a supply of natural gas in Spanish regions eligible under Objective One status; the plans, if any, she has to enter into negotiations with Bord Gáis Éireann to draw up proposals to extend the national gas pipeline in Ireland with a view to seeking EU funding post 1999; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I have had this matter examined by my Department and that examination has included consultation with the European Commission. The envelope of European Regional Development Fund aid currently available to Ireland in the 1993-9 round of EU funding is set out in the Community Support Framework agreement between the European Commission and Ireland. The funding priorities for each of the sectors is prescribed in the individual operational programmes. None of the operational programmes which form part of the Community Framework for Ireland for 1993-9 contain any European Regional Development Fund provision for development of the gas infrastructure. By contrast, the EU aid allocation for Spain for 1993-9 does contain an aid provision for the development of gas infrastructure.

MainHeading.P: Bord Gáis Éireann's future infrastructural requirements are being considered in the context of the Gas Demand 2025 Study being jointly undertaken by my Department and BGE. Post-1999 EU funding requirements in this regard have been included in my Department's overall submission to the Department of Finance concerning Structural Funding requirements for the period 1999-2006.

Qst.Quest: if, further to Parliamentary Question No. 34 of 3 June 1998, she will outline further progress in relation to the discussions on the viability plan for CIE; if she has satisfied herself with process made to date; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The three CIE subsidiary companies have been engaged in negotiations on necessary change and restructuring for some time. The parties are being assisted in their negotiations by the Labour Relations Commission and I understand that progress is being made, albeit slowly.
While the initial rejection of proposals by drivers in Dublin Bus has been disappointing, the acceptance of proposals by maintenance staff in Bus Éireann is very welcome.

A successful outcome to these negotiations is primarily a matter for the management and unions involved. While I recognise that progress to date has been slow, I hope that with the assistance of the State's industrial relations machinery, where required, the negotiations can be concluded to the satisfaction of all parties.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, Iarnród Éireann has for upgrading the Mallow to Tralee line and, in particular, from Killarney to Tralee; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: On 25 June last I announced an investment package of £26 million for mainline rail track upgrading as part of the reallocation of EU aid which was decommitted from the Luas project. The investment package includes an allocation of £10 million to complete the upgrading of the Mallow to Killarney line to continuous welded track.

In the context of developing proposals for inclusion in Ireland's application for post-1999 EU funding, CIE has submitted to my Department a number of studies related to its bus and rail transport investment needs, including a review of mainline rail requirements. The mainline rail review includes investment proposals for the upgrading of the Killarney to Tralee line.

These submissions are currently being considered by my Department, in conjunction with the Department of Finance which has the lead role in the preparation of the overall application. That Department will also engage in a consultative process with the regional authorities and the social partners before finalising Ireland's application to the European Commission.

Qst.Quest: if she is in a position to approve the ESB's application to build a 350/400 MW combined cycle gas turbine power station in advance of her publishing a Bill to establish an independent regulatory commission in view of the urgent need to increase capacity; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Record economic growth has fuelled an unprecedented demand for electricity with the result that new generating capacity is expected to be needed by late 2001 or early 2002.

The current legal situation is that the ESB requires my approval under the Electricity Supply Acts for capital expenditure on any new plant. Private sector companies, on the other hand, wishing to enter the market in competition with ESB require a permit from ESB under the Electricity Supply Act, 1927. ESB is, therefore, currently in the position of operating in the market and at the same time regulating the entry of competitors. I have been advised by the Attorney General to introduce a Bill to establish an independent regulatory commission to oversee the electricity sector.

The new EU Electricity Directive, which came into force in February 1997, must be implemented in Ireland by February 2000. This directive requires that 28 per cent of the electricity market must be open to competition by then.

I recently announced that the Government had approved the drafting of the necessary Bill to establish an independent regulatory commission. I hope that this Commission will be in place by early next year.

The regulatory commission will operate a licensing regime for operators wishing to generate and sell electricity. It will also issue authorisations for the construction of generating stations. Any proposals to construct a generating station by any party, including ESB, will be subject to an authorisation from the Commission.

Qst.Quest: if she will ensure that the Government decision of April 1996 that any green electricity generator that can supply any electricity customer will not be compromised when the new regulatory commission for electricity is established and the wheeling charges for use of the electricity grid are put in place, that is, that the 1996 deregulation is not revised; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I support the 1996 Government decision and I plan to implement that decision in the Bill currently being drafted to establish an independent regulatory commission to oversee the electricity sector. This Bill will include a provision enabling consumers to purchase electricity generated from renewable energy.

I envisage that this provision will be brought into effect once the detailed practical arrangements, including trading arrangements, for the opening of the market in accordance with the EU Electricity Directive, have been developed and implemented.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if she is in a position to sign off on the agreement for the rationalisation of the various pension schemes in relation to salaried officers and clerks in CIE; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As outlined in my reply to a Parliamentary Question No. 43 of 3 June 1998, amending schemes were drafted to give effect to the necessary restructuring of CIE's salaried staff superannuation schemes. However, during the course of the examination of the draft amending schemes by the Attorney General's office, legal problems were identified which necessitated considerable detailed attention.

This process was almost complete when further legal complications arose. These issues are being urgently addressed by my Department, CIE and the Office of the Attorney General and it is possible that primary legislation may be required. I am not in a position to approve the schemes until these legal issues have been resolved. However, I can confirm that, irrespective of the length of time it takes to complete the arrangements for approval, the agreed terms of the new scheme include a provision for an effective date of 1 January 1994.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Nuclear Safety.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. B. Moynihan-Cronin Mrs. B. Moynihan-Cronin
Qst.Quest: the changes, if any, made to the 1973 Euratom Agreement (Nuclear Safeguards Agreement) by the recent adoption of the new protocol additional to that agreement; the other changes sought by Ireland to that agreement that are not included in the new protocol; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The objective of the new protocol is to strengthen the effectiveness and efficiency of the existing Safeguards Agreement entered into following on from the Treaty on Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The existing agreement is implemented by the International Atomic Energy Agency as part of an international effort to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and to provide assurances about the peaceful use of nuclear materials.

MainHeading.P: The new protocol extends the scope of the existing agreement to include specified equipment and non-nuclear materials of a dual-use capability, i.e. civil or military. Under the protocol, contracting parties will be obliged to furnish information to the IAEA on the manufacture and export of components and equipment used in the civil nuclear industry that could potentially be used to manufacture nuclear weapons.

The discovery earlier in the decade of progress made by Iraq and North Korea towards developing nuclear weapons demonstrated to the international community that the existing safeguards regime had been insufficient to detect violations. It raised serious questions about the credibility of the IAEA safeguards system. The response of the international community was to design a future IAEA safeguards system, which would both strengthen the effectiveness and improve the efficiency of the existing regime, the so-called 93+2 programme.

The protocol signed in Vienna last week by Ireland and the other non-nuclear weapons states of the EU is modelled on this new system and is consistent with the aims of Irish policy. Ireland strongly supported efforts to improve and reinforce the existing safeguards programme.

Qst.Quest: if she has raised the Government's concerns with Mr. John Battle MP, Minister of State for Nuclear Safety Policy in the United Kingdom Government, following the publishing of the report on the many safety problems at the Dounreay nuclear plant; if she has sought reports on all other British nuclear plants in view of the serious implications of management failure at this plant; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. E. Ryan Mr. E. Ryan
Qst.Quest: if she will seek a meeting with the relevant Minister in the British Government for a full briefing on the recent report on the Dounreay Nuclear Power Plant.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The report to which the Deputies refer was published by the UK Health and Safety Executive on 1 September 1998. It details the results of a safety audit of the Dounreay plant undertaken jointly by the HSE and the Scottish Environment Protection Agency following an incident on 7 May of this year, which left the fuel cycle area without its normal electricity supplies for 16 hours.

MainHeading.P: The report makes 143 recommendations for improvements at Dounreay to bring it up to the standards required to enable the site to be decommissioned and made safe. Most of the recommendations relate to on-site health and safety issues, waste management and the minimisation of discharges to the environment. The operators of the Dounreay site, UKAEA, have until 30 November 1998 to submit a programme for implementing the works recommended in the report. I understand that the report would be published soon after 30 November next.

I have not at this stage requested similar safety audits to be carried out on other UK nuclear power plants. On the basis of advice which I receive from the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland it is my intention to keep this matter, and in particular the implementation of the recommendations of the Dounreay report, under review through the auspices of existing formal contacts between Irish and UK officials on nuclear safety matters.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Shannon Airport.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has for Shannon Airport in view of the concerns among tourists' interests arising from the decline in market share in the west and mid-west regions; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: As regards my plans for Shannon Airport, the first need is to support the growth of Shannon and this requires ongoing investment in airport facilities. Earlier this month I laid the foundation stone for a new terminal building at Shannon which is part of a £40 million investment by Aer Rianta aimed at doubling the existing capacity of the departures terminal, improving access to the airport and numerous other improvements to the facilities.

The second need is to provide the widest possible range of air services. Only last Friday I announced the establishment of the headquarters of Virgin Express (Ireland) Ltd. at the airport and its plans for twice daily flights, including a 7 a.m. early morning departure to London/Stansted, which will meet a long-standing demand from the business community. This latest announcement comes on top of a string of new services launched from Shannon over the past year, including Continental to Newark and AB airlines to Birmingham and Stansted. Polar Air Cargo began cargo services to New York and Chicago last May, to add to the San Francisco and Chicago routes of Lufthansa and Cargolux which commenced less than a year ago.

I also announced the proposed relocation by Royal Jordanian Airlines of its European hub to Shannon. When fully relocated, Royal Jordanian will operate, through Shannon during the peak season, seven return flights per week to New York and three flights to Chicago, with an additional weekly freight service between Amman and New York. As a further incentive to relocate, I have agreed to grant Royal Jordanian local pick-up rights at Shannon for each of these services.

MainHeading.P: Shannon Airport can best support the needs of the west and mid-west regions by providing a key infrastructural asset which contributes positively to meeting all the air transport needs of the region, not just in respect of tourism but also to service the ever growing demand from the business community, and to cater for the rapidly increasing air freight sector. I am confident that Shannon Airport is doing this today and will continue to do so in the future.

Qst.hpid: Mrs. B. Moynihan-Cronin Mrs. B. Moynihan-Cronin
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to establish a Charter of Rights for telephone users as provided for under the EU Open Network Provision Directive in view of her decision to liberalise the telecommunications market in Ireland for voice telephony; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Directive 98/10/EC on the application of open network provisions to voice telephony is in effect a charter of rights for telephone subscribers and users. It sets out a range of obligations with which telephone companies must comply in the interests of users in the fully liberalised telecommunications market. These include a right of connection to the fixed public telephone network and access to fixed public telephone services, provisions relating to the quality and capability of those services, directory services and public pay telephones, measures to cater for vulnerable groups of users such as the elderly, those with disabilities and those with special needs, the adjustment of tariffs to ensure the affordability of services and the publication and access to information relating to services.

My Department is at present working on the transposition of the provisions of this directive into national law by means of a Statutory Instrument which I expect to be in a position to sign later this year.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to introduce a home energy efficiency scheme to insulate homes here similar to schemes operating in Northern Ireland and Great Britain; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I have no plans to introduce a home energy efficiency scheme. The Energy Advisory Board has commissioned a study into the structure, content and funding of a national energy efficiency programme from 2000-5.
The outcome of that study will inform my decision on the matter.

Qst.Quest: the submission, if any, her Department has made to the EU in relation to funding for the period 2000 to 2004 for the Athlone to Westport to Ballina rail link.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Primary responsibility for the preparation of submissions for EU funding lies with the Department of Finance. In response to a request from that Department, my Department made an initial submission in June on EU funding for public transport projects in the post-1999 period. This submission takes account of the CIE review of mainline rail investment needs mentioned in my reply to the Deputy on 3 June 1998, and includes investment proposals for the Athlone to Westport/Ballina lines. The Department of Finance will also be engaging in a consultative process with the regional authorities and social partners before finalising Ireland's submission to the European Commission.

Qst.Quest: the work, if any, carried out on the now discontinued scheme of grants for energy audits; the number of audits followed up by concrete action; if the benefits of this action were assessed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The energy audit grant scheme closed for applications on 31 October, 1997. Under the scheme a total of 424 audits received aggregate grant aid of IR£774,758. A further 16 audits, in respect of which IR£51,434 in grant aid has been approved, are yet to be completed. This final group of audits will be completed before the year end.
There are currently 117 projects with approval under the energy efficiency investment support scheme which stemmed from audits carried out under the energy audit grant scheme.

An evaluation of the energy audit grant scheme was undertaken by the Irish Energy Centre following its closure in October, 1997. Approximately half of all the applications for funding under the investment grant scheme originated with an audit funded under the audit grant scheme.

It is estimated by the Irish Energy Centre that on completion of all such projects aggregate investment in energy efficient technologies will amount to IR£16 million, including European Regional Development Fund support of IR£3.57 million. The resulting annual energy savings are estimated at approximately IR£4 million.

Qst.Quest: if she will make a statement on the trends she would consider desirable in relation to energy consumption in households.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: As the economy continues to grow so does the demand for energy. It is estimated that GDP will have increased by 80 per cent between 1990 and 2000 while energy consumption will have grown by 30 per cent over the same period. It is the aim of my Department and of the Irish Energy Centre to continue delinking economic growth and energy consumption by means of energy efficiency improvements. In the case of the residential sector, the Irish Energy Centre will continue with its programme of raising public awareness of energy conservation and efficiency and influencing householders' attitudes and behaviour in respect of energy use.
