MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Unpaid Work.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made in measuring unpaid work; when the research group's report will be available; and when he envisages that the value of unpaid work to the economy will be included in annual returns of the State.

MainHeading.P: supporting community, local, county or regional

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The current UN and EU national accounting methodology specifically exclude from the national accounts the value of unpaid work, including the work done by members of a household for itself. Any inclusion of unpaid work in the annual accounts would have to include both women's and men's unwaged housework as well as unwaged work done outside the home e.g. voluntary community work. The measurement of the extent of these activities and their valuations will involve considerable work. However, provision is made for the possibility of using satellite accounts to extend the core accounting system to provide additional information where the estimation methods are not yet sufficiently developed to allow their inclusion in the main accounts.

In consideration of this and of the commitments given in Partnership 2000, a pilot time use survey was carried out by the CSO in June 1997. This survey covered some 300 households with nearly 1,000 respondents. As well as answering a wide range of questions, respondents also completed a time use diary, broken down into ten minute intervals, for two days.

Processing of this detailed data has taken longer than planned. The CSO is now analysing the data collected in the survey and is preparing a report on the experience gained in the pilot survey and the implications, particularly in relation to the feasibility and cost of a full-scale time use survey.

In its Statement of Strategy 1998-2000, the CSO has indicated that it will seek Government approval and the necessary resources to conduct a full-time use survey in year 2000. The CSO's priority is to extend the range of data available at present to comply with the requirements of the European system of accounts — ESA95 — as well as fulfilling the requirements of the European Monetary Union. Therefore, it does not envisage being able to undertake the necessary research to incorporate the value of unpaid work in the national accounts for the foreseeable future. However, the CSO is continuing to monitor international methodological developments in this area. There is no research group in the CSO dealing with this issue and I am not aware of any other research group in this area.

Qst.Quest: if he will sanction funds for phase II of the millennium park at Murrisk, Westport, County Mayo.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: The Government has decided to establish a national millennium committee. This committee will examine and make recommendations for State funding of a small number of millennium projects of national significance. It will also examine and recommend a system for projects which will provide an opportunity for local communities, including in areas of social disadvantage, to participate in the millennium commemoration. The proposal for a millennium park at Murrisk, Westport, County Mayo will be referred to the national millennium committee for consideration.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Commission on the Family.

Qst.Quest: the recommendations of the Commission on the Family relevant to his Department; the action, if any, he has taken to date to implement them; and the proposed timetable for full implementation of the recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Bertie Ahern
Speaker.P: There are no specific recommendations of the Commission on the Family directly relevant to my Department. As the Deputy is aware my Department does not have a direct role in operating programmes or grant giving. In the main the recommendations relate to the Departments of Social, Community and Family Affairs; Education and Science and Health and Children. However, I will continue to take an interest in this area and to ensure that any policy decisions taken arising from the recommendations in the report are consistent with the profamilies approach adopted by the Government as outlined in An Action Programme for the Millennium.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if she will outline the difference in availability of secondary benefits to those on the jobs initiative scheme compared to those on the back to work allowance scheme; the way in which the existing differences are justified; and the plans, if any, there are to bring both schemes into line.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The jobs initiative JI and the back to work allowance BTWA scheme have different functions. The JI is an active labour market programme for persons over 35 years of age who have been unemployed for five years or more. The back to work allowance is an in-work subsidy open to persons unemployed for one year or more, who take up a job either as employees or as self-employed.

The schemes are not in competition. A BTWA job is, in principle, permanent whereas a placement on JI is temporary, three years duration. In terms of access to progression options a person on JI has undiminished rights as a long-term unemployed person. This is not the case for persons on BTWA, e.g. it would be possible for a person to progress from JI to BTWA but not vice versa. Because the schemes have different functions and are targeted at different cohorts the incentives to participate are pitched differently, with persons on BTWA being able to retain secondary benefits while persons on JI just retain their medical cards although they are also eligible for family income supplement.

It is worth noting that JI is a pilot programme nearing the second year of completion for the first 1,000 participants. I intend to have the programme independently reviewed in the near future and I would like to see the issue of secondary benefits, addressed inter alia in that review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Health and Safety Standards.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, she proposes to take in order to implement a tougher approach to safety on building sites, resource a more aggressive policy on the part of the Health and Safety Authority in its dealings with the construction industry, have employers take the safety situation of workers more seriously, ensure that workers on building sites are properly and appropriately trained and introduce tougher punitive measures against employers found to be in breach of safety regulations in view of the fatalities on building site that occurred over the summer months; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: There is an extensive block of health and safety legislation in Ireland which adequately meets the requirements necessary to protect our workforce and which conforms to best international practices. Measures such as the Safety, Health and Welfare at Work Act, 1989, the 1993 general application regulations and the 1995 construction regulations provide a solid legislative framework by which effective and co-ordinated management of all construction projects can be ensured, and by which health and safety standards can be set. This legislation specifies that it is the primary duty of every individual employer to identify and manage the health and safety needs of his or her own business, and also lays down the duties of clients, designers and workers.

The National Authority for Occupational Safety and Health is responsible for the enforcement of all occupational health and safety legislation. The authority works to a targeted annual work programme and focuses on sectors with high accident rates and, in particular, the construction sector. The Safety, Health and Walfare at Work Act, 1989, applies to all sectors of employment and the authority approaches its considerable tasks on the basis of a successful combination of information, inspection and enforcement. The authority has always adopted a pro-active approach to its work and, given the ever evolving nature of work to-day, has proven itself more than capable of responding appropriately in different ways to different situations.

MainHeading.P: In this regard, in response to concerns about construction site safety, the authority launched its construction action programme during the summer. This action programme is a wide-ranging exercise which seeks to involve all the players, from client to workers, and to highlight their respective roles in improving site safety. The series of measures announced by the authority, if acted on by all the players in the industry, should help to bring accident rates in construction down to levels in other industries. These measures include the following; clients must be familiar with their legal responsibilities including the need to appoint competent personnel and must be generally aware of work under way, including any major problems arising on safety. To this end the authority will notify major clients who are currently having construction works carried out of the fact of prohibition notices and prosecution proceedings in respect of those works. Public sector clients have a major role to play given the size of the public capital programme. I have written to all my Government colleagues asking them to ensure that no public sector contract is awarded to a firm or contractor who does not have a safety statement as they are obliged to do so under the 1989 Act. Also, the authority is working with the Government contracts committee to see what other measures can be put in place, while still operating within the regulatory framework of public procurement.
It is hoped to involve designers in the improvement of safety standards in new developments, through training and awareness raising exercises.

The training of workers is another key area of concern. In this regard, FÁS will bring together its various training programmes under its new construction skills certification scheme, but of course all personnel on site, whether site managers, employees, sub-contractors or the self-employed need to receive appropriate training in health and safety on a systematic basis. The authority will be discussing with representatives of the industry ways of ensuring that training initiatives such as this have the maximum take-up.

The role of workers themselves has always been crucial at the place of work — workers too have duties and responsibilities to look after their own safety and that of their colleagues. Safety consultation, including safety committee meetings and tool box talks, will be encouraged among construction workers.

The authority has set up a construction inspection team who will cover this sector exclusively, and will do so with vigour and enthusiasm. By making this expertise available to the industry a marked improvement in standards is expected. Contractors with poor safety records will be asked to work with the authority in a structured programme to improve their safety management systems.

In addition, the authority will continue to make every effort to disseminate good quality information on best practice. For example, the authority is currently working with the industry to produce a new code of practice on scaffolding.

The authority's response is a comprehensive one — the authority has never operated in a “stalemate” manner in relation to its obligations, and this construction action programme is another welcome example of its pro-active approach to its statutory functions and obligations.

The programme is, of course, underpinned by the punitive sanctions to which the authority has recourse under health and safety legislation. While the authority has always emphasised the value of working in partnership with industry, and will continue to do so, nonetheless, it will not hesitate to use those sanctions where necessary.

As the Deputy will be aware, I have also recently announced sanction for the recruitment of a further 13 staff to the Health and Safety Authority. This is in addition to the seven posts which were authorised from the start of this year as an immediate measure to relieve the pressure under which the authority was then operating. This most recent sanction will bring the total staff complement in the authority to 132 and will put it in a better position to meet the ever increasing demands being placed upon it from all sectors of employment, including the construction sector. I would like to emphasise that this particular package represents part of an ongoing process designed to take account of the development needs of the authority over the next two to three years as it consolidates its present role and takes on new responsibilities.

However, what needs to be fully acknowledged is that while additional resources are essential to the authority, no amount of health and safety inspectors by themselves will eliminate workplace accidents if employers and workers alike do not take more responsibility for their own safety. To this end, I have had a number of meetings with both SIPTU and CIF to discuss the main issues of common concern within the construction sector and with a view to facilitating and strengthening the essential partnership approach to tackling these issues. A spirit of true partnership, to match the Government's commitment of increased resources, can bring about very real and substantial change.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Telecommunications Regulations.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: her assessment of the viability of the video rental business in the light of the telecommunications joint initiative involving the British BT company and the ESB which will allow movies to be downloaded via the Internet rather than rented on cassette tape; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The telecommunications sector worldwide is undergoing a process of reform driven on the one hand by rapid technological developments and on the other by the implementation of liberalisation of telecommunications markets which were traditionally characterised by monopoly supply. In response to these developments there has been a huge increase in merger, alliance and take-over activity as market players seek to exploit new opportunities both in newly opened markets and in the provision of new advanced services and to defend market positions against new and emerging challenges. The Irish market has been no exception and the joint initiative by the ESB and British Telecom is a further example of this.

MainHeading.P: The rapid advances in technology and in particular the advent of the Internet pave the way for the introduction of a whole new range of services including the potential delivery of movies to the home on-line. In practice, existing telecommunications infrastructures will have to be upgraded substantially before laboratory proven capabilities of this kind can be deployed on a mass market basis. The question of the timing and extent of such deployment are uncertain variables at this point in time. The prospective challenge to the viability of the traditional role of the video rental business is therefore equally uncertain.

It is however important to point out that the technological changes which are driving convergence between the traditionally separate telecommunications, broadcasting, information technology, publishing and entertainment sectors bring not only risks but also opportunities. For example, many operators in the video rental sector have already diversified into areas such as rental of computer games and provision of mobile telephony equipment.

In the final analysis, it is a matter for individual enterprises to respond to technological developments and resultant competitive challenges and to exploit any opportunities which emerge in their marketplace.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: her view on the way in which to provide for open competition in the market for the delivery of telephony, e-mail and Internet access services; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: Open competition in Ireland in the markets referred to may be ensured by compliance with the principles enshrined in the Competition Acts, 1991 and 1996, which are enforced by the independent Competition Authority. Where there exists a complaint or suspicion that a contravention of these principles has or may occur the Director of Competition Enforcement is empowered to investigate the matter and to make recommendations and give advice to the Competition Authority in this regard.

The 1991 Act set out the rules of competition and section 4 of that Act prohibits and makes void all agreements between undertakings, decisions by associations of undertakings and concerted practices which have as their object or effect the prevention, restriction or distortion of competition in any goods or services in the State or in any part of the State. Section 5 prohibits any abuse of a dominant position. Section 6 of the 1991 Act provides for right of action for firms or individuals in the courts by way of injunction, declaration, or damages including exemplary damages in certain cases.

MainHeading.P: The 1996 Amendment Act specifies offences and penalties for breaches of the rules of competition. In addition it provides for the public enforcement of the rules of competition. A Director of Competition Enforcement and his staff have been appointed to give effect to the public enforcement provisions of the 1996 Act. Competition rules in the European Economic Area and more particularly in the EU are a matter for decision and enforcement by the EU Commission.

In so far as the method by which open competition comes onto the market for the delivery of telephony, e-mail and Internet access services this is a matter for my colleague the Minister for Public Enterprise. A key element in the transition from a monopoly to a fully competitive market is the establishment, in the interim, of sector specific regulation. The Minister for Public Enterprise promulgated the Telecommunications (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1996, which provided for the setting up of the office of the Director of Telecommunications Regulation and it is the director who decides who the players are in the market referred to by the Deputy.

Among the functions of the director are: the licensing of telecommunications operators and telecommunication service providers, regulation of access agreements including arbitration where necessary, the managing and licensing of the radio frequency spectrum and the television retransmission sector, the regulation of Telecom Éireann charges for services which are not subject to full competition. In addition to compliance with the terms of licences issued by the regulator, compliance with the Competition Acts is also necessary in offering services in the marketplace. We are already seeing the benefits of increasing competition in the telecommunications market. All areas of telecommunications have now been liberalised with the exception of Telecom Éireann's monoply on voice telephony.

Earlier this year the Government decided to end Telecom's derogation on voice telephony on 1 December — 13 months ahead of schedule. Telecom Éireann has recently announced the latest in a series of price cuts in the run up to the opening up of the market. Further benefits to the consumer will follow. The Government has decided to sell Cablelink, which is currently owned by Telecom Éireann — 75 per cent and RTE — 25 per cent. Cablelink has the potential to become a strong competitor in the developing Irish communications market, in time offering services such as voice telephony, high speed Internet access, home shopping, tele-banking and video conferencing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - National Irish Bank.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: whether she has satisfied herself that staff at National Irish Bank, who may have behaved illegally in the matter of overcharging customers, will be identified and brought to justice as a result of ongoing investigations; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: whether she has satisfied herself with the outcome of the review of National Irish Bank charges and the reimbursements made to customers in view of the fact that the investigation did not include formal interviews with the appropriate staff; her views on whether a further investigation is required in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 157 and 158 together.

At my request, the High Court ordered on 30 March 1998 under section 8 of the Companies Act, 1990, that Mr. Tom Grace, FCA, and the retired Supreme court judge, Mr. John Blayney, SC, be appointed as inspectors to investigate and report on the affairs of National Irish Bank Ltd. relating inter alia to the improper charging of interest and the improper charging of fees to customer accounts. The inspectors' remit includes the identification of the person or persons responsible for or aware of these alleged practices.

MainHeading.P: On 10 June last, the inspectors to National Irish Bank presented an interim report to the High Court at a sitting held in camera. On the following day, the High Court decided that a trial should take place of a number of issues on which the inspectors had sought directions from the court. Following the required hearings, the High Court on 13 July determined inter alia that the procedures proposed to be employed by the inspectors were consistent with the requirements of natural and constitutional justice and that persons were not entitled to refuse to answer the inspectors' questions on the grounds of possible self-incrimination. An appeal of this decision is currently being made to the Supreme Court by certain National Irish Bank employees.

Separately last March, my colleague, the Minister for Labour, Trade and Consumer Affairs, exercised certain of his powers under the Consumer Credit Act, 1995, and requested the Director of Consumer Affairs to carry out an investigation into the practices and procedures employed by credit institutions in regard to the imposition of charges, in order to ensure that the interests of consumers were adequately protected.

The director wrote to all credit institutions, including National Irish Bank, seeking a written assurance that the institutions impose only those charges which had been notified to him under section 149 of the Act. The director received a written assurance to that effect from National Irish Bank. The director also issued a statement on 27 March 1998 requesting inter alia that the full current value be restored to any of the bank's customers who were found to have been the subject of improper charging.

It is understood that the bank has since reimbursed certain of its customers as a result of its own internal investigations. As the remit of the inspectors is a general one into the bank's affairs, I expect that it will be clear from their findings the extent to which these reimbursements represent full value for the losses of customers. I will be seeking legal advice on what appropriate action should be taken on completion of the inspectors' report in due course.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Community Employment Schemes.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to change the age limitations for eligibility to work on a FÁS community employment scheme in view of the fact that the rulings currently discriminate against settled people and favour members of the travelling community for the age group from 18 to 21.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if she will include persons in receipt of deserted wives benefit on the eligibility category for community employment schemes as administered by FÁS; and her views on whether refusing applications from these persons is discriminatory.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: I propose to take written Questions Nos. 160 and 164 together.

The objective of community employment — CE — is to provide temporary opportunities for those who are having difficulty in obtaining employment so that they can develop skills and obtain part-time work experience which will enhance their prospects of obtaining a job in the open labour market.

MainHeading.P: The programme is part financed from savings in social welfare payments in order to maximise the availability of places. Its eligibility criteria are designed specifically to discriminate positively in favour of those who experience greatest difficulty in obtaining employment in order to prevent them from becoming marginalised.

CE is primarily targeted at those over 21 years and whose principal or only source of income is an unemployment compensation payment or one parent family payment — OPFP — for at least 12 months. However, other disadvantaged categories such as travellers, those referred by the NRB and programme refugees, who have difficulty in entering the labour market regardless of age, can also participate. In addition married persons can swap their social welfare entitlement with a spouse in order for that person to qualify for CE. Those in receipt of deserted wife's benefit and who have children can apply to revert to one parent family payment and, if awarded this, qualify to participate in CE. Women on deserted wife's benefit who wish to re-enter the labour market can, of course, access a wide array of FÁS training courses and return to work courses.

Settled persons between 18 and 21 years are not an eligible category for CE as it is easier for this group than their traveller peers to obtain employment. Where settled young persons need support to progress to job readiness a placement in training, education or in a jobsclub is much more appropriate than community employment. As a group travellers are particularly marginalised in terms of access to the jobs market and this is recognised in the eligibility criteria for community employment.

Any change to the CE eligibility criteria will be examined in the context of considering the recommendations made by the consultants who have undertaken a comprehensive review of the programme on behalf of the Government. This review is being published to facilitate the maximum consultation with the various stakeholders involved.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if she will accept the decision of the Competition Authority which was authorised under section 11 of the Competition Act, 1991, to undertake a study and analysis into a proposal submitted by Eircell to locate mobile phone antennae at 260 Garda sites and masts for a period of 15 years in view of the fact that 223 of these are included in the agreement reached with ESAT Digifone allowing it access to 418 Garda station sites; her views on whether, due to the huge unrest and all the antimasts campaigns, the decision on COAL locations is a greater issue than competition; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: Following initial consideration by the Government of an Eircell proposal to use Garda masts for mobile telephone services I requested the Competition Authority in July 1998 pursuant to section 11 of the Competition Acts, 1991 and 1996, to carry out a study and an analysis of the competition aspects of the matter and to report to me. I have now received that report from the Competition Authority and it has been considered by the Government and will be published shortly.

While the views set out in the report on the practice and method of competition involved represent those of the independent Competition Authority, I broadly share those views on competition. I intend to place copies of the report in the Library of the House and to publish it as soon as the Government has concluded its consideration of the matter.

As regards the second part of the question, the matters raised there relate to planning, regulatory and environmental issues which are the responsibility of other Ministers and the Deputy may wish to raise those individual matters with appropriate Ministers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Health and Safety Regulations.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to the fact that all 3-pin plugs must have the Irish safety standard approval; if her attention has further been drawn to the fact that any United Kingdom appliances that have the plugs fitted do not require this approval; the plans, if any, she has to deal with this issue; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.P: Statutory instruments S.I. 525 of 1997 and S.I. 526 of 1997 require that electrical appliances, supplied or offered for supply, in the State: (a) shall have a 13 amp plug attached; (b) that such plug shall comply with the requirements of Irish Standard IS 401: 1977 Specification for 13A rewirable and non-rewireable plugs, or equivalent standard; and (c) that compliance shall be approved by a designated body, notified under Article 11 of the Low Voltage Directive (73/23/EEC).
The British standard BS 1363 is an equivalent standard to IS 401 and, therefore, if a plug fitted to a UK appliance is approved by a designated body, to BS 1363, it complies with IS 401.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to give increased powers to the Irish Insurance Compliance Bureau in view of the serious shortcoming in the regulation regime for insurance brokers; her views on whether there is a serious risk to the customer arising from the current legal responsibility of brokers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. Treacy)
Speaker.P: Under the Insurance Act, 1989, certain responsibilities are imposed upon insurance companies in respect of their dealings with insurance intermediaries. As previously announced the Government is currently drafting legislation which will transfer regulatory responsibility for insurance intermediaries to the Central Bank. In drafting this legislation, it is not our intention to change in any material way the responsibilities imposed upon insurance companies in respect of insurance intermediaries.

Insurance companies, through their umbrella organisation, the Irish Insurance Federation, have established the Insurance Intermediary Compliance Bureau IICB to carry out certain checks to meet, in part, the insurers' responsibilities under the Insurance Act, 1989. The role and functions of the IICB are entirely a matter for the insurance companies which appointed the body.
We are completely satisfied, that any shortcomings that may exist in the regulatory regime for insurance intermediaries will be eliminated, once responsibility has transferred to the Central Bank.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: if she has any proposals, at national level or in conjunction with her EU colleagues, to put in place effective European wide consumer protection in relation to the sales techniques applied to holidaymakers when abroad for timeshare and other holiday plan sales; if, in particular, she will pursue, at a bilateral level, the non-adherence of the existing regulations by the Spanish authorities in view of the number of Irish people who have lodged complaints about sharp practices engaged in by such sales personnel; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: The European Communities (Contracts for Time Sharing of Immovable Property — Protection of Purchasers) Regulations, 1997 (S. I. No. 204 of 1997) came into operation in Ireland on 19 May 1997. These regulations gave effect to European Parliament and Council Directive 94/47/EC on the protection of purchasers in respect of certain aspects of contracts relating to the purchase of the right to use immovable properties on a timeshare basis. The protections include a requirement to supply those seeking information on timeshare properties with a brochure giving specific details of the property, including location, current status, associated services and facilities, details on the vendor, the price and the right to cancellation. There is also provision for a cooling-off period and a prohibition on vendors seeking deposits. The regulations are enforced by the Director of Consumer Affairs, who has wide-ranging powers to regulate timeshare-selling activities. In addition, Directive 98/27/EC on Injunctions for the Protection of Consumers' Interests allowing recognised consumer organisations in one member state to take action in the courts of another member state in order to protect the collective interest of consumers where practices contrary to certain directives, including the timeshare directive, listed in the annex to Directive 98/27/EC occur, is due for implementation by end December 2000.

I would urge Irish consumers to exercise caution before entering into any timeshare contract. In particular, consumers should satisfy themselves that the contract would fall within the protections of the Irish regulations. I understand that the Director of Consumer Affairs and the European Consumer Information Centre, ECIC, in Dublin have received complaints about timeshare contracts but these do not appear to fit the type of concerns to which the Deputy adverts. I would invite the Deputy to provide whatever information he has to the office of the director for investigation as appropriate.
Apropos the references to another member state, the Deputy will be aware that responsibility for ensuring that EU legislation is properly implemented throughout the EU is a matter for the Commission.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The Restrictive Practices (Groceries) Order, 1987, made as a consequence of a report by the former Restrictive Practices Commission, covers all grocery goods, with the exception of fresh fruit, fresh vegetables, fresh and frozen meat and fish, as well as intoxicating liquor and other household goods sold in grocery shops. It also prohibits practices such as below cost selling, boycotting, hello money, and provides for control of terms and conditions of supply. The order is enforced by the Director of Consumer Affairs.

The Groceries Order, among other matters, is currently being reviewed by the competition and mergers review group which was set up after the passing of the Competition (Amendment) Act, 1996. I understand that the review group has received submissions from a number of interests in regard to the Groceries Order. I will make a decision in regard to the future of the order when I have received and considered the full report and recommendations of the review group. I have brought the contents of the Deputy's question to the attention of the group.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to direct or encourage Enterprise Ireland to issue a customers charter for the many companies which avail of the agency's service.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: In the context of the Strategic Management Initiative, the practice of publishing a customers' charter has been the policy of both my Department and the bodies under its aegis for a number of years. Addressing and satisfying client needs in a streamlined and effective fashion are cornerstones of the mandate given to Enterprise Ireland when it was established in July of this year.

Enterprise Ireland is currently engaged in preparing a charter for publication. To that end, it has completed a series of independently administered focus groups to obtain client feedback and is now putting in place a major programme of client engagement during which senior managers from across the organisation will meet with over 300 client companies between now and the end of October. On completion of this process, the results of these meetings will be used to finalise a customer charter which will transparently set out how Enterprise Ireland will work in partnership with its clients and what its clients may expect from the agency.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to legislate for a code of good conduct for Irish and transnational companies importing clothing and other goods into Ireland from countries where unacceptable work conditions and child or forced labour are common.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt) Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Mr. T. Kitt)
Speaker.P: Ireland fully supports international efforts, especially through the International Labour Organisation — ILO — to eliminate forced and child labour practices and to encourage compliance with these and other core labour standards. At this year's ILO annual conference a declaration on core labour standards was adopted which specifically targets the elimination of all forms of forced or compulsory labour and the effective abolition of child labour.

At the conference, the ILO also initiated discussions on a draft convention and draft recommendation focusing on the most intolerable forms of child labour. This convention and draft recommendation will come up for final dicussion at the annual conference next year. Ireland will be represented at this conference by a tripartite delegation comprised of Government, employer and trade union delegates.

Ireland also fully supports efforts at EU level to ensure compliance with core labour standards through the European Union's generalised system of preferences scheme which provides preferential access to Community markets for developing countries. Special incentive arrangements have been put in place to encourage beneficiary countries to comply with the ILO standards. In the discussions which will commence shortly on a revised GSP scheme we will look favourably on any proposal from the Commission which strengthens the impact of these incentives or increases them.

At present there is no EU legislation in force requiring codes of good conduct nor is it expected that any proposal will be made to introduce such a requirement in the future. I believe that the way forward towards stamping out forced and child labour practices is through multilateral action rather than through imposing regulatory burdens in relation to imports from outside the EU and we will continue to pursue such an approval at international level, in particular through the ILO.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Commission on the Family.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the recommendations of the Commission on the Family relevant to her Department; the action, if any, she has taken to date to implement them; and the proposed timetable for full implementation of the recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The Deparment of Enterprise, Trade and Employment does not have primary responsibililty for any of the recommendations in the report of the Commission on the Family. That being said, my Department will be happy to play its part to assist in developing coherent, progressive and effective policies for families on foot of any initiatives undertaken by the family affairs unit of the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs or by another lead Department to give effect to recommendations in the report.

Qst.hpid: Mr. C. Lenihan Mr. C. Lenihan
Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the Irish Exporters Association's views on the need for the 24 hour operation of Dublin port.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The management and operation of Dublin Port is a matter for Dublin Port Company. The company, which was established as a commercial State body in March 1997 under the Harbours Act, 1996, is charged with a statutory mandate to regulate operations within its harbour and to control its business at all times in a cost effective and efficient manner.

I am advised by Dublin Port Company that the port is open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year and will facilitate the arrival-departure of vessels at all times. The privately operated terminals within the port open to suit the arrival of their vessels and the needs of their customers and their opening hours vary from terminal to terminal but will accommodate customers outside these hours when required. The port company has no doubt that if the demand exists the terminals would extend their hours.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Sea Trout Stocks.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the action, if any, his Department is taking regarding the collapse of seatrout stock along the western seaboard; and if he will provide statistics of the stock levels for the past five years.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the state of seatrout stocks and the anxieties that have been expressed concerning the sealice problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 173 and 189 together.

I am providing to the Deputy a table of reported rod catches for the period 1985-97 for the main seatrout fisheries. While statistics for 1998 are not fully collated, preliminary indications are that the overall figures will be up on 1997.

MainHeading.P: National seatrout conservation, management and research programmes since 1991 have been directed towards stock assessment, rehabilitation and conservation measures as well as work to address the various adverse factors affecting seatrout stocks and habitats, including drainage, pollution, predation, erosion and acidification. The measures include intensive sealice management strategies on marine salmon farms. Further enhancement of these multiple strategies, including sealice management, was put in place following the Whitaker task force report of 1994 which has been the agreed blueprint for seatrout programmes since that time. There is evidence that the strategies are paying dividends with improvements in a number of stocks. The reliability of rod catch statistics and stock assessment is being improved in order to better quantify the impact of conservation, management and rehabilitation strategies. Funding has been provided under the tourism angling measure for the Marine Institute's fish counter programme and for seatrout enhancement work by the Salmon Research Agency. Sealice management and monitoring programmes are rigorously overseen and are the most comprehensive and intensive such programmes in Europe.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Finfish Farms.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to introduce a regular reporting system on lice counts from finfish farms and regular reports of the control of finfish farms, in particular of lice control.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to implement strategies to control lice and other problems associated with finfish farms.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 174 and 175 together.

Sealice management and monitoring strategies on marine salmon farms have been in place since 1991 and were comprehensively enhanced in 1994 in line with the recommenadations of the Whitaker Sea Trout Force Report which is the agreed blueprint for seatrout programmes. All marine finfish farms operate lice management regimes which are monitored on a monthly basis. Farms are monitored twice per month during the critical period for the wild seatrout smolt run i.e. March to May. The monthly reports of lice levels on farms are circulated at the end of each monthly sampling period to the Central Fisheries Board, the regional fisheries boards, private fishery owners (on request) and other interested parties. On any occasion where elevated lice levels are recorded or where the potential for development of elevated levels is detected, fish farmers are obliged to take all necessary remedial action.

Comprehensive fishhusbandry and fishhealth strategies including fallowing of production sites, separation of year classes and production techniques are also recognised as contributing significantly to sealice control. All finfish farms must be licensed under the Fisheries and Foreshore Acts. An extensive consultation and assessment process takes place before a licence is granted. Where licences are granted they are subject to compliance with strict conditions in relation to fishhusbandry, production parameters and fishhealth.

MainHeading.P: The Irish salmon farming industry is one of the most highly regulated aquaculture industries by international standards. The enhanced regulatory framework for the acquaculture industry introduced in the Fisheries Amendment Act, 1997, underlines the sustainable development imperative which will underpin contnued growth and jobs in the sector.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will intervene with the Central Fisheries Board and impose an immediate ban on the boxes and traps set in the River Moy.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if his Department has received reports in relation to fish stocks in the River Moy, County Mayo; and if he will make a statement on the matter, in particular outlining the action, if any, which will be taken on foot of these reports.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 176 and 179 together.

A report from the North-Western Regional Fisheries Board on the salmon run to the River Moy this year indicates that in common with a number of other rivers, the run of spring salmon was disappointing and there was a significant reduction in rod catches of spring salmon.

Rod catches in June were relatively poor due to the grilse run being one month later than usual. Catches in the main grilse run up to end July were good. The total recorded rod catch for the river for the season is about 6,000 fish, which is a decrease of 20 per cent on the annual catch over the past five years. Persistent high water levels during the summer months will have contributed to the reduced rod catch.

The installation of a fish counter on the Moy, funded under the tourism angling measure, will provide enhanced information on stocks and will facilitate improved monitoring and management of salmon/grilse stocks in the river. The operation of the traps on the Moy Fishery by the Central Fisheries Board is kept under regular review by the Board in light of ongoing stock assessment scientific advice and all other relevant factors. The CFB has already reduced the length of season and number of days per week for operation of the traps. Utilisation was postponed until June this year. I have asked the Central Fisheries Board to review with the North West Regional Fisheries Board future operational strategies for the Moy Fishery including the operation of the traps in the context of progressing the overall arrangements for transfer of the management of the fishery to the North West Regional Board.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will impose a moratorium on netting at sea and in estuaries to preserve salmon stocks; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to introduce a tagging system and bag limits for all anglers to preserve salmon stocks.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 177 and 178 together.

I have no plans to impose a moratorium on netting for salmon at sea and in estuaries. My immediate policy priority is to continue to progress my conservation and management strategies for the salmon resource on a consensus basis and which requires recognition of the need to give and take on the part of anglers and commercial netsmen alike.

The impact of the conservation measures which I renewed for 1998 has been to effectively reduce the commercial salmon season to the months of June and July. I will be assessing the conservation measures needed for 1999 in light of trends this year, with particular reference to concerns about the state of spring salmon stocks. The evidence available indicates clearly the continued need for reduced exploitation on the part of all involved in spring salmon fishing.

I have already announced the steps I am taking to move towards the introduction of a tagging and quota scheme in order to achieve realtime management of salmon stocks on a shared resource basis. The practical work of translating this concept into reality is under way, led by the regional fisheries boards. I have announced the establishment of a National Salmon Management Commission which will have a key role in delivering the new regime and all the related decisions underpinning that approach.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Lobster Fishing.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the compensation, if any, available for a person (details supplied) in County Mayo who has lost a total of 102 lobster pots due to damage by trawlers entering Porturlin Bay.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if officials from his Department have investigated the damage being incurred by small fisherman in Porturlin Bay when trawlers enter the bay; if a report has been complied on the number of incidents; and the steps, if any, he will take to help these fishermen and prevent further damage to equipment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 180 and 181 together.

MainHeading.P: Problems arising from the use of different types of fishing gear on fishing grounds are best resolved at local level, through co-operation between fishermen. The code of practice drawn up some years ago for inshore fishermen and trawlermen, was designed to minimise the risk to local fishing gear from trawling activities. The code of practice has facilitated a degree of co-operation between fishermen and has contributed to a reduction in the level of lost or damaged gear. My Department, in association with Bord Iascaigh Mhara, is setting up meetings of inshore fishing and trawling groups to review recent incidents and the operation and effectiveness of the code of practice.

A compensation procedure of an informal nature has operated within the framework of the code of practice in cases of verifiable gear loss or damage. While the person referred to by the Deputy made a claim for compensation in respect of lobster pots, it has not been possible, in the absence of any verifiable identification of the vessels involved, to resolve the claim to date. The compensation system will be on the agenda at the forthcoming meetings with all relevant interests.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if there is a quota system on mackerel fishing for allocation to small fishermen, similar to the quota systems in other European countries; and, if not, the plans, if any, he has to introduce this system.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: Ireland's mackerel fishery is exploited by large refrigerated sea water — RSW — vessels and smaller dry hold vessels. Under the present quota management regime for the fishery catch limits are imposed on the RSW vessels targeting the stock. These limits specify the maximum quantity which may be landed by individual RSW vessels in the fishery. Individual catch limits have not been imposed on the dry hold vessels in the mackerel fishery. It is not proposed to introduce any such limits for these vessels in the autumn fishery.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: whether it is the policy of his Department to seek to promote sustainability accreditation, as defined at the 1992 Rio Earth Summit, for all forestry operations here; if so, the resources being applied to this objective; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I support fully the principle of sustainable forestry development as defined at the 1992 Rio Summit. Accreditation/certification is primarily a marketing issue to prove to interested consumers that specific timber is from a sustainable managed source. It is a voluntary agreement between producers and users. The Government's role is to create a framework which will encourage best management practices. The forest service of my Department is actively pursuing such a framework.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: whether forestry policy here is unique in the EU in that we are the only country to have been cited by the European Commission for pursuing a forestry policy that is actually environmentally damaging; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The European Commission has not cited Ireland in relation to its forestry policy. The Commission, however, initiated proceedings in the European Court of Justice on 5 December 1996 for alleged failure to adequately transpose the EU Directive on Environmental Impact Assessment (85/337/EEC). This action primarily relates to one aspect of Ireland's transposition of the directive, i.e. the levels at which EIA should be required for certain classes of projects, one of which is afforestation. Full effect has been given to the directive in Ireland since the introduction of the European Communities (Environmental Impact Assessment) Regulations, 1989, and other relevant regulations. Ireland has lodged a full defence and a public hearing of the case took place in Luxembourg recently. The advocate general of the court is expected to deliver an opinion on the case on 2 December 1998. The judgment will be given some time therafter. My Department has no information on other similar actions being taken by the European Commission.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Prospecting Licences.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the intended outcome of the exploration at Slieve Foyle in County Louth which is being undertaken by a company (details supplied) under licence from his Department; the time period these exploration works are likely to continue; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: In December 1995 four prospecting licences were granted to BHP Minerals International Exploration Inc., under the Minerals Development Acts, 1940 to 1995, to undertake a programme of mineral exploration in the Carlingford peninsula in County Louth. The licences are valid for a period of six years. The purpose of the company's exploration programme is to ascertain the character, extent or value of minerals which may be lying on or under the land in the licence areas. The licences were granted in respect of the following minerals: base metals; silver; gold; vanadium; chromium; cobalt; nickel; ruthenium; rhodium; palladium; osmium; iridium; platinum.

MainHeading.P: I must stress that what have been granted to BHP are prospecting licences. No permission has been granted for mining. All aspects of prospecting are subject to safeguards and controls to protect the State's rights, landowners' rights and licence holders' rights, while having regard to protection of the environment. The most conspicuous part of prospecting involves drilling which is no more harmful to the environment than sinking a well. I insist that drillholes are sealed, where appropriate, when drilling is completed to ensure that no easy route is made for pollutants to subsequently percolate down through the ground and that animals will not injure themselves.
By its very nature most prospecting comes to nought. If an economic prospect is found, however, before mining would be considered a company would have to:
(a) apply for planning permission from the local authority;
(b) apply for an integrated pollution control licence from the Environmental Protection Agency;
(c) apply to me for a State Mining Facility (SMF).

All three processes require the preparation and publishing for public examination and comment of an environmental impact statement. All three applications would also be subject to public advertisement which allows objections to be made and taken into account. In no circumstances will I award an SMF unless both planning permission and an integrated pollution control licence are in place and where I do grant an SMF it is a strict condition that it is made void by noncompliance with both. This ensures that when I grant an SMF I have been satisfied that the project is environmentally acceptable.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Toxic Waste Monitoring.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to reports that monitoring rag worms can be used as an effective method to measure toxic waste in sea water; his views on whether this technique may have an application in Irish waters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I am aware of a number of reports and studies on the use of ragworms — nareis — as biological indicators for the marine environment. These species are, however, of little use in the testing of toxicity in the water column as they are predominantly sediment dwelling. I understand that their use in marine environment monitoring programmes for testing sediment quality is also limited because of their insensitivity to contaminants and that studies have been shown to give unreliable data.

MainHeading.P: The national marine monitoring programme is carried out in accordance with the Oslo and Paris Commissions' — OSPAR — Joint Assessment and Monitoring Programme — JAMP. This is an agreed programme for the monitoring and assessment of the marine environment of the north-eastern Atlantic and specific guidelines apply so as to ensure the quality and complementary aspect of the data obtained. At present the main emphasis is on chemical monitoring of contaminants in water and sediments, and on biota-using techniques which have been shown to provide results capable of providing a convention-wide assessment e.g. the Quality Status Report 2000 in which Ireland is currently involved.

There is, however, an increasing acceptance that biological effects monitoring should form a substantial part of JAMP and that a co-ordinated chemical and biological effects monitoring programme is essential for identifying areas of concern. I am keeping developments in this area under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Departmental Grants.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: when payment will be made under the afforestation grant scheme to a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny; and if his Department will accept his herd number and the fact that he has received other payments under the scheme as proof that he is farming.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The farmer rate of premium will be paid to the person in question on receipt of documentary evidence, i.e. a tax assessment and farm accounts, that 25 per cent of the applicant's total income was derived from agriculture. This information was requested in a letter to the applicant on 2 June 1996. On receipt of this information the premium application will be considered further. A herd number and the fact he has received other payments under the scheme is not sufficient to qualify an applicant in a case such as this.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if he will intervene in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Leitrim to have his forestry grant payments increased in view of the fact that he has never received an increase; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The person in question planted his lands on 1 April 1992 and he is in receipt of a premium payable under this scheme which has not increased since the scheme began. Under the CAP premium scheme higher premium rates were introduced for applicants who received approval to commence work on or after 1 August 1992. Since the person in question planted prior to this date he is not eligible to be considered for the CAP premium scheme.

MainHeading.P: A number of proposals to improve the situation of farmers paid under the forest premium scheme have to date been turned down by the European Commission. I am in the process of preparing a new case which will be forwarded to the Commission at the earliest possible date.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in issuing an aquaculture licence to a person (details supplied) in County Mayo in view of the fact that the licence was applied for many months ago and the delay is hindering his business.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: It may be of assistance if I set out the position with regard to the licensing procedure. All licensing proposals are assessed by the Department from the relevant technical and scientific perspectives. In addition, a public consultation procedure applies whereby all applications for licensing are advertised in the local press. The licensing process also involves consultation with fisheries interests, together with tourism, environmental and wildlife interests. It is the Department's objective to ensure, as far as possible, that aquaculture and other marine activities/interests are developed together on a planned and well regulared basis.

Mr. Cronin's application was assessed by the Department's licence advisory committee, a multi-disciplinary committee comprised of technical and scientific experts, at a recent meeting which recommended that the application should proceed to the public notice stage. The Department has written to Mr. Cronin requesting that he provide drawings of the structures he intends to employ in his operation. On receipt of same the Department will advise Mr. Cronin to advertise his application.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the reason for the delay in having moneys allocated in May 1998 for a project (details supplied) in County Kilkenny; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The management committee overseeing the operation of the tourism angling measure — TAM — have agreed in principle to allocate funding to the project in question. I am advised by the Central Fisheries Board, which administers the TAM, that a formal letter of offer will be issued as soon as the project promoters definitively confirm to the CFB the proposed startup and completion dates for the project.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: if his Department is in receipt of reports concerning the breakwater in Ballycotton harbour, County Cork, and the need to dredge the harbour; if so, if he will outline the contents of these reports and any recommendations contained therein; if he will state whether or not his Department is in a position to make funding available towards these two projects in the near future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The harbour at Ballycotton is owned by Cork County Council, which is responsible for its repair and maintenance. Accordingly, it is a matter for the local authority, in the first instance, to determine that works may be required at the harbour. I am pleased to inform the Deputy that I announced recently that grant assistance of £64,500 is being made available to the county council towards a silt dredging scheme at Ballycotton. It is a condition of this grant aid that the works be completed before the end of 1998. My Department has not, to date, received any proposals from the county council concerning the breakwater at Ballycotton. While I would, of course, give careful consideration to any such proposals, if submitted, I must point out that they would have to be considered in the context of the overall development requirements and available funding for fishery harbours generally.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Commission on the Family.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the recommendations of the Commission on the Family relevant to his Department; the action, if any, he has taken to date to implement them; and the proposed timetable for full implementation of the recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: The recommendations of the Commission on the Family outlined in the final report, Strengthening Families for Life, are not directly applicable to the day to day activitive of my Department. However, that being said, Part 6 of the Commission's final report does discuss the issues of families living in rural areas and the need to tackle the issues of poverty and social exclusion in rural areas. In this regard, the Department of the Marine and Natural resources is engaged, on an ongoing basis, in a number of activitives to promote the economic development of rural areas through the sustainable exploitation of the indigenous resources' potential. This is aimed at generating the enterprise and employment necessary to maintain viable coastal communities. These actions assist in addressing rural poverty by increasing wealth generation within isolated rural areas through employment creation.

MainHeading.P: The Commission's report also makes recommendations in relation to support for bereaved families. In this regard I have supported the establishment of the group LOST — Loved Ones of Sea Tragedies — which was set up earlier this year to provide support services for families who have been bereaved due to a marine tragedy. While funding for bereavement services is provided by the family affairs unit of the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs, I am pleased to say that I secured funding of £10,000 in June of this year towards the initial establishment and start-up costs of this group.

Qst.Quest: the number of applicants who have applied for a holiday visa to Ireland in 1998 and in each of the three previous years; the number of successful and unsuccessful applicants; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The manner in which visa applications are processed and recorded does not permit the extrapolation of statistics of specific categories of applications such as holiday visas. According to the best estimates of the Department of Foreign Affairs, the numbers of applications from holiday-makers in the years 1995 to 1997 and in 1998 to date were about 2,900, 3,200, 3,700 and 3,200, the numbers approved by the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform were about 2,610, 2,880, 3,330 and 2,880 and the numbers of unsuccessful applicants were about 290, 320, 370 and 320. Most people from abroad who come as tourists to Ireland are not required to have visas.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Overseas Development Aid.

Qst.Quest: the percentage of GNP spent by Ireland in 1997 on overseas development assistance; whether it remains the intention of the Government to reach the UN target of 0.7 per cent by the year 2002; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: In 1997 allocations for Overseas Development Assistance — ODA — amounted to £124.47 million. This amounted to 0.30 per cent of a GNP figure of £41,919 million. In the document An Action Programme for the Millennium, a key priority was stated to be the adoption of an interim overseas development assistance target of at least 0.45 per cent of GNP by 2002 on the way to reaching the UN target of 0.7 per cent.

MainHeading.P: In line with that commitment, £137 million was allocated for ODA in the 1998 budget. In addition this month the Government indicated its intention, subject to Dáil approval, of providing a further sum of £22 million, £14 million in 1998 and the balance in subsequent years, for a debt relief package for developing countries. It is estimated that this will bring official ODA to 0.325 per cent of the provisional 1998 GNP figure which is itself growing at a rate of 7.5 per cent per annum.

The Government's aim is to continue to increase the ODA allocation and to ensure that we have an aid programme which is effective, focused and sustainable and which is targeted at alleviating the poverty of people in some of the least developed countries in the world. It is also our intention to work with the international community to create conditions in the global economy which will allow developing countries to reach their full potential to the benefit of their people. This includes an effort to halt the current downward trend in flows of assistance from the developed world and to achieve agreement among donor countries on the necessity of reaching the UN target of 0.7 per cent of ODA as one of the most important instruments in development.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference.

Qst.hpid: Mr. C. Lenihan Mr. C. Lenihan
Qst.Quest: the changes, if any, he envisages to the standing intergovernmental machinery in order to enhance co-operation between the British and Irish Governments.

Qst.hpid: Mr. C. Lenihan Mr. C. Lenihan
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the way in which relationships between the British and Irish Governments, previously dealt with under the Anglo-Irish conference, will now be dealt with under the British-Irish Agreement.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 196 and 198 together.

The British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference — BIIC — will be established on the entry into force of the British-Irish Agreement early next year. It will replace and subsume both the conference set up under the Anglo-Irish Agreement and the Anglo-Irish Intergovernmental Council set up after the 1980 summit. The BIIC will essentially operate like the present conference, under the co-chairmanship of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, but with a number of key differences. It will cover all Irish-British Governmental matters, not just Northern Ireland. It is recognised, however, that it will deal largely with Northern Ireland and will meet usually in a dedicated Northern Ireland format. The conference will not be involved in matters which have been devolved to the Northern Ireland Assembly. Relevant members of the Northern Ireland Executive will be involved in the meetings of the conference. The BIIC will be supported by a standing joint secretariat of Irish and British officials.

MainHeading.P: A British Irish Council — BIC — will also be established under the British-Irish Agreement to promote the harmonious and mutually beneficial development of the totality of relationships among the peoples of these islands. It will comprise representatives of the British and Irish Governments, devolved institutions in Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales, and, if appropriate, any others established in the United Kingdom, together with representatives of the Isle of Man and the Channel Isles. It will meet twice a year at summit level, and in sectoral formats at ministerial level on a regular basis. It will exchange information, discuss, consult and use its best endeavours to reach agreement on co-operation on matters of mutual interest within the competence of the relevant administrations. It will operate by consensus and not all members need be involved in any given area of co-operation. The BIC will have a secretariat provided by the Irish and British Governments in co-ordination with officials of each of the other members. The elected institutions of the members will be encouraged to develop an interparliamentary tier.

Qst.Quest: if Ireland will ratify the UN convention against torture; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: Human rights are a key priority for this Government and inform all aspects of Irish foreign policy. This priority is reflected, inter alia, in our commitment to ratify key international human rights instruments to which Ireland is not yet a party.
