As Minister for Foreign Affairs, it is a matter of deep concern to me that Ireland is not yet in a position to ratify the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

In order to give domestic effect to the convention, it is necessary to introduce legislation regarding the offence of mental torture. My Department has been in contact with the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform with a view to expediting this process. I have been advised that work is well advanced and it is hoped that the necessary Bill will be published in the forthcoming session. Once this legislation has been passed, I will seek Dáil approval for ratification of this important convention.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Kosovan Conflict.

Qst.Quest: whether Ireland has been approached to give recognition to an independent state of Kosovo; his views on recent developments in this troubled region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The situation in Kosovo is a cause for grave concern. I believe we are witnessing there the prospect of a humanitarian catastrophe which could replicate the horrors of Bosnia. The latest UN estimates of refugees and displaced persons now total more than 291,000 and appproximately 50,000 of these are without shelter and other basic needs as the harsh Balkan winter rapidly approaches. In my address to the General Assembly of the United Nations in New York last week, I indicated my concern on this issue and I called on the international community to take urgent and effective action, within the framework of the United Nations, to ensure that our worst fears are not realised.

If the international community is to address this question successfully it is imperative that it do so in the most coherent and cohesive way possible. In this regard I welcome in particular Resolution 1199 of the UN Security Council, adopted on 23 Sepember. The resoluton provides a good basis for reaching a solution, setting out in detail the steps to be taken to bring this conflict to an end and to provide relief for the suffering civilian population. It is important that all parties to the conflict adhere to its demand that hostilities cease immediately so that a meaningful dialogue can start without delay and the risks of a humanitarian catastrophe can be reduced.

Intensive efforts are now being made by the international community to ensure the start of the dialogue between the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia and the Kosovo Albanian leadership. Austria, as EU Presidency, is co-ordinating the efforts of EU partners. I am maintaining close contact with the Presidency in order to provide whatever advice and assistance I can. Resolution 1199 further calls on the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia to enable effective and continuous international monitoring in Kosovo by, inter alia, the European Community Monitoring Mission — ECMM — to which Ireland contributes.

While the early start of dialogue is essential, the provision of humanitarian aid and the implementation of measures to allow the safe return of refugees and displaced persons are equally pressing priorities. Resolution 1199 spells out clearly to the Yugoslav authorities what they are now required to do so that these objectives can be achieved.

The Government has already provided £50,000 to the International Federation of the Red Cross for Kosovan refugees in Albania and is actively considering additional assistance. The European Community Humanitarian Office — ECHO — has announced an aid package amounting to ECU 8.55 million in response to the crisis.

MainHeading.P: The wide-scale abuse of human rights in Kosovo, including reports of summary executions, kidnappings and mistreatment of civilians, is also cause for serious concern. Resolution 1199 addresses this aspect comprehensively, and prescribes what has to be done by the International Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, whose work has to be facilitated by the Yugoslav authorities, as well as the latter assuming their responsibilities to bring to justice their agents guilty of such crimes.

The solution to the conflict in Kosovo has to be brought about by negotiation and political means. No approaches have been made to the Government regarding recognition of an independent state of Kosovo. While the international community has not indicated any support for the independence of Kosovo, there is widespread support not only for the restoration of Kosovo's autonomous status, but also for the enhancement of this status. This is the view of the Government, and it is a view shared by our partners in the European Union.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Human Rights Abuses.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the military occupation in Chiapas, Mexico, since the massacre at Acteal, has led to widespread human rights abuses; the representations, if any, the Irish Government has made to the Mexican Government on these matters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if his attention has been drawn to the fact that on 7 June 1998, Samuel Ruiz, Bishop of San Cristobal de la Casas tendered his resignation as head of the CONAI, National Mediation Commission and Chief Mediator between the Government and the EZLN, and in his resignation statement accused President Zedillo of sponsoring a constant and growing governmental aggression against himself and the mediation process; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 200 and 201 together.

Both before and since the massacre at Acteal, I have followed with concern the situation in Chiapas, Mexico, particularly the reports of the serious violations of the human rights of the indigenous people. The tragic situation in Chiapas is characterised by grave ethnic, religious and political conflicts, sharp disparities of income and disputes between large landowners and indigenous communities. The Mexican Government is attempting to bring to an end a four year old rebellion by the Zapatista Liberation Front and other indigenous groups. Tensions have been exacerbated by the scale of the presence of federal forces which the Government regard as necessary to maintain the peace. Others, including representatives of the indigenous people and a number of NGOs, have said that these forces are responsible for abuses and have been involved in arming and training paramilitary groups.

MainHeading.P: The federal Government's response to the crisis included the establishment of a mediation commission — CONAI — to facilitate negotiations with the rebels who refuse to engage in direct talks. However, Bishop Samuel Ruiz's resignation earlier this year as President of CONAI and his criticisms of the Mexican Government clearly reflect the difficulties encountered in the mediation process.

The Mexican authorities have been made aware of Ireland's close interest in this issue. With our EU partners, we have been active in encouraging the Mexican Government to ensure the safety of the civilian population in Chiapas. Following the Acteal massacre, the European Union condemned the killings and called on the Mexican Government to make a full investigation. The EU has made known its expectation that the Mexican Government will protect the civilian population and undertake action to end impunity before the law of perpetrators of serious human rights violations. The new EU-Mexico Global Agreement will be conditional on respect for human rights. Both the EU and Mexico are committed to this conditionality.

The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mrs. Robinson, has recently expressed concern about reports of the indigenous people of Chiapas being caught between government forces and armed resistance groups. She appealed to the government to look urgently at ways of restoring dialogue. She added that a reduction in the military presence in the region could be an important first step in restoring confidence that a peaceful solution might be found.

Mexico has informed the UN Sub-Commission on Human Rights of Government strategy to resolve the question of Chiapas with the help of dialogue and by tackling the structural causes of marginalisation and extreme poverty connected with the underdevelopment of the region. It is understood that measures are now being taken with a view to the reform of the security forces and to end abuses and impunity for human rights violations. In his State of the Union address on 1 September, President Zedillo acknowledged “many years of accumulated deficiencies, injustice and neglect” and said that public safety and justice constitute an essential obligation of the State.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the case of persons (details supplied) who were arrested in Buenos Aires on 11 October 1976 and were tortured by the so called Argentine Anti-Communist Alliance; if the Government intends to do everything in its power to bring the perpetrators to justice; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware of the cases of the two people named, one of whom was an Irish citizen. The Irish Embassy in Buenos Aires at the time played a central role in ensuring that the Irish citizen was released, locating the place of his detention, visiting it quickly and maintaining strong pressure on the authorities. Our primary involvement was, of course, with the Irish citizen, but the two cases were closely related. Both were detained during the military dictatorship in Argentina. The Irish citizen had been tortured and we understand that the other individual suffered similar treatment. Both individuals were eventually released and are now living in Argentina.

Very serious atrocities occurred under the Argentine military dictatorship. Under the democratic administrations which replaced the dictatorship, legislation was passed, the effect of which was to grant immunity from punishment to those who were responsible for violations of human rights during the military regime. I understand that there has been ongoing debate in Argentina on the repeal of this legislation. However, it is not certain that any repeal could have retrospective effect. We understand that both persons referred to in the question have received civil compensation from the Argentine authorities for their ordeal.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to introduce an extradition treaty with Mexico during the term of office of this Government; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government have no plans to conclude an extradition treaty with Mexico in the immediate future.
The need for extradition arrangements with other jurisdictions is kept under review by my Department and the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Human Rights Abuses.

Qst.Quest: the action, if any, he has taken to express Ireland's concern about the atrocities which are continuing in Algeria and the plans, if any, he has to co-sponsor a motion on Algeria at the UN General Assembly this year.
the steps, if any, he is taking in relation to an investigation by the United Nations Commission on Human Rights of the ongoing civil war in Algeria.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 204 and 212 together.

MainHeading.P: I have been most concerned with the on-going situation in Algeria, particularly the continuation of appalling massacres involving innocent civilians including children, since I took office. As the House will recall, I visited Algeria last December and met President Zeroual and leading government ministers and political figures in this context. Since then I have met the Algerian Foreign Minister, Mr. Attaf, on two occasions — once at Palermo in June during a meeting of European Union and Mediterranean Foreign Ministers and the second time at the United Nations last week at New York. On all occasions I have discussed the current situation in Algeria, including the massacres, and urged the need to end the tragic situation in that country.

At our meeting last week, Mr. Attaf and I discussed the situation in the light of the decision of Mr. Zeroual to resign as of next February which will necessitate a presidential election. Mr. Attaf told me that there would be a deepening of the reform process leading to further democratisation, greater pluralism and the revitalisation of the economy. He also stated that there had been progress in the fight against terrorism. He spoke of closer ties between the EU and Algeria following the Palermo meeting and said that he would next be discussing the matter with the troika of European Foreign Ministers next month in Vienna. I renewed the invitation to him to visit Ireland for further talks and he agreed to come subject to the other demands on his schedule.

In my address to the United Nations General Assembly last week, I highlighted the problems arising from the abuse of human rights and the need for concerted international action to address them. I will consider further the possibility of co-sponsoring a resolution on Algeria, taking into account, inter alia, the outcome of the session of the Commission on Human Rights last March when it was clear that the international community was not prepared to support such a resolution. The commission has itself not carried out any investigation of the situation there due to the refusal by the Algerian authorities to allow UN investigators to visit that country. This is also a matter for concern.

I would like to take this opportunity again to assure the House that I will continue to pay close attention to the evolution of the situation in Algeria and to raise the plight of the Algerian people both in international fora and in bilateral contacts with the Algerian Government.

Qst.Quest: the action, if any, he has taken to denounce the ruling army council regime in Burma for its continued harassment of Aung San Suu Kyi; and the plans, if any, he has to raise this matter at both EU and UN level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am greatly concerned at the continuing abuse of the human rights of the Burmese people by the military regime currently in power in Rangoon and in particular by the recent incidents involving the freedom of movement of the NLD leader and Nobel laureate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. In my statement to the General Assembly of the United Nations last week, I drew attention to the human rights situation in Burma and urged the need for international action.

The Government's position in relation to Burma is based on the common position adopted by the European Union in October 1996. The common position, which is due for renewal next month, expresses the European Union's alarm at the continuing deterioration of the political situation in Burma, including the restrictions imposed on fundamental rights of freedom such as speech, movement and assembly. It also urges the State Peace and Development Council in Rangoon to restore democracy without delay and respect human rights.

I have indicated to our EU partners our support for increased pressure on the Burmese Government by strengthening and broadening EU sanctions to include aspects of trade, tourism and investment. The EU General Affairs Council will be considering further possible measures.

The Deputy will be aware that Ireland supported the adoption of a resolution on the situation of human rights in Myanmar in April 1998 at the 54th session of the UN Commission on Human Rights in Geneva. This resolution expressed the concern of the international community at the continuing violations of human rights in Myanmar and called upon the Government of Myanmar to guarantee an end to violations of the right to life and the integrity of the human being and to ensure full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I wish to assure the Deputy that the Government will continue to avail of every opportunity to work for an improvement of the human rights situation in Burma and to assist the democratic movement in that country.

Qst.Quest: if he will arrange for the immediate processing of an application for post-nuptial citizenship which was made by a person in South Africa (details supplied) to the Embassy in Pretoria on 19 May 1998, given that this family are very anxious to leave South Africa as soon as possible due to increasing violence there; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: A declaration by this person, accepting Irish citizenship as her post-nuptial citizenship, has been considered by the Department of Foreign Affairs. Two points relating to the documentation accompanying the declaration have recently been raised with the person concerned through the Embassy in Pretoria. Once the Departments of Foreign Affairs and of Justice, Equality and Law Reform are satisfied that this person was legally free to marry her present husband in 1993 and when the required fee is paid her declaration will be accepted and she will become an Irish citizen.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to appoint an Irish consular representative to the Palestinian autonomous area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: There are no plans at present to appoint an Irish consular representative in the Palestinian autonomous area. The normal basis for the appointment of consuls, whether officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs or honorary consuls, is the existence of a sizeable community of Irish citizens resident in or visiting a country and/or the prospect of increased trade, investment or tourism from a country where there is not already an Irish mission.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Third World Debt.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will outline the principles underlying Irish policy towards third world debt; if its aims include debt cancellation and poverty reduction; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The issue of debt represents a serious and growing economic and social problem for many developing countries. It is now clear that a concerted international effort is required to tackle the problem.

In terms of our national policy, the Minister for Finance and I recently announced details of a major new package of assistance to help address the debt problems of developing countries and to assist the process of economic and social reform in the most heavily indebted poor countries in the world. This package will comprise a total of £31.5 million, of which £9.5 million has already been committed to two of Irish Aid's priority countries, Mozambique and Tanzania, in debt relief. A total £15 million will be provided for multilateral debt relief under the joint World Bank/IMF heavily indebted poor country — HIPC — initiative, while the remaining £7 million will be provided to the enhanced structural adjustment facility — ESAF — of the International Monetary Fund.

MainHeading.P: The Government has also agreed that the following principles should underlie Irish policy towards indebtedness in the developing world: debt relief should become an integral part of Ireland's overall overseas development aid strategy, reinforcing the existing emphasis on the fundamental goal of poverty alleviation as well as environmental sustainability and gender equality; Ireland will emphasise the need for definitions of debt sustainability to take human, as well as economic development into account; the Minister for Finance will press for greater transparency in the working of the Bretton Woods Institutions; we will press for increased flexibility in the implementation of the HIPC Initiative in particular with a view to its speedier implementation and its application to as wide a range of the heavily indebted countries as possible; we will continue to encourage the IMF to take full account of the social impact of its policies at the design and implementation phases of its macroeconomic and structural adjustment programmes; we will strongly encourage the international community, including bilateral creditors, to take a generous and flexible approach to the heavily indebted poor countries. Ireland will continue to press for deeper debt relief so as to ease the debt burden that is imposing enormous constraints on many developing countries; the Minister for Finance will continue to advocate a greater degree of consultation and involvement for civil society in the developing countries in the planning design and implementation phases of IMF/World Bank programmes; the Minister for Finance will continue to call on the IMF to maximise the use of its own resources to fund a deeper and wider response to the debt problems of third world countries; and emphasis on the importance of continued consultation with the NGO community on issues of concern in relation to debt and development. These principles, as well as the specific financial contributions involved, will allow Ireland to continue to play a strong and vigorous role in international action to tackle the crisis of developing world indebtedness.

As regards debt cancellation, Ireland is not a bilateral aid creditor country and supports in this context the call of the G8 countries for bilateral aid-related debt forgiveness. In respect of general bilateral and multilateral debt, the position taken to date by developing countries is to generally favour reducing the debt burden of the most heavily indebted poor countries to a sustainable level, which would allow them to foster a process of economic growth and development. Ireland, as stated in the principles announced by the Government, will continue to use every opportunity to press for deeper debt relief so as to ease the debt burden on developing countries.

The goal of poverty reduction, as the primary focus of Ireland's overseas development programme, is central to Ireland's policy on third world debt. Poverty eradication has many interrelated dimensions — national policies to advance sustainable development, fair trade patterns, development of suitable economic and social development programmes involving macroeconomic and fiscal policies, sectoral development, inward investment and debt relief.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Middle East Peace Process.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he has raised the question of Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and southern Lebanon with the Israeli ambassador; and, if not, if he will undertake to do so at an early date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government believes that Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and southern Lebanon should take place in accordance with the relevant Resolutions of the UN Security Council. The Madrid Conference of 1991 inaugurated a series of bilateral negotiations between Israel and its neighbours, including Syria and Lebanon. Substantive talks took place between Israel and Syria over a period of time following the Madrid Conference. However, following the change of Government in Israel in May 1996 these were suspended. Only preliminary talks between Israel and Lebanon took place at the time of the Madrid Conference.

The European Union is seriously concerned at this lack of progress. At Luxembourg last December the European Council reiterated the importance which the EU attached to the relaunching of negotiations on the Syrian and Lebanese tracks. The European Council also indicated that it sought the resolution of a comprehensive process on the basis of “Land for Peace” and demanded the full implementation of the relevant UN Security Council resolutions.

On 1 April the Israeli Government stated that it was accepting UN Security Council Resolution 425 so that its forces could leave Lebanon with appropriate security arrangements and so that the Lebanese Government could restore its effective control over southern Lebanon and ensure that its territory would not be used for terrorist attacks against Israel. This offer was rejected by Lebanon as it was not in conformity with the terms of Resolution 425, which called on Israel immediately to withdraw its forces.

On 15-16 June the European Council meeting at Cardiff again expressed its grave concern at the lack of progress on the Syrian and Lebanese tracks. It repeated its earlier call for a continuing effort to reinvigorate the talks. While the Council welcomed Israeli acceptance of Resolution 425, it called for a full and unconditional withdrawal of Israeli troops from southern Lebanon.

On 26 August the European Union issued a declaration expressing its concern about reports that the Israeli Military Committee had approved a plan to expand settlements on the Golan Heights. The declaration viewed the implementation of such a plan, if it were to take place, as a significant setback to the efforts to resume Israeli-Syrian negotiations and urged the Israeli Government not to proceed with its implementation. The European Union took the opportunity of reiterating its position that settlements in the occupied territories are illegal and in contravention of international law.

The concerns of the Government, both as an EU member state and also as a major contributor to UN peace-keeping activities in the region, have been made clear to the Israeli authorities on a number of occasions. They have also been raised with the Israeli Ambassador in Dublin.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if he will exert maximum pressure on the Israeli authorities, both directly and through the EU, to comply in full with the Oslo accord and, in particular, to end their opposition to the construction of a port and the operation of the airport already built in the Palestinian autonomous area in order that the area can develop a viable commercial structure, halt the development of Israeli settlements in the area and, in particular, in East Jerusalem, to provide a secure corridor between the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, to end the harassment of Palestinians and the division of families by bureaucratic rules, to lift the restrictions on Palestinian workers working in Israel which is having a devastating impact on the incomes of 80,000 workers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: The Government is firmly of the view that the terms of the Declaration of Principles, also known as the Oslo Accord, signed in Washington on 13 September 1993 and all subsequent related agreements should be fully adhered to by all the parties concerned within the timetables envisaged. The Declaration of Principles and the subsequent agreements addressed a wide range of issues. Under their terms continuing negotiations between both the Israeli Government and the Palestinian Authority were envisaged over a period of five years after which a permanent status agreement negotiated during the period was to come into effect. Two of the more sensitive issues covered by the declaration were the gradual redeployment of Israeli troops from the West Bank and Gaza and the definition of the terms of co-operation on a wide range of economic issues of concern to both sides. The latter included co-operation in the field of transport which envisaged the establishment of a harbour and airport in Gaza and communications links between the West Bank and Gaza.

Several working groups addressing economic issues were set up and initially made progress. However negotiations regarding Israeli troop redeployment proved difficult from the outset. Since the partial agreed withdrawal of Israeli troops from Hebron in January 1997, talks on a subsequent redeployment have so far proved impossible to conclude. A key issue is the amount of land which would be the subject of this exercise. For the past number of months the US has attempted to broker an agreement. To date, these attempts have been without success. This failure to reach agreement on redeployment has had an indirect negative impact on the negotiations of agreements on a number of issues in the economic area including the proposed Gaza harbour and airport and the development of an industrial estate. It is not expected that agreement will be concluded on these issues until the redeployment issue has been settled.

MainHeading.P: The Government is most concerned at the lack of progress in this area. Together with our EU partners we have encouraged both sides to reach agreement urgently. We have fully supported calls to this effect made at the Luxembourg European Council in December and at the Cardiff European Council in June. Ireland has also been strongly in favour of the direct involvement by the current EU Presidency in the process. We have also encouraged the efforts of the European Union's special envoy to the region, Ambassador Moratinos, who has special responsibilities in the field of economic co-operation. In our bilateral contacts with the parties we have used every available opportunity to press both sides to reach agreement as soon as possible, and will continue to do so.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the position of eastern-rite Catholics in Romania and the ongoing discrimination to which they are subjected; and if Ireland will raise this issue at international fora.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: I am aware of problems facing the Eastern Rite Catholic Church in Romania also known as the Romanian Uniate Church. Since Ireland does not have resident diplomatic representation in Romania, the Department of Foreign Affairs sought information on this issue from a number of sources including the Holy See, the Commission of the European Union, which has a mission in Bucharest, and the chair of the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe. Although there do not appear to be reports of systematic discrimination against members of the Romanian Uniate Church, there are specific problems such as the issue of the restitution of Church property and places of worship.

The Council of Europe has raised this issue in a number of reports concerning Romania's obligations and commitments. In a report, adopted by the parliamentary assembly last year, on the situation concerning the restitution of Church property and places of worship in Romania, it noted that this issue had been partly resolved, but that it was complex and difficult to settle. There continued to be a financial problem, as the Romanian state struggled to allocate the considerable budgetary resources required for the restitution of property. The report also noted that there seemed to be an apparent willingness on the part of the authorities in Romania to amend the law on the restitution of places of worship. In its official Opinion on Romania in the context of preparations for enlargement, the EU Commission has stated that “negotiations under way with the Orthodox Church should soon permit the Uniate Church to recover its property”. Ireland will continue to keep the matter under review both in our EU and multilateral contacts and directly with the Romanian authorities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Commission on the Family.

Qst.Quest: the recommendations of the Commission on the Family relevant to his Department; the action, if any, he has taken to date to implement them; and the proposed timetable for full implementation of the recommendations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Andrews) David Andrews
Speaker.P: While the recommendations of the Commission on the Family do not apply directly to the Department of Foreign Affairs, it nonetheless respects the spirit of these recommendations in both its personnel and consular policies.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Higgins (Dublin West) Mr. Higgins (Dublin West)
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, she has for the provision of a legislative basis for the mandatory sharing of masts and other telecommunications infrastructure in view of the refusal of the mobile phone licensees to observe the guidelines for telecommunications antennae and support structures; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A Bill which will provide for an up-to-date regulatory regime in relation to the development of telecommunications infrastructure is currently in preparation in my Department. I propose to incorporate in this Bill the provisions of the Interconnection Regulations (S. I. No. 15 of 1998) which deal with the sharing of telecommunications facilities and to extend those provisions to certain other facilities.
The final decision on the contents of the Bill will be made in consultation with my Cabinet colleagues. I hope to be in a position to publish the Bill during the current Dáil session.

With regard to the guidelines referred to by the Deputy, these are the “Telecommunications Antennae and Support Structures” guidelines for planning authorities which were published by the Department of the Environment in July 1996. These guidelines, as with all planning policy matters, are the function of my colleague, the Minister for the Environment and Local Government. The implementation of the guidelines at the local level is the responsibility of the relevant planning authority. I have no function in relation to these matters.

Qst.Quest: her views on news reports that air traffic delays of up to one hour may be encountered by air traffic in the London area in the next few years due to delays in the commissioning of the new air traffic control centre at Swanick; her views on the safety of the many Irish aircraft in this region, which is operating at near full capacity due to the nature of the older equipment at the West Drayton air traffic control centre; if her attention has been drawn to the fact that the number of near miss incidents in the London area has increased in each of the past four years; and if she has discussed or will discuss this situation with her British counterpart and report back to Dáil Éireann.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will appreciate air traffic control arrangements in the UK are a matter for the UK authorities. However, I can assure the Deputy that safety is the paramount consideration in the provision of air traffic control services internationally whether it be in Ireland, the UK or in any other state that is a member of ICAO — the International Civil Aviation Organisation which sets the overall safety standards. I would therefore, wish to allay any concerns the Deputy might have about the safe operation of Irish aircraft. Over the past few years there have been very significant increases in the level of air traffic in Europe and elsewhere and because of such increases, delays are imposed on traffic, when and where necessary, to maintain system safety standards at all times.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Tuskar Rock Air Crash.

Qst.Quest: if she will request from her British counterpart the releasing of all British files relating to the crash and recovery of debris from Aer Lingus flight E1712 St. Phelim, in March 1968, and files relating to civilian and military air traffic at the time and area of the crash; and if all Irish files have been made available to the relatives of the crash victims.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In response to a question in the House of Commons in March of this year, a Minister at the Department of Environment, Transport and the Regions in the UK, indicated that

the Air Accidents Investigation Branch file relating to this accident was reviewed by the Department of Transport (in the UK), in September 1994. It was not selected by the Public Records Office for permanent preservation in the National Archive and was destroyed at that time.
The Ministry of Defence has documentation relating to the search and rescue aspects in the immediate aftermath of the accident which will be made public in accordance with the 30 years rule.

MainHeading.P: The UK Air Accidents Investigation Branch were assisting the official inquiry being conducted by the officials of my Department in the years following the tragic crash of the Aer Lingus Viscount, the St. Phelim. It is therefore likely that the significant items in the Air Accidents Investigation Branch file, such as reports of analysis of components and engines from the St. Phelim, which were conducted in the UK, were copies of what was sent to my Department. These reports are still held in my Department.

The voice tape of the air traffic communications between London air traffic control and the St. Phelim are in the possession of my Department, and the transcript of these communications was included in the official published report into this accident. This Department is not aware of any other UK air traffic records relating to this accident. This Department has acceded to all requests for information regarding this tragedy from relatives of the victims or their representatives including the examination of records. I understand that the relatives of the victims of the St. Phelim have formed a Tuskar tragedy relatives support group. Should representatives of this group wish to meet with me, I would be happy to do so at a mutually agreeable date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - EURATOM Treaty.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to recent media reports which suggest that the Irish contribution to EURATOM is currently £3 million per annum; her views on whether funding for the nuclear industry is congruent with the overall policy position of the Government; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

the plans, if any, she has to review the Irish Government financial contribution to EURATOM in view of increasing public concern regarding the threat to public health posed by the Sellafield Nuclear Reprocessing Plant which EURATOM subsidises; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 217 and 218 together.

As Ireland is party to the EU Treaties, we must pay our contributions to the EU budget. EURATOM activities form part of this budget and the expenses of EURATOM are financed directly out of the general EU budget.

The EURATOM Treaty remains the main framework for dealing with nuclear matters within the European Community. Ireland's priority has been to steer the EURATOM programme of activities and budget towards nuclear safety and radiological protection and the implementation of the Non-Proliferation Treaty and Protocols.

MainHeading.P: I should add that the EURATOM Treaty encompasses some important provisions for the protection of health and safety of workers and the general public. Article 30 of the Treaty provides for basic safety standards which must be laid down within the Community for the protection of the health of the general public and workers against the dangers from ionising radiation. My Department and the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland are actively involved in making preparations for the introduction into Irish law of Directive 96/29/EURATOM which sets out new revised standards of safety in this field.

Qst.Quest: if telephone lines will be available to rural dwellers at the same cost as other users after deregulation in view of the fact that this has not been the case up to now; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: There is no discrepancy in charges for telephone connection charges and line rental for urban and rural customers. Telecom Eireann are obliged to supply this service at the same price, regardless of geographic location. The Director of Telecommunications Regulation is responsible for ensuring compliance with this obligation.

After full liberalisation of the telecommunications sector, the Director of Telecommunications Regulation will be responsible for administering a universal service obligation, which will ensure that telecommunications services subject to that obligation are made available to all users independent of geographic location at an affordable price.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Energy Policy.

Qst.Quest: her views on the options available in the area of energy policy over the period ahead; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The three objectives of Irish energy policy are competitiveness, security of supply and environmental compatibility and it is expected that these will continue to be the main drivers of policy in the years ahead.

One of the most significant developments in the energy sector in recent years has been the increasing trend towards liberalisation of energy markets globally. At EU level, two directives have been adopted in the recent past providing for the introduction of competition into the electricity and gas markets. Earlier this year my Department issued a consultation document setting out the legislative proposals for the implementation of the electricity directive and work has commenced on proposals for the gas industry. This legislation will pave the way for the development of a competitive energy supply industry in Ireland into the new millenium by encouraging new entrants into the electricity and gas markets.

It is expected that the strong growth in energy demand will continue in line with our economic growth. However, major improvements in energy efficiency in recent years mean that while GDP is expected to be 80 per cent higher than 1990 levels by the year 2000, our energy consumption is forecast to increase by 30 per cent in the same period. Continued improvements in energy efficiency will help to further contain this growth.

MainHeading.P: In line with the Government's commitment in An Action Programme for the Millennium I intend to publish a Green Paper on sustainable energy by the end of the year. The public consultation processs in relation to the Green Paper has just been completed. It will address, inter alia, the potential contribution of renewable energy resources to the Irish energy mix.

Qst.Quest: the policy measures, if any, she proposes to apply in order to secure free and open competition in the provision of the infrastructure needed to provided telephony, e-mail and Internet access services to business and domestic customers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The provision of infrastructure for already liberalised services, such as e-mail and Internet access, was liberalised on 1 July 1997.
Full competition in the provision of infrastructure for all services, including voice telephony, will be introduced on 1 December 1998.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether the ESB and Cablelink will be in a position to exercise a competitive advantage vis-à-vis Telecom Éireann in the provision of e-mail and Internet access services in view of the potential of cross-subsidisation in this area once the basic infrastructure is in place; her further views on whether this will distort the telecommunications market; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will give an overview of the relative competitive advantages and disadvantages enjoyed by the ESB with the British BT company, Cablelink and Telecom Éireann in the area of e-mail and Internet access provision to business and domestic subscribers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 225 and 229 together.

The Director of Telecommunications Regulation has certain functions and powers in relation to the development of competition in the telecommunications sector, including powers to ensure that cross-subsidisation does not occur in the telecommunications sector.

Anti-competitive behaviour in the telecommunications sector also comes within the scope of the Competition Authority in accordance with the Competition Acts. The question of the relative competitive positions of the companies referred to by the Deputy is a matter for the companies themselves.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I have not made any such agreement with any exploration company.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether Cablelink, when privatised, will be in a position to use its cable system to provide Internet access to subscribers and consumers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

whether it is the policy of her Department to provide the necessary authorisation to allow Cablelink to offer full telephony, e-mail and Internet access services to its 300,000 customers in Dublin, Galway and Waterford; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose taking Questions Nos. 227 and 230 together.

The Director of Telecommunications Regulation is responsible for the issuing of licences for both telecommunications infrastructure and service provision. I have no function in the granting of such licences to Cablelink. It is the Government's policy that the Cablelink system should be upgraded as a platform for the provision of a full range of multimedia services, including full telephony services. The necessary investment for this upgrading will be raised by the sale of Cablelink. Cablelink is set to become a strong competitor in the high growth telephony and multimedia market in Ireland and recently announced its plans to introduce a high speed Internet service.

Qst.Quest: whether she anticipates that the telecommunications joint initiative involving the British BT company and the ESB will result in bringing down both electricity and telephony prices to the consumer; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In entering the telecommunications business, through its joint venture with BT, ESB is seeking to capitalise on the commercial opportunities presented by the new market opening and to utlise its assets to the best advantage of the company and its electricity customers. The Government's decision to accelerate the opening of the telecommunications market to full competition will bring significant benefit to consumers. Ocean — the joint venture between ESB and BT - has publicly stated that it will bring choice of international connectivity and price competitiveness to Irish telecommunications customers. It will also provide a range of data and voice services for business and residential customers which should bring both price benefits and new services.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to publish a discussion or White Paper on communications policy; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is not my intention at this time to publish a White Paper on communications policy. The Deputy will however be aware that I recently appointed an advisory committee for telecommunications which is charged with the task of advising me on the strategy which should be pursued to develop Ireland as a centre for electronic commerce. I understand that the advisory committee will invite submissions on the development of this strategy in the course of its work. The report of the committee which is to be finalised by the end of the year will be published.

Qst.Quest: whether, in light of the telecommunications joint initiative involving the British BT company and the ESB, she anticipates that telephony charges generally are set to decrease; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: In the fully liberalised telecommunications market, the charges which telecommunications companies may levy on their customers are a matter for the companies themselves, having regard to competitive market conditions.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether the telecommunications joint initiative, involving the British BT company and the ESB, poses a threat to the viability and long-term commercial prospects of Telecom Éireann; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My fundamental objective is that competition in the Irish markets work to the benefit of all consumers, be they residential or business, large or small. My announcement earlier in the year of the ending of the derogation on voice telephony and public network infrastructure by 1 December next will accelerate competition in the provision of telecommunications services and infrastructure in the Irish market.

Activity in the telecommunications sector in Ireland has risen very sharply in recent years driven by the twin forces of liberalisation of the sector and strong underlying growth in the economy generally. I am confident that Telecom Éireann will continue to play a significant part in the sector and also in developing new services and will be well positioned to meet the challenge that will be posed by new operators such as Ocean, the joint telecommunications venture between ESB and British Telecom.

Qst.Quest: her views on whether the cost of telephone calls between land lines and mobile telephones are excessive; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

whether it is currently cheaper to make a telephone call to a mobile phone in Britain from Ireland than to make a telephone call to a mobile phone within Ireland; whether such a pricing structure is ultimately sustainable or indeed justifiable; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 234 and 250 together.

The price of telephone calls to mobile phones is a matter for the day to day operations of Telecom Éireann subject to the limits laid down in the price cap which applies to its services. Following the full liberalisation of the telecommunications sector from 1 December this year, Telecom Éireann will face competition from new public voice telephony operators and competitive market forces will therefore strongly influence telephone call prices.

the position in relation to the proposal to develop a wave energy generating station for which £1 million of EU funds have been set aside; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 234, 235, 237, 240, 241 and 269 together.
I have received a final report from ETSU recommending the WaveGen Ireland proposal as winner of the wave energy-to-electricity section of the AER III competition.

I noted in the final report that the winning applicant had applied for 1.24 MECU in European Regional Development Fund grant aid under the Economic Infrastructure Operational Programme for the project, provision of which was subject to the approval of the monitoring committee of the Economic Infrastructure Operational Programme and the European Commission.

The monitoring committee, which includes the European Commission, has decided not to provide grant assistance for the wave energy station from the Economic Infrastructure Operational Programme. It is the committee's view, based on an assessment of the project by the committee's independent evaluator, that wave technology has not advanced sufficiently beyond the research stage to justify assistance under this particular Operational Programme. In theory, Ireland has considerable potential for generating electricity from wave power. I believe it is important that we begin to harness that power and for that reason I am prepared to consider nominating the project to receive an offer of a power purchase agreement at its bid price.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Radioactive Discharges.

Qst.Quest: whether she has satisfied herself that the OSPAR Resolution, agreed earlier this year, is as much as can be achieved in terms of reducing the threat that Sellafield poses to the health and welfare of people living in this country in view of the accidents that have occurred at Sellafield even since the OSPAR meeting; whether she will use every opportunity to make the case for the plant to be closed down or decommissioned; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will outline the information available to her Department which would help define the naturally occurring background level of radiation in the Irish Sea, close to which level the authorities responsible for the operation of the Sellafield Nuclear Reprocessing Plant are required to bring discharges from the plant under the terms of the OSPAR Convention; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if she will outline, in light of continuing concern about the safety of the nuclear reprocessing plant at Sellafield, the steps being pursued by her Department to have reprocessing cease at Sellafield and to have the plant closed or decommissioned; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

the contacts, if any, she has had with Minister Michael Meacher of the United Kingdom pursuant to his remarks in mid-July that the Government in Great Britain is prepared to consider closing the Sellafield Nuclear Reprocessing Plant; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 238, 239, 242 and 254 together.

As the Deputy is no doubt aware, the UK nuclear industry, in particular Sellafield, has long been a source of grave concern to successive Irish Governments. This Government is totally committed in its opposition to the Sellafield operations and will continue to work towards a cessation of nuclear activities at the site.

Over the past 12 months, my Department has been involved in making a number of submissions to the UK Environment Agency in the context of public consultation processes held by the agency about Sellafield. On 16 March 1998, two separate submissions were forwarded to the agency detailing Ireland's concerns about an application from BNFL to the agency for a variation in the Sellafield Radioactive Discharge Authorisations and an application by BNFL to the agency to commission a mixed oxide fuel fabrication plant

MainHeading.P: — MOX — at Sellafield. I am awaiting the decision on these crucial applications.

In the case of radioactive discharges, there was a very positive development in Portugal, in July, at the ministerial meeting of the OSPAR Commission, held to discuss the OSPAR Convention on the Protection of the Marine Environment of the North-East Atlantic. At the meeting, which I attended, the OSPAR Ministers adopted a strategy on radioactive substances which incorporates a commitment by the contracting parties to this convention to achieve close to zero radioactive discharges into the marine environment by the year 2020.

In effect, this means that the UK Government will be obliged to achieve close to zero discharges of radioactive substances into the Irish Sea by the year 2020. In keeping with this commitment, the UK authorities have requested BNFL to prepare “forward-looking” strategies for reducing discharges over the next twenty years.

As to the naturally occurring or “background” levels of radiation in the Irish Sea, the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland — RPII — point out that the main pathway for radiation exposure is the consumption of seafood. The RPII's report on Radioactivity Monitoring of the Irish Marine Environment 1996 and 1997 concluded that a heavy fish consumer would receive 150 microsieverts in “background” radiation. This compared with 1.4 microsieverts radiation exposure to the same consumer originating from Sellafield discharges in 1997.

As a result of commitments made within OSPAR, artificial radionuclide concentrations in the Irish Sea will be close to zero by 2020, leading to a further reduction in the already comparatively small radiation exposure to a heavy fish consumer which is Sellafield originating. The progressive and substantial reduction of Sellafield's discharges between now and 2020 will have the added advantage that it will help to allay legitimate concerns about the impact of radioactive discharges. I believe that the positive commitments made have the potential to assist in the preservation of sea-based livelihoods which might otherwise be at risk due to contamination of the Irish Sea. The promotion of consumer confidence in seafood and sea produce and the use of the amenities of the Irish Sea should benefit from the OSPAR decisions.

The most recent contacts with Minister Meacher were during the meeting of OSPAR Ministers in Portugal. I found these discussions helpful in gaining an insight into current UK thinking about Sellafield and particularly the UK Government's wish to address public concerns about the impact of Sellafield discharges. I have no immediate plans to meet Minister Meacher in the near future but I await with interest the outcome of forthcoming decisions concerning the Sellafield discharge authorisations in the aftermath of OSPAR.

While I am pleased with the progress made at OSPAR in relation to radioactive discharges, the agreement will not directly address our concerns about a number of the nuclear operations at Sellafield. Unfortunately, there is no evidence at present that the UK Government intend to close the Sellafield reprocessing plant. We will continue to highlight our concerns, both directly with the UK authorities and at relevant EU and international fora, about the continuation of reprocessing activities at Sellafield; the storage on-site of high level radioactive liquid waste; the operation of Magnox reactors beyond their design life and proposals for a MOX fuel manufacturing plant.

Qst.Quest: if she will outline the information that has been provided to her Department by the regulatory authorities in Great Britain or directly by BNFL concerning the escape of radioactive material from the Sellafield plant on 3 August 1998; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The incident to which the Deputy refers occurred on 3 August last in the mixed oxide fuel — MOX — demonstration facility at Sellafield. There was a minor release of radioactivity which was contained within the building.

The Radiological Protection Institute — RPII — received information early on 4 August last. The incident, which occurred in a laboratory in the MOX building, involved a torn protective glove in a glove box used for hazardous work. Radiation alarms were activated and personnel were evacuated from the immediate area. One person was found to have been contaminated and was sent to the site surgery for examination. Testing showed that there was no internal contamination and all external contamination was removed. Other personnel involved were monitored and everyone was found to be clear of contamination.

I have been assured by the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland that the incident did not have any radiological consequences for Ireland. However, any such incident can give rise to public concern about the possibility of a nuclear accident which would affect us. My concerns about incidents at Sellafield will continue to form part of formal discussions between Irish and UK officials on nuclear safety matters.

Qst.Quest: the actions undertaken to date and the proposals on hand in her Department to effect a reduction on sulphur dioxide and NOx emissions from power generation; if she will outline the voluntary agreements entered into with producers in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The EU Large Combustion Plant Directive (88/609/EC) regulates emissions of SO2 and NOx from large scale industrial plant. National commitments under protocols to the UN-ECE Geneva Convention on long-range transboundary air pollution also apply, however, and the voluntary arrangements entered into between the ESB and Government in this regard are more stringent.

Under the Geneva Convention Protocols, Ireland must limit national NOx emissions to their 1987 levels from 1994 onwards and reduce national SO2 emissions by 30 per cent on their 1980 level from 2000 onwards. Applied on a pro rata basis to the power generation sector, NOx and SO2 emissions reductions of 42,000 tonnes and 82,000 tonnes per annum respectively have been agreed between the ESB and Government.

ESB reports on its emissions on an annual basis to the Department of the Environmental and Local Government and to the Environment Protection Agency. ESB has met its commitments in the past and has plans in place to ensure compliance in the future. These plans include the additional use of gas, low sulphur oil and coal and the installation of additional low NOx burners at power stations.

The agreement between the ESB and Government regarding limitations on SO2 and NOx is a voluntary one and my Department is kept apprised of the ESB's performance in meeting these voluntary obligations.

The forthcoming measures necessary to implement the EU electricty directive are likely to result in the present voluntary agreement with the ESB being superseded by industry-wide arrangements to take account of new entrants to the market, in order to ensure that SO2 and NOx reduction commitments continue to be met.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Sustainable Development.

Qst.Quest: whether the forthcoming electricity Bill is to be so framed as to be fully congruent with the national strategy for sustainable development; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The primary purpose of the forthcoming Electricity Regulation Bill is to implement in part EU Directive 96/92/EC concerning common rules for the internal market in electricity. This phase will see the necessary minimum provisions being put in place to establish a regulatory regime for the electricity sector. Further legislation to give full effect to the directive is scheduled to follow next year.

MainHeading.P: I envisage that this initial Bill will include a range of provisions, which reflect the Government's commitment to sustainable development. The proposals include: a provision for the regulatory commission to exercise its functions under a range of duties which include taking account of the protection of the environment, as well as promoting safety, efficiency and economy of electricity undertakings; a provision that plant authorisations will be granted subject to criteria laid down by the Minister as required under the EU electricity directive. These criteria may include safety and security of the electricity system, protection of the environment and energy efficiency; a provision for the Minister to give directions to the commission regarding the imposition and recovery of the cost of public service obligations including those relating to environmental protection; a provision designed to take account of the alternative energy requirement programmes conducted by the Minister; and an enabling provision for consumers to purchase electricity generated from renewable energy.

Qst.Quest: whether EU Directive 90/313/EEC on access to environmental information and SI No. 185 of 1996, which is the relevant implementing regulation, will apply in full to any new body to be established under the forthcoming electricity Bill; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: S.I. 185 of 1996 has been repealed by S.I. 125 of 1998 which provides that all public authorities, having public functions and responsibilities, and possessing information relating to the environment, shall, notwithstanding any other statutory provision and subject only to the conditions and exceptions provided for, make available to any person who requests it any information relating to the environment to which the Statutory Instrument applies.

The primary purpose of the forthcoming Electricity Regulation Bill is to implement in part EU Directive 96/92/EC concerning common rules for the internal market in electricity. This phase will see the necessary minimum provisions being put in place to establish a regulatory regime for the electricity sector. Further legislation to give full effect to the directive is scheduled to follow next year.

The forthcoming Electricity Regulation Bill provides for the establishment of the electricity regulatory commission. Given that the commission would fall within the definition of a public authority as outlined in S.I. 125 of 1998 i.e. it will be a body established by statute and will have public administrative functions and responsibilities and will possess environmental information, the provisions of the statutory instrument would apply to it.
