MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Rail Network.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to a report which concludes that much of the 600 mile long Irish rail track is over-age and worn beyond what would normally be acceptable on other European railways; the steps in hand to rectify this matter; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

if her attention has been drawn to a report which suggests that the 84 mile Mullingar to Sligo railway line is the most dangerous in Ireland and among the most dangerous rail routes in Europe; the steps being taken to improve safety along this stretch of rail track; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to answer Questions Nos. 251 and 252 together.

I should explain firstly that the board of CIE has a statutory responsibility under the Transport Act, 1958, in relation to the safe operation of its services and I have been assured that safety is the priority consideration in the operation of the railway.

The report referred to by the Deputy is an independent safety review of railway infrastructure which was carried out earlier this year for Iarnród Éireann by consultants A.D. Little. The consultants' brief was to examine the track and signalling infrastructure on the railway lines with jointed track. The consultants identified a number of areas where work will be required over the coming years, including the stretch of line from Mullingar to Sligo mentioned by the Deputy.

MainHeading.P: Earlier this year I commissioned a strategic review of all aspects of rail safety to be carried out by consultants, International Risk Management Services — IRMS. In addition to the infrastructure aspects looked at by A.D. Little, the IRMS brief extends to an examination of rolling stock, overall safety policy and on-the-ground safety practice. The review, which will take into account the A.D. Little findings, is expected to be completed within the next month and it is my intention to publish it.

Arising from the A.D. Little report, I asked CIE to prepare a railway safety investment plan which I will consider in conjunction with the IRMS report when it comes to hand. When I have completed my consideration of these reports I will make appropriate recommendations to Government at an early date.

As part of the reallocation of the Luas EU assistance, additional track renewal expenditure of £26 million was approved in June. This includes an extra £14 million which will enable track renewal work on the Mullingar to Carrick-on-Shannon section of the Sligo line to be completed. This in turn will reduce the risk categorisation of this line in the context of the A.D. Little report.

In the meantime, in response to a request from the Department of Finance my Department has made an initial submission on EU funding for public transport projects in the post-1999 period. The submission takes account of proposed investments identified by CIE in a review carried out earlier this year and includes proposals for the Mullingar to Sligo line.

Qst.Quest: her estimate of the potential for the penetration of the electricity market by privately owned powerstations operating on a combination of heat and power; whether the operation of such plants on a widescale basis would reduce electricity costs for domestic consumers; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Joe Jacob
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: The European Commission's “Communication from the Commission to the Council, the Parliament, the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions on a Community strategy to promote combined heat and power (CHP) and to dismantle barriers to its development” recommends that the European Union should endeavour to increase CHP to 18 per cent of gross electricity production by 2010.

Ahead of the liberalisation of the electricity market in Ireland it is not possible to estimate the potential level of penetration of any power generation technologies, combined heat and power included, and to estimate the likely impact of any individual technology on electricity costs for the domestic consumer. In the context of the Green Paper on substainable energy, I will examine how Ireland can contribute fully to achieving the EU target.

Qst.Quest: her views on a media report (details supplied) that the International Federation of Air Line Pilots' Associations has placed Schipol Airport, Amsterdam, on a black list because noise restrictions on the approach and take-off paths to the airport are a safety hazard; and if she will raise this matter with her counterpart in the Dutch Government given the importance of Schipol to Ireland as an international hub airport.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of safety at airports in the Netherlands is a matter for the Dutch authorities. EU regulations allow the Dutch authorities to establish on a non-discriminatory basis rules relating to the protection of the environment, including noise restrictions.

The Irish Aviation Authority is charged with the regulation of safety of operations of all Irish airlines. The authority has informed the Department that no safety concerns in relation to Schipol Airport have come to their attention, either from Irish airlines or otherwise.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Telecommunications Regulation.

Qst.Quest: the current position in relation to the proposed sale of Cablelink; the way in which the sale will be processed and the timescale involved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The Government is commmitted to the continuing development of competitive multi-media and telecommunications sectors, since they are key factors in sustaining the development of the Irish economy.

The prime consideration in the sale of Cablelink is to ensure the upgrading of its network to enable it to become an important provider of a range of advanced multi-media services including digital television, internet, telephony, and value added services such as data services, messaging, near-video-on-demand, video conferencing and interactive services such as home shopping and home banking. Cablelink is set to become a strong competitor in the high growth telephony and multi-media market in Ireland and recently announced its plans to introduce a high speed Internet service.

A steering group has been established representing all the interests involved to manage the sale process. This group is chaired by the Department of Public Enterprise, representing the Government, and also comprises representatives from KPN/Telia, the strategic partners in Telecom Éireann, Telecom Éireann and RTE. This group is arranging for the full disposal of Telecom Eireann's and RTE's shareholdings in Cablelink through a trade sale process.

MainHeading.P: The sale of Cablelink Ltd. requires expert consultants to advise and assist in relation to the sale. Following a competitive tendering process N. M. Rothschild & Sons Limited were appointed to advise on the sale. Preparations are in hand to issue an information memorandum to potential bidders. This memorandum will issue once the Director of Telecommunications Regulation has clarified the future licensing regime to apply to the company which is expected shortly. The process will then involve bidders in preparing initial indicative bids from which a shortlist will be selected. This will be followed by a detailed “due diligence” process performed by each of the shortlisted bidders, final negotiation of the sale and purchase agreements and formal completion of the sale. The sale process, subject to final regulatory approvals, is expected to take three to four months from the issue of the information memorandum.

Qst.Quest: her plans, if any, to give legislative effect to the Government's decision to sell shares in Telecom Éireann through an I.P.O.; if subscribers to Telecom Éireann and its consumers will be allowed purchase shares; and, if so, the conditions under which shares will be made available.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The preparations for an IPO in Telecom Éireann next year are now in train. Merrill Lynch and AIB Capital Markets have been engaged as joint financial advisers and distributors on all aspects of the flotation of shares owned by the State in the company next year. In addition, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher and Flom have been retained as international counsel during the course of the IPO process.

Such expert financial and legal advice will be very important in terms of determining the details of the IPO such as the amount of shares to be sold and the structure of the offer. I can, however, say at this stage that it is the Government's intention that the public will be able to subscribe for shares in the IPO. As members of the public, Telecom Éireann's customers will, of course, be able to subscribe for shares but the detailed terms of any public offer will not be settled until much closer to the flotation date. Decisions on the size and structure of the offer will only be made in the period leading up to the flotation. At this stage, the IPO is being targeted to take place around mid 1999, depending on market conditions.

Preparatory work is at an advanced stage in my Department on the legislative changes necessary to enable the IPO to proceed and to make legislation pertaining to Telecom Éireann compatible with its subsequent status as a publicly quoted company. It would be my intention to bring the draft Bill to Government over the coming months.

Qst.Quest: if she will provide a list of the peat fired power stations that will close and their closure dates pending the completion of the Euro Peat II power station at Edenderry, County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The peat review group, comprising representatives of my Department, ESB and Bord na Móna, was set up in August, 1993. Its mandate was to identify opportunities to increase the long-term usage for milled peat in electricity generation in an efficient and economic manner for all the interests concerned. The group reported in February, 1995. The optimum scenario identified in the report, which was accepted by the boards of ESB and Bord na Móna, comprised: (1) the proposed closure of a number of units in the existing stations, (2) a refurbishment programme by ESB in other plant and (3) the development of the new 120 MW peat station in the east midlands.

The refurbishment programme for the existing stations coupled with the commissioning of the new 120MW station represents a long-term strategic approach to ensure the continued use of peat in electricty generation. It also maximises long-term employment in peat production and electricity generation in the midlands.

The new 120MW peat station is due to come on stream in 2001. A 20MW unit at both Rhode and Ferbane are effectivley no longer operational and two further 20MW units at Ferbane and one 20MW unit at Rhode are due to be decommissioned before 2001. The precise decommissioning dates will have to be synchronised with ESB's refurbishment proposals for the other units at these stations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Electricity Regulation.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, she has for the implementation of the EU Directive relating to competition and liberalisation of the electricity generating sector.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: My Department has undertaken an extensive consultation process to date regarding implementation of the EU electricity directive in Ireland which is due by February 2000. The Directive requires that approximately 28 per cent of the Irish electricity market be opened to competition at that time, rising to about 32 per cent within three years. Proposals for implementing the directive were published in May 1997, a discussion forum was held in January 1998 and a further consultation document was published in May 1998.

MainHeading.P: I propose to publish shortly the Electricity Regulation Bill to establish an independent regulatory regime for the electricity industry with a view to it being enacted before the end of the year. The current legal situation is that ESB require my approval under the Electricity Supply Acts for capital expenditure on any new plant. Private companies, on the other hand, wishing to enter the market in competition with ESB, require a permit from ESB under the Electricity Supply Act, 1927. ESB is therefore currently in a position of operating in the market and at the same time regulating the entry of competitors.

In the circumstances, I have been advised by the Attorney General that it is essential to arrange for the immediate establishment of an independent regulatory commission to oversee the electricity sector.

The comments received in response to the May 1998 consultation document were considered when preparing the heads of the currently proposed Bill and will be further considered when preparing the balance of the legislation for the full implementation of the EU directive which will follow next year.
Legislation will also be required next year to deal with the conversion of ESB from a statutory corporation to a public limited company under the Companies Acts.

Qst.Quest: the role, if any, she or her Department has had in resolving the difficulties relating to Dublin Port in the dispute between the Irish Road Haulage Association and port operators.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke

On these two occasions my Department played an active behind the scenes role in seeking a resolution to the issues which gave rise to the disputes and in facilitating contact between the parties involved. My Departmet has also made available the services of an independent facilitator on request to assist the parties in addressing these issues.

Qst.Quest: the arrangements, if any, being made by the Irish Aviation Authority for new air traffic control facilities; whether there are any European rules governing tendering procedures and if global competitors will be given an equal opportunity to compete for this work; and if she will clarify the criteria for the selection of any such tender.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: In November 1996 the Irish Aviation Authority — IAA — presented proposals for a new Air Traffic Control Centre — ATC — at Shannon. Following a rigorous appraisal of the authority's proposal the then Minister of State, Deputy Emmet Stagg, on 15 April 1997 conveyed approval in principle for the authority to proceed to the detailed planning stage for the development of a new air traffic control and training centre at Shannon. A further proposal for equipping the new ATC facilities was submitted to my Department on 17 June 1998. Following consideration of this project I conveyed my approval to the chairman of the authority to proceed to tender for the new equipment.

The authority's contracting and tendering arrangements encompass the EU utilities and the Government public procurement procedures. The procuremennt of the building services and air traffic mangement systems and equipment for its new air traffic facilities are accordingly carried out in strict conformity with the foregoing procedures.

The authority has now commenced the tender process. The criteria for the award of the air traffic management equipment contract was published as part of the notice of competition placed in the Official Journal of the European Commission (OJEC) on 29 July 1998 — TED-Ref. 96374-98. The criteria for the award of the building services contract will be included in the tender invitation to be issued to tenderers selected in accordance with the notice of competition placed in OJEC on 4 September 1998 — TED-Ref. 115783-98.
All competitors will, within the confines of the OJEC notices, be given an equal opportunity to compete for these contracts.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Gas Prices.

Qst.Quest: whether her attention has been drawn to an increase in gas prices to householders from An Bord Gáis from 10.7997 to 11.5186 pence which is an increase of over 10 per cent; if there are regulatory or other controls in place to control the price of gas; the justification made for this significant increase; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob) Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State in the Department of Public Enterprise (Mr. Jacob)
Speaker.P: There has been no increase in gas prices to householders. The current price of gas, which has not been increased for over ten years, will continue at least until the year 2000. Since early 1997 Bord Gáis Éireann has been importing increasing quantities of natural gas from the North Sea to supplement the declining supplies of Kinsale Head Gas. Practically all natural gas used by customers in Dublin is now imported through the Ireland-UK gas interconnector.

MainHeading.P: The purchase price paid by BGE for natural gas is based on the calorific value — energy content — of the gas. The imported gas has a higher calorific value than Kinsale Head gas, i.e. a lesser volume is required for the same energy output.

Customers using North Sea gas continued to be billed on the Kinsale Head gas calorific value until April 1998 when BGE increased the conversion factor to account for the higher calorific value of the imported gas. A conversion factor is applied to each bill to convert the customer's gas consumption, measured in terms of volume, to the unit of billing, i.e. kilowatt hours. This does not mean an increase in the price of gas to the customer — the amount of North Sea gas required for a given energy output is less than what would be required to produce the same energy output using Kinsale Head gas.

The figures referred to by the Deputy reflect the change in the conversion factor from 10.7997 to 11.5186, and not the unit price of gas. The calorific value of imported gas can vary over time because gas is supplied from a number of different gas fields in the North Sea. Consequently the conversion factor will continue to vary.

My approval is not required for the application by BGE of the relevant conversion factor to billing. BGE has assured me that the methodology for determining calorific values is based on best international practice and is directly comparable with the approach taken in the UK.
Under the Gas Acts, my powers in relation to gas prices are limited to the giving of general directives to BGE concerning its pricing policy as to the sale and supply of gas.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Earlier this year, Ryanair submitted a proposal for my consideration of their plans to build a second terminal at Dublin airport to operate in competition with Aer Rianta's facilities there.

The board of Aer Rianta itself is currently conducting a fundamental review to establish what would be the most appropriate strategic direction for the company and is expected to submit a report to me within six months. Qst.Quest: if she has clearly formulated a framework for development of an employee share ownership programme in the commercial State companies; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The question of employee share ownership schemes in commercial State companies will be dealt with on a case-by-case basis. I am in no doubt that in the right circumstances such schemes can be of benefit to the company, the staff and the wider economy. There are certain guiding principles which are to be applied in all cases: employees can be offered shares in return for agreement to genuine restructuring and to changes in work practices which make the company more competitive, provided the value of the shareholding is commensurate with the value of the agreed changes and that those changes are not also being paid for in some other way; the transfer of those shares must be linked in some measurable way to the implementation of the agreed restructuring and agreed changes in work practices; it may also be possible for employees to buy additional shares at market value; purchase of these additional shares should not involve recourse to the company or to the State to fund their purchase.
Finally, a critical test in any change of shareholding arrangements for State companies is that there must be benefit to the economy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Import of Animals.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the recent move in the United Kingdom to introduce a passport for pets system in view of the fact that there is free movement of pets between Ireland and the United Kingdom; the plans, if any, he has to introduce this scheme here; if so, when it will be introduced; the changes, if any, there will be in the quarantine laws for domestic pets in line with EU regulations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he has satisfied himself with the level of controls on imports of animals coming into the country, particularly pets, in view of the greatly reduced number of customs officers operating at ports; the proposals, if any, he has to improve the surveillance in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 301 and 358 together.

The import of pet cats and dogs into this country is governed by the Rabies Orders, 1972-76. There is free movement of these animals from the UK, Channel Islands and the Isle of Man as they share the same common health status. Animals from all other countries must undergo a period of six months quarantine in a premises approved by my Department. These requirements are designed to eliminate the risk of rabies being brought into the State by animals incubating the disease. Entry is by way of import licence and a strict surveillance regime is in place at all ports and other points of entry.

MainHeading.P: I have noted the report of the Advisory Group on Quarantine, established by the UK Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, which was published last week. The report recommends that, for cats and dogs travelling between Great Britain and the member states of the European Union, the European Economic Area, or rabies-free islands, the quarantine system should be replaced with a system involving vaccination, blood testing and microchip identification requirements. The report also notes that a further period of up to three years would be required to enable the arrangements necessary to give effect to its recommendations to be put in place. A three month period of public consultation has begun in the UK and I will be following developments closely. In this regard, plans are already in train for Ireland to host a meeting of the rabies control liaison group, which includes all participants in the common quarantine arrangements — Ireland, Britain, Channel Islands, Isle of Man — to take place later this year. Changes which might be contemplated in the UK system of quarantine controls would hold potential for this country, given the common approach to rabies which both countries have followed over many years.

Qst.Quest: the changes, if any, which have occurred in the REP scheme regulations for 1998.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The following changes in the operation of the REP scheme were introduced during 1998.

P.i: Revision of REPS in respect of NHAs and Commonages

Speaker.P: The most significant development was the agreement of the European Commission to the new improved package of measures in REPS drawn up to address environmental conservation in Natural Heritage Areas (NHAs) including Special Areas of Conservation (SACs) and Special Protection Areas (SPAs) and commonages. This new measure will be known as Supplementary Measure A and replace Supplementary Measures 1 and 2 of the existing scheme. As a result increased payments will be available to farmers in these areas.

P.i: Improved Control Procedures for Organic Supplementary Measure (SM6)

Speaker.P: The eligibility rules in relation to this measure were clarified in view of the large number of REPS applications involving this measure, where part of the area being claimed for was commonage, which is not capable of being farmed organically by a single shareholder. Applicants with commonage land or grazing rights are ineligible to participate in the Organic Supplementary Measure (SM6).
The option of a destocking payment of 210 ECU/Livestock Unit (LU) combined with a reduced area payment under these supplementary measures was withdrawn.

The requirement that applicants who owned commonage land must have ten acres of privately owned or leased land to qualify the commonage land for payment was abolished. In addition, the acceptance of new applicants to REPS with commonage land is now subject to the new arrangements for NHA commonages.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Pigmeat Sector.

Qst.Quest: the initiatives, if any, he proposes to take to protect the pig industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. B. Smith Mr. B. Smith
Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, being taken to off-set the serious difficulties facing pig producers, particularly in the Border region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. B. Smith Mr. B. Smith
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, being made towards the provision of additional pig slaughtering capacity in the Border region; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 315, 365 and 366 together.

The difficulties in the pigmeat market derive mainly from surplus production within the EU coupled with weakness in international markets, notably Asia and Russia. The situation in Ireland has not been helped by the loss of slaughtering capacity as a result of a fire in June at a Northern Ireland plant. I have taken a number of initiatives at both national and EU level aimed at alleviating the situation for Irish pig producers.

Earlier in the summer, I sought and secured increased export refunds from the EU Commission. In May last, the Commission increased the rate of refund on pigmeat exports and followed this with a further increase in August. In view of continued weakness in the export market and in particular on the Russian market, I have again raised the question of a further increase this week at the Agriculture Council.

I also sought the introduction of an aids to private storage scheme to support the market at this time. The Commission also agreed to do this, and a very attractive scheme was introduced with effect from 28 September. This will provide EU funding for the storage of up to 70,000 tonnes of pigmeat destined for export to third countries for up to six months prior to the shipment. I have put a proposal to the Commission for an adjustment in the veterinary inspection fee to reflect the price payable to the producer at a particular time within the pig cycle.

MainHeading.P: The backlog of pigs awaiting slaughter on the market which arose from the fire has now been greatly reduced. To deal with the problem, it was agreed jointly betweeen the IFA, the Irish Association of Pigmeat Processors and my Department, to put arrangements in place for Saturday slaughterings. The recent purchase of a major pigmeat plant in Northern Ireland by the firm which owned the plant destroyed by fire should also help to alleviate the overhang of pigs on the market in the south.
An Bord Bia has recently launched a promotion campaign designed to encourage sales of pigmeat on the domestic market.

All in all, I am confident that the range of measures taken in response to the weakness in the market will have the desired effect and that it will very soon become evident in the returns to producers. I will keep the situation under review and with strong support from other member states I will continue to press the Commission to ensure that suitable export arrangements, including refunds, are in place to allow EU traders compete on world markets and to exploit every possible export opportunity.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The regulations governing payment of the 1996 BSE compensation package, which was paid out in October 1996, provided for payment of top-ups in respect of animals which qualified for payment under the 1995 EU suckler cow premium scheme and 1995 EU special beef premium scheme. The regulations also provided for adjustments, upwards and downwards, later on to take account of the number of animals qualifying for payment under the 1996 EU suckler cow premium scheme and the 1996 EU special beef premium scheme. In effect, the regulations require that when all balancing payments under the 1996 EU suckler cow premium scheme and 1996 EU special beef premium scheme are made a comparison will be carried out between the number of animals qualifying for payment under the 1995 schemes and the number qualifying under the 1996 schemes. Money is to be recouped from those farmers who, had fewer animals qualifying under the 1996 schemes. The money so recouped is then to be used to make payments to those farmers who had more eligible animals under the 1996 schemes.

A message to this effect was conveyed to all herdowners by way of an addendum to the pay orders at the time of issue. The person named was paid BSE top-up amounting to £515.00 — £22.40 × 23 — based on the 23 suckler cows on which he was paid premium under the 1995 suckler cow premium scheme. As the herdowner did not have eligible animals for premium under the 1996 suckler cow premium scheme the overpayment made must be refunded.

Qst.Quest: the system in place to identify the exact date of birth of animals on the old blue card system where these animals are bought in by farmers and no date of birth is noted on the card; the position in this regard; the way in which a farmer is to establish the date of birth of an animal that he has purchased operating on the old card system; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture and Food (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: The old green — blue card system which was in place for brassed tagged bovine animals did not require that the date of birth of an animal be recorded. Neither was there a birth registration system for calves in place.

Animals identified under that system and which are now being exported to an EU member state must be reidentified with double plastic tags and issued with passport documentation, which requires the dates of births to be recorded. The dates of birth of calves have to be entered on cards-passports since early 1996.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Urban and Rural Renewal Schemes.

Qst.Quest: if he has received sanctions from the European Commission for the introduction of the urban renewal areas; when he expects to announce his decision on same; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the commencement date of the renewal scheme for the upper Shannon region in view of the fact that there is a substantial amount of work planned under this scheme; if his attention has been drawn to the potential loss of investors because of the delay; when the application, if any, was lodged to the EU Commission for approval; the status of the application and the timescale involved; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. B. Smith Mr. B. Smith
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the introduction of the rural renewal scheme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 369, 417 and 422 together.

With regard to the introduction of the rural renewal scheme, while I am aware that there is a lot of planned investment and work on hold pending the introduction of the commercial and industrial elements of the rural renewal scheme, I must add that under EU Commission Regulations on State Aid all business tax incentives must have the Commission's approval prior to their introduction. However, no such EU constraint arises in connection with the residential tax incentives in the rural renewal scheme and for this reason I introduced the residential tax incentives with effect from 1 June 1998.

MainHeading.P: There have been major problems arising in obtaining the necessary EU Commission approval for the business tax incentives despite the fact that they were discussed with the Commission in Brussels at meetings in February, May and July 1998. The two business tax incentives in the rural renewal scheme are the capital allowances for the construction or refurbishment of industrial and commercial buildings and the double rent relief for the lessees of such buildings. These same two reliefs were the subject of formal notification sent to the EU Commission at the end January 1998 in connection with an extension to the Custom House Dock Area in Dublin. It was decided it would be advisable to wait until these two reliefs were processed by the EU Commission for the Custom House Dock Area before formally notifying them again to the Commission for the rural renewal scheme given that the reliefs were the same in both cases. As the Deputy will appreciate, the views of the Commission in regard to the first scheme should clearly be of assistance in framing the subsequent formal notification for the rural renewal scheme.

However, as the Commission had not yet approved the Custom House Docks scheme by mid-September despite all my Department's efforts, it was decided that the Commission be formally notified immediately of the rural renewal scheme. The formal notification was done on 17 September. The timescale for dealing with the application is a matter for the EU Commission and every effort will be made to assist the Commission in processing the application as quickly as possible.

The position with regard to European Commission approval for the new urban renewal scheme is similar to that applying to the rural renewal scheme. Both schemes were discussed in tandem with the Commission at meetings in February, May and July 1998, and were formally submitted to the Commission for approval on 17 September. Any decision on the designation of areas for inclusion in the new urban renewal scheme will be made as soon as possible after EU approval has been obtained for the scheme.

Qst.Quest: the reason the 2.5 per cent insurance levy continues to be charged on insurance policies in the State in view of the fact that the purpose of the levy was to cover the ICI bankruptcy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The current non-life insurance levy is 2 per cent and not 2½ per cent. The levy is imposed on almost all non-life insurance premia, the exceptions being reinsurance, health insurance, marine, aviation and transit insurance and export credit insurance. The yield from this levy in 1997 was £30.5 million. Similar levies exist in most other EU countries and, in general, at rates much higher than 2 per cent. The levy was introduced to broaden the stamp duty base, thereby raising additional revenue. Consequently, at this stage, I have no plans to abolish this levy.

A separate levy was brought into effect on 1 January, 1984 by the then Minister for Industry and Commerce to fund the Insurance Compensation Fund. From 1984 until the end of 1991 the levy was charged at a rate of 2 per cent of gross premium income and paid by all non-life insurers. From 1 January 1992 until 1 January 1993 the levy was charged at 1 per cent. This levy, which was not a taxation measure, ceased to apply from 1 January 1993.

Qst.Quest: if he will clarify the situation in relation to any possible extension of the time limit for an urban renewal tax designated project (details supplied) in County Wexford; whether there is a precedent for extending the timetable where there is a delay which is no fault of the developer; and whether such an extension would be granted in this case in order to finalise the development in view of the investment and other consequences.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The 1994 urban renewal scheme has already been extended twice. In the 1997 Finance Act the end-July 1997 deadline was extended by one year to end-July 1998 provided at least 15 per cent of the expenditure on the project had been incurred by end-July 1997. This condition also applied when the scheme was given a further five month extension to end-December 1998 in the 1998 Finance Act. The additional conditions associated with this extension are that an application for planning permission must have been received by a planning authority by 1 March 1998 and the planning authority must also certify that the failure to meet the end July 1998 deadline was due in its opinion to a significant extent, to unanticipated delays relating to obtaining planning permission or a fire certificate or legal proceedings or a number of other factors. With regard to the issue of extending the time limit for a project under the existing urban renewal scheme, there is no precedent of the deadline being extended for an individual project.

Qst.Quest: the reason VAT is charged on the free telephone rental allowance element of a Telecom Éireann phone bill and on the free electricity allowance element of an ESB electricity bill; his views on whether this is appropriate; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Electricity services are taxed at the reduced VAT rate of 12.5 per cent while telecommunications services are taxed at the standard rate of VAT which in Ireland is 21 per cent.

Persons with invalidity pensions and others in receipt of the free electricity allowance do not pay VAT on the standing charge and units which are the subject of these allowances; the relevant VAT is paid by the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs.

As regards the free telephone allowance, customers in receipt of this allowance do not pay VAT on the rental and units which are the subject of the allowance, as it is also paid by the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs.
I appreciate that these arrangements may not be readily apparent from the way in which either the electricity or telephone bills are structured or presented.

Qst.Quest: if he will extend the present exemption for spouses from capital acquisitions tax on the family home to persons either living together as man and wife or close relatives, for example, brother and sister or uncle and nephew where it can be demonstrated that the persons in question have been living together for a period of at least ten years in the property which constitutes the family home, where neither party has a beneficial interest in any other property and where one or both have contributed to either the cost of purchase or upkeep of the residence in question; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: With regard to the inheritance of the family home, I remind the Deputy that in the 1998 budget, I extended the sibling relief scheme and introduced a new relief for other close relatives, other than children, where the threshold is £188,400 per child inheriting their family home. This means that given certain conditions the value of the family home taken by inheritance by a beneficiary, other than a child, can be reduced by up to 80 per cent or £150,000, whichever is the lesser for the purposes of determining the liability, if any, to capital acquisitions tax.

The capital acquisitions tax treatment of cohabiting couples was discussed during the Committee Stage of the 1998 Finance Bill. At that stage, I said that the issues involved are complex and that finding an amendment to the capital acquisitions tax code to deal with this problem, which would be in line with Irish law and the constitution has up to now proved difficult. There are a number of substantial problems, including difficulties with definition, which have been identified in attempting to provide a general relief or exemption from capital tax treatment of cohabiting couples. As the Deputy will no doubt appreciate, the general rule has been that tax law follows general law relating to marriage.

I am conscious of the difficulties which can arise for cohabiting couples in certain circumstances. An interdepartmental working group has been set up under the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs to examine the treatment of married, cohabiting and one-parent households under the tax and social welfare codes. This group is due to report later this year.

However, with regard to inheriting the family home from either a close relative or from one's partner, I did indicate at that time, that the matter would be considered further in the context of the 1999 Finance Bill. Consequently, the many complexities associated with this issue will be examined further over the coming months.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to a practice whereby some lending institutions breach the two and a half times income criteria for borrowers who require a mortgage; his views on this practice; the discussions, if any, he has had to date with lending institutions on this matter; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: In the first instance, I have no direct statutory responsibility in relation to the extension of credit by individual credit institutions to individual consumers. However, I have been advised by the Central Bank that it continues to monitor the guidelines applied by the credit institutions in lending for house purchase and is satisfied that these are generally prudent. The bank has repeatedly warned the institutions of the dangers inherent in high rates of credit growth and any relaxation of lending standards and has reminded them of the necessity to ensure that lending standards are being adhered to rigidly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that the matter referred to by the Deputy relates to a compromise penalty paid by the person concerned for release of a vehicle which had been seized by Revenue Officers on 9 January 1997 for evasion of vehicle registration tax. The amount evaded was £1,300.

Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the employment of people with disabilities in the Civil Service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The Civil Service, as an employer, is committed to a policy of equal opportunity for people with disabilities, which includes ensuring that people with disabilities who are capable of effective performance in the jobs to which they aspire are not disadvantaged by reason of having a disability.

Since 1994 a code of practice for the employment of people with disabilities in the Civil Service has been in place. The code of practice covers issues such as recruitment, reception and integration into the workplace, career development, accommodation, equipment, safety and evacuation procedures. The implementation of the code of practice is monitored by a committee representative of staff and management. In addition, in the context of the Strategic Management Initiative in the Civil Service, equality issues, including issues relating to the employment of people with disabilities, are being examined by a committee set up specifically for this purpose.

As you are aware the policy in relation to the employment of people with disabilities in the Civil Service is implemented by (a) from time to time holding competitions confined to candidates with a disability, (b) facilitating candidates with a disability when competing in open competitions not confined to people with a disability and (c) where possible, retaining staff who become disabled after their recruitment.

As of 1 April 1998, there were 777 people with disabilities employed in the Civil Service, representing 2.8 per cent of the staff. The fact that this has dropped below the target of 3 per cent is a cause of concern and the matter is being kept under review. The heads of each Government Department and office have been made fully aware of the importance of reaching and maintaining the 3 per cent quota. My officials are currently in the process of gathering the figures for 1 October 1998.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Value Added Tax.

Qst.Quest: if he will review the rate of VAT charged on educational journals.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Research journals, including professional educational journals, in book form, other than those which are issued as periodicals, attract the zero rate of VAT.

Generally speaking, where such periodicals are normally paid for by annual subscription, have their pages sequentially numbered by reference to the completed work and are supplied with a binder or are bound for no extra cost in book form at the end of the year, they are regarded as books and thus zero rated for VAT purposes.
This approach ensures that the zero rate applies to most research journals, including those purchased by the libraries of the universities, research institutions and similar bodies.

MainHeading.P: In addition, the Finance Act, 1998 provided for a significant rationalisation of the VAT treatment of printed matter. With effect from 1 May this year, the reduced rate of 12.5 per cent, rather than the standard rate of 21 per cent, has applied to magazines and periodicals generally, as well as to brochures and leaflets and other similar printed matter which is not purely advertising. Thus, those educational and professional journals which do not qualify for zero rating have benefited from this recent reduction in the VAT rate of 8.5 percentage points.
If there are any particular cases causing difficulties, the Deputy should advise those concerned to contact the Revenue Commissioners, who will be glad to discuss the matter with them.

Qst.Quest: if he will reduce the rate of VAT on services and sales in order to help small service sector businesses such as beauty salons; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Beauty salons and many other service sector businesses already benefit from the reduced rate of 12.5 per cent VAT.

The Government is committed in Partnership 2000 to maintain labour intensive services which include beauty salons at the reduced rate in the medium term and to seek in the forthcoming negotiations at EU level to have the option of reduced rating on labour intensive services included in the future VAT system.

Qst.hpid: Mr. C. Lenihan Mr. C. Lenihan
Qst.Quest: his views on the need to concentrate decision-making on transport policy in one ministry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The Government on coming to office in 1997 made a series of changes in the allocation of functions and responsibilities between Ministers and Departments. These reflected its considered view on the appropriate distribution of functions of Government between its members. That remains the situation.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to tax traffic congestion through company car park charges, thereby creating a pool of revenue for investment in quality public transport systems; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the plans, if any, he has to impose or to provide for the imposition of car parking charges on large scale out of town shopping centres in view of the contribution they make to traffic congestion and to undermining the commercial vitality of town centres; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 380 and 381 together.

With regard to the issue of out-of-town shopping centres affecting the commercial vitality of town centres, section 344 of the Taxes Consolidation Act, 1997 provides capital allowances for the construction or refurbishment of certain multi-storey car-parks where the relevant local authority certifies that it is satisfied that the car-park has been developed in accordance with criteria laid down by the Minister for the Environment and Local Government following consultation with the Minister for Finance. Among the criteria which must be met in the development of a qualifying multi-storey car-park are that the car-park must support the objective of making the core area of the urban centre in which the car-park is located, the focus for the centre's commercial and business activity. Furthermore, the planning and design of the multi-storey car-park must take account of the nature and character of the area in which it is located and the provision of the car-park must be supportive of the relevant local authority's traffic and parking management policies.
While I have no proposals under consideration at present to impose car parking charges on company car-parks or on car-parks in out of town shopping centres, the matter will be kept under review.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Rural Decline.

Qst.Quest: the special taxation or other measures, if any, in place to address the problem of rural decline, particularly in villages with a population of less than 1,000 where essential services are being put at risk due to a vicious cycle of decline; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: In the 1998 Finance Act I introduced a pilot rural renewal scheme for the upper Shannon area subject to EU approval. The area covered by the scheme comprises of all of counties Leitrim and Longford, north County Roscommon, the western part of County Cavan and a large part of County Sligo. The incentives available under the scheme consist of accelerated capital allowances for industrial and commercial buildings, double rent allowance for business tenants for activities approved by the EU Commission, and reliefs for the construction, conversion or refurbishment of certain rented residential accommodation which commenced on 1 June this year. The business reliefs were submitted to the EU commission for formal approval on 17 September last. It is hoped that this scheme will ameliorate the process of decline in the areas covered by the scheme.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the Deputy's queries concerning other measures addressing the problem of rural decline, this is a very broad question and one might argue that any measure which is directed at rural areas is tackling this problem. Examples of these would be the work done by the county enterprise boards, the Leader groups and the area partnerships. Similarly, things like headage payments made to farmers or agricultural relief for gifts or inheritances of agricultural property, stamp duty relief on transfers of land to young trained farmers might also be considered as measures which address the needs of rural communities and the problem of rural decline.

The Minister for Agriculture and Food is currently preparing a White Paper on rural development which will focus on the needs of rural communities and address issues raised by the Deputy. I suggest that that document will contain a more comprehensive picture of the issue than is possible to set out in this reply.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Taxation of Energy Products.

Qst.Quest: if he will report on his Department's contribution to date to the preparation of a common EU taxation policy on carbon and fossil fuel inputs; the attitude adopted by his Department in these discussions; the specific proposals, if any, his Department has tabled in the context of these discussions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
his views on the merits and demerits of introducing a package of carbon taxes in the context of the forthcoming budget; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
his Department's approach to the current EU discussions on harmonizing taxes on energy products; and if he will provide copies of all memoranda relating to this proposal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 383, 402 and 411 together.

Proposals on the taxation of energy products were presented by the EU Commission in March 1997. Since then, they have been the subject of examination by technical experts reporting to the ECOFIN Council. No level of agreement has been reached in these discussions.

MainHeading.P: I can inform the House that the proposed directive suggests both increased existing taxes on items such as petrol and proposes new taxes on coal, gas and electricity. There are also complex arrangements to assist energy intensive industries with both obligatory and optional provisions for relief from the tax suggested. It is proposed that the EU would apply such taxes irrespective of any requirement for paralleling action by other non-EU countries, including the USA. It is necessary from an environmental viewpoint to examine these proposals constructively. Nonetheless, while the imposition of a carbon tax — at either EU or domestic level — may influence both private and industrial consumers in their use of energy products, I would be concerned, as Minister for Finance, to ensure that any measure which is advanced to promote energy saving does not adversely affect Ireland's international competitiveness. I am also concerned about the effect the imposition of such taxes would have on the Consumer Price Index and how any tax would impact on the less well off members of the community.
I am sure that the Deputies will acknowledge the validity of these concerns which have been conveyed to our EU colleagues.
Details of the proposal are set out in Commission Document COM (97) 30 final, 97/0111 (CNS), dated 12 March 1997.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Exchange Transaction Tax.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the proposals advanced by a person (details supplied) in relation to the possibility of taxing speculative transactions on the exchange market at a rate of 0.05 per cent which would create a pool of revenue in the industrialised countries which would be collecting the tax for possible distribution to the national and international bodies which struggle against growing inequality in the developing world, which promote education and public health in poor countries and provide the strategic resources needed in poor countries to achieve food security and sustainable development; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

his views on the imposition of a tax on speculative transactions in the exchange market unilaterally at national level or on the prospects for such a tax to be introduced by international agreement at EU or OECD level; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 384 and 385 together.

Gains in speculative transactions in the exchange market are already taxed here under the capital gains tax or income tax or corporation tax code, depending on whether the gain arises in the course of a financial trade, or whether it accrues to an individual or a company. Losses on speculative transactions are also of course treated as allowable deductions for tax purposes.

While I am aware of the Tobin proposal regarding a tax on speculative transactions. I am not aware of any proposal to implement this measure on an international basis, at this stage. Furthermore in the light of EMU it may not be possible for Ireland to take action, in this way, on a unilateral basis.

MainHeading.P: With regard to the provision of resources to poorer countries, the Deputy will be aware that a major priority of the Government as set out in An Action Programme for the Millennium is to give increased aid to developing countries. The amounts provided over the last three years from 1996 to 1998 have been as follows:
1996 — £106 million
1997 — £122 million
1998 — £151 million (est)

Finally, the Government recently announced its intention to contribute £31.5 million to help alleviate the crushing burden of debt on the poorest countries in the world. Of this, £22 million will be given to the IMF and World Bank to assist in their programmes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - National Debt.

Qst.Quest: the meetings, if any, officials of his Department have had with Finance officials of other smaller EU member states to discuss the management of Government debt after the introduction of the euro; if his attention has been drawn to the attitude of the EU Finance Commissioner, Yves Thibault de Silguy, to these meetings; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if Irish bond auctions are likely to be cancelled in 1998 and thereafter would be held on fixed dates to avoid clashes with the bond auctions of other smaller EU and euro member states; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if the yield on Ireland's benchmark ten year bond has dropped from 6.3 per cent in December 1997 to 4.93 per cent in July 1998; if so, the implications of this trend for Ireland's ability to market Government debt after the full introduction of the euro; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 386, 387 and 395 together.

The management of the national debt is a matter for which the National Treasury Management Agency (NTMA) has been delegated responsibility, under the provisions of the National Treasury Management Agency Act, 1990.

MainHeading.P: There have been no formal meetings between officials of my Department and their counterparts in other smaller EU member states specifically about the management of Government debt after the introduction of the euro. However, officials of my Department and the NTMA, along with representatives of similar organisations in other member states, participate in an ad hoc working group on debt redenomination and market conventions set up by the Monetary Committee in the autumn of 1997 — the purpose of this ad hoc group is to assist member states in dealing with the technical challenges involved in the redenomination of debt at the start of stage three of economic and monetary union.

I understand from the NTMA that, since 1992, some of its officials have had informal meetings on a regular basis with its counterparts in other smaller EU member states. At two recent meetings, the implications of the euro for national debt management in smaller EU member states were discussed; I understand from the NTMA that no further discussions are planned on this subject. I am aware of a newspaper report which attributed views to EU Commissioner de Silguy in relation to meetings between smaller member states, but I do not know whether the report accurately represents Commissioner de Silguy's views on this matter.

As regards bond auctions, I understand from the NTMA that it does not intend to cancel any bond auctions announced in its calendar for 1998. I also understand from the NTMA that it is planned to continue with a calendar of bond auctions in 1999, subject to the ongoing review of the arrangements for issuance in the context of the changing euro market environment. While the precise dates for auctions after 1998 have not yet been decided, I understand that they will take account of bond auction dates of other euro member states, in particular the larger states.

The yield on Ireland's ten year benchmark bond fell from 6.3 per cent in August 1997 to 5.5 per cent in December 1997 and fell further to 4.93 per cent in July 1998. I understand from the NTMA that this downward trend reflects, among other things, EMU convergence as well as an increased demand for Irish Government bonds, and that the latter augurs well for their sale in the deep, liquid, euro-denominated bond market. The NTMA feels that competition between euro area Government borrowers will increase greatly in the euro and that it will be faced with a major marketing challenge, which I am confident it will successfully meet.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Community and Voluntary Sector.

Qst.Quest: his Department's estimate of the value to the economy of services provided to the community by volunteer or volunteer-managed organisations in the fields of personal social services, community development, training, education and literacy, information and advocacy, therapy and counselling, environmental protection and awareness-raising, sporting, recreational and leisure pursuits, services to refugees and asylum seekers, etc; his views on whether this contribution is adequately matched through the provision by Government of supportive infrastructure, core-funding and grant-aid; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: There are no estimates by my Department of the added value of services specified in the Deputy's question. The macroeconomic statistics — the national accounts published for the Irish economy by the Central Statistics Office and used in this Department — record only those transactions relevant to the measurement of Gross Domestic Produce in the economy. I understand that the services to which the Deputy refers do not comprise part of GDP to the extent that money transactions are not involved.

The national accounts are a comprehensive framework within which economic data can be presented in a coherent and consistent manner. They are subject to strict international guidelines under the new international system of National Accounts as amended within the EU to ESA 95, European System of Accounts, to meet the needs of member states. These do not encompass the measurement of voluntary activity.

However, just because community and voluntary activity is not measured in the national accounts is not a reason to dismiss the importance of the contribution to our society of the work carried out by this sector in terms of the services they provide to communities. The contribution of the voluntary sector is supported by very significant amounts of Government expenditure in such areas as health, education and training, social welfare, equality etc.

The role of the voluntary sector and its relationship with the State has been the subject of debate for many years. In an effort to ensure that community and voluntary organisations can grow in a supportive and enabling environment, I understand that my colleague, the Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs will be bringing forward a White Paper on the community and voluntary sector early next year.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Anti-Poverty Strategy.

Qst.Quest: the policy areas, if any, he intends to develop in his forthcoming budget to address the deepening crisis of rural poverty as documented in a recent authoritative study published by the Combat Poverty Agency; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: It is not usual to make any advance statements on budget strategy.

However, I would like to point out that the matter is being addressed by my colleague, Deputy Davern, Minister for State at the Department of Agriculture and Food, with responsibility for rural development who is chairing an inter-departmental committee on the preparation of a White Paper on Rural Development.

MainHeading.P: The White Paper will address rural development, including the questions of rural exclusion and poverty as a broad multifunctional process involving the economic, social, cultural and environmental conditions which influence the quality of life of rural communities.

It will provide a vision statement of the overall objective to be achieved in rural areas in the medium to long term and the broad policy framework, together with the necessary institutional mechanisms to achieve it.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to figures available to his Department which show that the number of people earning in excess of £100,000 per annum has more than doubled in the past five years and to figures from the Combat Poverty Agency which show the incidence of poverty increasing significantly in the same period; if these trends are congruent with the policies being pursued by his Department and with the budgetary policy pursued in recent years; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: My attention has been drawn to figures from the Revenue Commissioners which indicate that the number of income taxpayers with taxable income exceeding £100,000 increased from 2,100 in the 1993-4 tax year to 4,600 in the 1997-8 tax year an increase of 2,300. Over the same period, the number of income taxpayers increased by 177,000 to 1.2 million. Given that the percentage of taxpayers whose taxable income exceeds £100,000 is less than half of one percentage point of all income taxpayers, I do not consider the fact that the number has doubled a particularly meaningful statistic.

The Combat Poverty Agency does not have any figures on the incidence of poverty in Ireland which cover the same period as the Revenue Commissioners' figures. The agency has confirmed that the most recent figures on poverty levels available to it, is the ESRI's report entitled Poverty in the 1990s. This report relates to the period 1987 to 1994 and shows a consistent fall in aggregate poverty between 1987 and 1994.

The budgetary strategy in recent years is designed to strengthen the economy's capacity for sustainable employment, economic growth and social inclusion, in a low inflation environment while continuing to improve the public finances. I agree with the widely held view that the best anti-poverty strategy is the creation of sustainable employment. Over the last four years, the economy has grown at an average of 7.5 per cent per annum generating unprecedented increases in employment. The unemployment rate has fallen by over a third — from 14.7 per cent in 1994 to 9.0 per cent. Long-term unemployment has also fallen dramatically.

MainHeading.P: The reduction in unemployment will have reduced poverty accordingly — in 1994, households headed by an unemployed person constituted the largest single group of households in poverty. There was also a high incidence of poverty among women in “home duties”. A significant part of the additional employment in the economy has been taken up by women formerly engaged in “home duties”.

Budgetary strategy is currently underpinned by Partnership 2000, in which there is a commitment to invest an additional £525 million on a full year cost basis on the promotion of social inclusion over a three year period. The 1997 budget allocated £273 million for this purpose and I allocated a further £282 million in the 1998 budget thus exceeding, in only two years, the three year commitment in 2000.
