Qst.Quest: the total number of taxpayers in each year declaring an income in excess of £250,000 per annum for each of the past five tax years; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The following is the information requested in so far as it is available:
Taxpayers declaring an income in excess of £250,000 per annum from 1994-5 to 1998-9:

row.entry: Number of income taxpayers with gross incomes exceeding £250,000.

MainHeading.P: Notes:
(1) A married couple who has elected or has deemed to have elected for joint assessment is counted as one tax unit.
(2) The figures in the table for 1996/97, 1997/98 and 1998/99 are projected estimates and are subject to revision.
Deputies will be aware of the measures I introduced in budget 1998 to reduce the availability of certain tax shelters used in particular by high income earners.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to proposals drawn up by Dublin Corporation to levy a bed tax on tourist accommodation within its area; whether his Department has assessed the likely revenue generation capacity of a local tax; whether his Department has formed an opinion on the likely effect on the Exchequer of the imposition of such a tax; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
his view on the desirability of introducing local bed taxes relating to tourist accommodation at local authority level; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 392 and 393 together.

I have no proposals under consideration for the imposition of a tax on accommodation of the sort described nor has my Department made any estimates of potential yields. I would remind the Deputy that VAT at 12.5 per cent already applies to hotel accommodation.

Qst.Quest: his views on the desirability of introducing landing taxes on the harbours of our offshore islands during the summer months from which island residents would be exempt with a view to generating the revenue at island community level to provide the sort of infrastructure, facilities and resources needed by the islands to cope with increasing tourism traffic; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I have no proposals to introduce taxes of the sort described by the Deputy. On balance, it would not be desirable to introduce taxes on individuals passing from one part of the national territory to another.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Public Sector Pay.

Qst.Quest: whether public sector pay, which has increased ahead of average increases in the private sector in recent years, is likely to come into line with the level of pay increases generally in the economy in the mid-term future; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Public servants have fared well under the local bargaining provisions of the Programme for Competitiveness and Work (PCW). The significant upward drift in the level of settlements, from the initial figure of around 3 per cent has imposed substantial additional costs on the Exchequer, over and above what was initially envisaged when the PCW was agreed.

Despite this, there are still demands from some quarters for further increases in cases where local bargaining agreements under the PCW have already been finalised. This is something that the Government can not countenance. There is no basis for any group getting increases beyond those which have already been agreed within the terms of the PCW. There can be no opening of existing agreements and all remaining negotiations must be resolved within the PCW cost parameters.

As regards future developments, the level of increase provided for in the Partnership 2000 Pay Agreement is the same in both the public and private sectors and I am determined that, in the case of the public service, there will be no moving away from the cost limits agreed in Partnership 2000.

MainHeading.P: Public and private sector pay movements can be compared by using the earnings series produced by the Central Statistics Office, viz. those dealing with public sector average earnings, on the one hand, and those dealing with industrial earnings, construction earnings, and banking, insurance and building society earnings, on the other hand. The table below sets out the increases in each sector in the one-year, three-year and nine-year periods up to December 1997 (the latest date in respect of which figures are generally available for the various sectors). These figures indicate as follows:
(a) increases in the public sector have been higher than those in banking, insurance and building societies but lower than those in construction over all the relevant periods, and
(b) although the public sector increase was lower than that for industrial earnings in the year to December 1997, it was higher in the other periods.
Note: *September 1988 — September 1997.

It should be noted that (i) the December 1997 figures do not reflect a number of the more recent pay settlements in the public service, such as those involving craftworkers and gardaí, and (ii) the public sector average earnings index does not include the health sector, which accounts for about one-third of the public service.

It is essential to have regard also to the expenditure implications of public service pay, given that the Exchequer Pay and Pensions Bill accounts for just over half of all current voted expenditure. I should point out, in this context, that by the end of 1998 the paybill is expected to be nearly double what it was in 1989 — an average increase of nearly 8 per cent a year over the period 1989-98. By way of comparison, aggregate inflation over the same period has been less than 30 per cent.

Excessive pay demands in the public service risk undermining the competitiveness of the entire economy by accelerating the growth in public expenditure, diverting resources away from required improvements in the quality of public services, restricting the scope for further tax reform, undermining our budgetary performance and ultimately leading to reduced employment in the economy.

Further upward drift in public service pay would also increase pay pressures in parts of the private sector. This would have damaging effects on competitiveness and would be likely to make it more difficult to secure the support of private sector workers for an acceptable successor agreement to Partnership 2000.

Qst.Quest: the effect any likely budget surplus in 1998 will have on the implementation of the National Anti-Poverty Strategy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The emerging surplus this year will be used to retire our debt burden which in turn will reduce our debt servicing costs and release resources for more productive purposes.

In the last budget I identified the reduction of the national debt as one of a number of strategic issues. As I pointed out at the time, this country is still deeply in debt. At the end of 1997, our national debt exceeded £30 billion which is equivalent to about £22,000 for every person at work. The interest costs alone are over £2 billion. The freeing up of some of these resources will assist the Government in providing for the longer term needs of the economy.

The National Anti-Poverty Strategy (NAPS) is a ten-year plan which was launched in April 1997 with a target of reducing the number of people in persistent poverty from 9-15 per cent of the population to 5-10 per cent. It also includes the halving of the unemployment rate to 6 per cent and the long-term unemployment rate to 3.5 per cent by 2007.

Considerable progress has already been made towards meeting these targets. The unemployment rate has already fallen to 9 per cent and the long-term rate to 5.6 per cent, in March 1998. There were substantial real increases in social welfare payments in 1997 and 1998 and especially for the elderly in 1998. In addition, the Government recently decided that all significant proposals coming before the Government be assessed for their impact on poverty-proofing.
I am satisfied that the Government is already well placed to meet the targets set out in the NAPS.

Qst.Quest: if it is his policy to maintain a link between social welfare payment increases and wages rather than with prices in the context of preparations for the December budget; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Social welfare payment increases are not directly linked to either wages or prices. At every budget the amount available for allocation is limited. This means that social welfare increases have to reflect the balance struck between the many competing demands for these limited resources. That has been the approach in the past and will also be the approach in the 1999 budget. Notwithstanding these constraints, in this year's budget, I provided for increases of £3 per week in personal rates, while qualified adult allowances rose by 3 per cent. These increases were well above the expected rate of inflation and reflected substantial progress towards meeting the commitment in Partnership 2000 to implement, before the end of the Partnership, the minimum rates recommended by the Commission on Social Welfare. I also announced an increase of £5 per week in the full personal rate of all old age and related pensions, which gave these elderly people increases ranging from 6 per cent to almost 7.5 per cent, or at least three times the expected rate of inflation. Furthermore, all increases in social welfare payments were brought forward to the first week in June 1998, which meant that the new rates were payable for 31 weeks in 1998 as compared with 29 weeks in previous years.

The Government's Action Programme for the Millennium also contains a commitment to increase the old age pension to £100 per week by the year 2002. I hope to make some progress in this year's budget towards fulfilling that commitment.

Qst.Quest: if he will consider the funding crisis in our mental handicap services in the framing of his forthcoming budget; his views on the proposal of the National Association for the Mentally Handicapped of Ireland that a figure of £25 million be provided specifically to eliminate waiting lists for services and to deal with the appalling conditions being experienced by people with a mental handicap who are resident in psychiatric hospitals including St. Ita's, Portrane, County Dublin; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The Government is currently considering the 1999 expenditure Estimates, together with the financial envelopes for the years 2000-1. It would be neither practicable nor appropriate for me to speculate on the outcome for one particular aspect of these deliberations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Charitable Status.

Qst.Quest: the exact wording of the confidentiality reasons which prevent the Revenue Commissioners from making public the details of those organisations to which they have granted, at public expense, the benefits of charitable status in tax law; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the cost to the Exchequer, in terms of revenue foregone, arising from the designation by the Revenue Commissioners of certain organisations which for confidentiality reasons are unknown to the public as having charitable status for each year in which the Revenue Commissioners have exercised this discretion; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the individual or body which has responsibility for monitoring or policing the Revenue Commissioners specifically in the matter of their observation of certain confidentiality reasons which prevent them from making known to the tax paying public the details of organisations which have been granted charitable status in tax; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 400, 401 and 403 together.

While the information sought on charities is not generally published, the Deputy will be aware that section 61 of the 1998 Finance Act introduced a scheme of tax relief for companies who make donations to bodies which have been granted exemption from tax on the basis that they have been established for charitable purposes only and have been authorised under the scheme. The Act specifically provides that the Revenue Commissioners may make available the name and address of any body authorised under the scheme and I will send the Deputy a list of these names.

MainHeading.P: The question of whether more general information such as details of tax exemptions granted to taxpayers, other than information covered by the 1998 Finance Act, should be made available to the public by the Revenue Commissioners is a matter for decision within the terms of the Freedom of Information Act, 1997. That Act provides for the non-disclosure of information given to a public body in confidence, where disclosure would be likely to prejudice the giving of further similar information to that body from the same person or other persons. The Revenue Commissioners have advised me of their view that the non-disclosure of information they receive in confidence in the ordinary way from taxpayers, including information received in the course of applications for exemptions, is an important element underpinning voluntary compliance with the tax laws and in maintaining public confidence in the tax system. I am also informed by the Revenue Commissioners that the question of the release of the names and addresses of bodies granted exemption as charitable bodies is currently being considered by the Information Commissioner who is generally responsible for reviewing decisions not to release information under the Freedom of Information Act. The information commissioner will decide whether or not the maintenance of the confidentiality principle in this particular matter outweighs any public interest concerns.

I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that details are not available in relation to the cost to the Exchequer, in terms of revenue foregone, as a result of the granting of charitable exemption. Such information could not be obtained without undertaking inquiries which could be carried out only at a disproportionate cost.

The Deputy should be aware that the role of the Revenue Commissioners in relation to charities is confined to consideration of applications from bodies of persons or trusts claiming exemption from tax on the basis that they are established for charitable purposes only. The issue of the general regulation of charities on the other hand is the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to publish the recommendations of the Interdepartmental Committee on Instruments to Promote Environmental Protection which he will be taking into account in framing his package of financial incentives for renewable energy in the context of the forthcoming budget; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I assume the Committee to which the Deputy refers is the interdepartmental group, established following the budget of 23 January 1996, whose remit was to examine the strategic impact of taxation on environmental policy.

I can assure the Deputy that the recommendations of this group will be considered in the run up to the budget. However, I draw the Deputy's attention to the provisions of section 62 of the Finance Act, 1998 which relates to relief for investment in renewable energy generation. The operation of the section is a matter for the Minister for Public Enterprise.
The question of publication of recommendations does not arise at this stage but there are procedures under the Freedom of Information Act for the release of this information at the appropriate time.

Qst.Quest: the scale of the incentives he has in mind in his budget package to encourage investment in renewable energy in view of the commitments contained in the document entitled Sustainable Development: A Strategy for Ireland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: This year's Finance Act provides for a new tax relief for corporate equity investment in renewable energy projects which are approved by the Minister for Public Enterprise. The scheme is a pilot scheme which will operate for three years and will apply to wind energy, biomass, solar and hydropower technologies. Up to 50 per cent of the total capital cost of the project, net of grant and excluding land acquisition costs, may be tax relieved under the scheme, subject to an overall cap of £7.5 million per project.

The scheme is subject to EU Commission approval under the state aid provisions of the treaty and it will be commenced once this approval is obtained. In the circumstances, I do not envisage any further incentives for renewable energy in the forthcoming budget.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to recent comments (details supplied) which referred to a yawning gap in our child care laws; the proposals, if any, he has to provide tax incentives for minders who care for pre-school children and incentives for childminders to register so as not to drive good and experienced but unregistered child minders out of the market; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The Government's policy programme, An Action Programme for the Millennium, contains a number of priorities focused on support for both parents and their children.
With regard to child care, in my budget speech last December I said:

It is not possible to introduce all the new measures one would wish in a single budget. I have examined carefully the possibility of a tax relief on child care at the standard rate of tax but have decided not to proceed with it this year. I will review the situation for my next budget in the light of the reports due next year from the Working Group on Childcare set up under Partnership 2000 and from the Household Review Group and the Commission on the Family set up by the previous Government.
The reports of these groups will enable me to give these issues more informed consideration in the context of the preparation of the forthcoming budget.
As regards the question of child care laws and registration of child minders, the Deputy will appreciate that these are matters for the Minister for Health and Children.

Qst.Quest: the investigation, if any, carried out by his Department, in line with the practice in certain other EU member states, notably France, Austria, Germany and Italy, to assess the appropriateness of introducing fiscal instruments to stimulate an indigenous biofuel industry; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Section 116 of the Finance Act, 1995 already provides, subject to certain compliance as detailed in the section, for the remission or repayment of duty in respect of biofuels used in pilot projects undertaken in the State, which are designed to manufacture or produce biofuel or to test the technical viability of biofuel for use as motor fuel and are required for use in the project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Tax Reliefs.

Qst.Quest: if he will amend the VAT (Refund of Tax) (No. 15) Order, 1981, to allow for VAT exemption on building works required for adaptation of living accommodation for persons with a disability; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The position is that under VAT (Refund of Tax) (No. 15) Order 1981 it is possible for individuals to obtain repayments of VAT expended on certain aids and appliances which assist persons with a disability overcome that disability. For example, walk-in baths, lifting seats and chairs, hoists and lifters and stair lifts, designed for persons with a disability, as well as iron lungs and kidney machines, can qualify for relief.

MainHeading.P: There are no repayments of VAT available in respect of any general construction, as the provision of building work is regarded as a service for VAT purposes and is not, accordingly covered by the terms of the order. An extension of the order on the lines proposed by the Deputy could be seen as the introduction of an additional zero rate of VAT and under the EU Sixth VAT Directive, member states may maintain existing zero rates but are prohibited from introducing new ones.

I understand instead that there are direct grants available from the Department of the Environment and Local Government for the construction of facilities for people with disabilities and the operation and terms and conditions of the scheme is a matter for that Department.

I should also point out that there is an income tax relief available in respect of interest on moneys borrowed for the repair or improvement of a taxpayer's main residence. This relief is, however, subject to the normal ceiling on mortgage interest relief.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Rural Renewal Schemes.

Qst.Quest: if he will extend the County Sligo qualifying rural areas scheme to include the two extra electoral districts (details supplied) which are contiguous to areas already classified in order to redress the disadvantage suffered through the dilution of the tax package originally announced for the regional airports and as it would bring the Strandhill, County Sligo area into the rural renewal scheme to the benefit of the airport land which is now being developed for industry and internationally traded services; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Since the announcement of the pilot rural renewal scheme in the last budget my Department has been inundated with requests on behalf of areas seeking inclusion in the scheme. It is the nature of schemes such as the rural and urban renewal schemes and the seaside resort scheme, that there will always be complaints from people who are just outside the boundaries of the designated area. Yet the boundary line must be drawn somewhere, and somebody will always be excluded. Consequently, one will never be in a postion to satisfy everybody. I would stress that this is a pilot initiative and that it is not possible to designate every part of the country. I have no plans to extend the rural renewal scheme beyond the areas already selected.

MainHeading.P: The position with regard to the tax incentives for areas adjacent to airport enterprise areas is that these are subject to the approval of the EU Commission in the context of state aids. Last December, the Commission decided to approve the tax reliefs for existing and some new enterprise areas in the context of state aids but the decision did not cover the regional airports enterprise areas scheme. EU officials have since informed my Department that the rates relief and double rent relief will not be approved by the Commission whenever a submission is made to them seeking EU approval for tax designation at any of the regional airport enterprise areas. However, it is understood at present that there is no objection to the provision of capital allowances. Therefore, when projects for the airports enterprise areas are approved by the Irish authorities and areas are then designated, they will be submitted to the EU Commission for approval in respect of the capital allowances. It should be noted that the business incentives in the rural renewal scheme are also subject to EU approval.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Tax Reliefs.

Qst.Quest: his Department's views on the current exemption of a company (details supplied) from excise duties on imported oil; his views on whether this is equitable and consistent with current EU policy to rationalise and harmonise energy taxes; and if he will provide copies of all correspondence in relation to this matter between the company, the Department of the Environment and Local Government and his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The exemption from the payment of the excise duty on the oil, imported or domestic used in a particular process was agreed prior to this plant locating in Ireland. It was provided for initially in Statutory Instrument No. 126 of 1983. Council Directive 92/510/EEC, having regard to Article 8 (4) of Council Directive 92/81/EEC, authorised the continuation of the exemption without time limit.

The provisions set out in Directive 92/510/EEC were updated in Council Decision 97/425/EC. Article 1 of that decision authorises the further exemption from the payment of the excise duty until 31 December 1999 and for its continuation from exemption to apply automatically for subsequent periods of two years, unless the Council decides unanimously before the end of that period, on a proposal from the Commission, that the exemption should be abolished or modified.

MainHeading.P: At EU level, Ireland stressed the need to retain the exemption in order to help secure employment in energy intensive industry in the EU, against competition from outside the EU, where no tax or very low taxes apply. We also indicated that we would not oppose parallel treatment for any other similar EU industries and there are somewhat similar tax concessions in other EU states for plants of this type. The Deputy will realise that the issue concerns the tax position of an individual company and it would not be usual, in such cases, to publish such correspondence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: the reason it has been decided to reverse Government policy by supporting the IMF's enhanced structural adjustment facility which is a mechanism that is leading to increased hardship for Third World countries.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: In the context of the major debt relief package announced by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and me on 16 September, it is now appropriate for Ireland to honour its proposed contribution to ESAF. Subscription to ESAF would be consistent with and should enhance the attainment of Ireland's wider overseas development co-operation objectives. I accept the need for reform of certain aspects of ESAF programmes and note the positive response of the IMF to the external evaluation of the facility. I will continue to seek to ensure that the lessons learnt from the external review will be brought to bear as regards the planning, design and implementation of ESAF programmes.

Qst.Quest: his views on whether the proposal by the national lottery to increase the minimum cost of playing from £1 to £1.50 is excessive; his further views on whether it may be a prelude to a further increase of the play cost to two euros which equates to £1.60; and if he will request the national lottery to allow people to play a single panel of the lotto at a proportionate cost which would be half the existing minimum cost for two panels.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I recently approved the price increase from £1 to £1.50 of the National Lottery Company's main game, lotto. The increase took effect on 26 September as part of a package for a major relaunch of the game. The main reason for the increase in price — the first such increase since the lotto was introduced ten years ago — is to maintain and enhance the appeal of the game in the light of the increase in price of lotto players' dreams, e.g. the cost of houses. This is not a price increase in the usual sense as prizes have risen in line with lotto charges. All prizes have been increased by 50 per cent and the minimum guaranteed jackpot per draw is now £1 million. A new prize category, “Match 4 Plus Bonus Number” has also been introduced.

The price of a national lottery ticket in euros will not become relevant in practical terms until the year 2002. The exact rate of exchange for the Irish pound will not be determined until 1 January 1999 and the euro will not be in use in cash form until the year 2002.
The requirement to play two panels is an integral part of the design of the lotto game and there are no proposals to alter this at present.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Tax Code.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to address the anomaly whereby lone parents returning to employment are taxed on part of their allowance which up until then was not taxed, in view of the fact that this is a disincentive to taking up employment.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: It is a general principle of taxation that, as far as possible, income from all sources should be subject to taxation. In line with this principle the majority of social welfare payments are, therefore, reckonable as income for tax purposes, including the social welfare lone parent's allowance. Treating such payments as income for tax purposes is essentially a matter of equity.
The apparent anomaly referred to in this question relates to the operation of the tax and social welfare systems.

While the lone parent's allowance has always been taxable it is paid in full by the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs without tax being deducted. The extent, if any, to which taxation will actually arise in a given case will essentially depend on the level of other income that a recipient has in the same tax year. If there is no other income in addition to the social welfare payment, the existing exemption limits and allowances can be expected to ensure that there is no tax to be paid on the social welfare income itself.

Where there is additional income leading to a tax charge, in order to collect the tax due on the allowance, it is necessary to reduce the taxpayer's tax-free allowance by an amount equal to the lone parent's allowance received.

The position with regard to the taxation of lone parents is that a lone parent receives personal tax allowances, i.e. basic personal allowance of £3,150 plus a lone parent allowance of £3,150, which are the equivalent to the personal allowances of a married couple, £6,300.

Lone parents have, like other taxpayers, benefited from the general tax improvements introduced in the 1998 budget e.g. the increase in personal allowances of £250, the increase in the lone parent allowance of £250, the widening of the standard band by £100 and the 2 per cent reduction in both the standard and top income tax rates.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in Dublin 7 who has just returned to employment has a tax free allowance of only £60.77; and if this will be reviewed in view of the fact it appears to be a disincentive to returning to work.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Revenue Commissioners that prior to commencing employment on 17 August the taxpayer was in receipt of unemployment benefit.

MainHeading.P: Unemployment benefit is taxable but is paid by the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs without tax being deducted. In order to collect the tax due on the unemployment benefit, it is necessary to reduce the taxpayer's tax free allowance by an amout equal to the unemployment benefit received. In the case of the taxpayer in question, unemployment benefit of £580.70 was received since 6 April 1998. This is a lesser amount than that shown on the certificate of tax free allowances sent to the taxpayers because the inspector was unaware that the taxpayer did not receive unemployment benefit during the month of May. A revised certificate of tax-free allowances showing the following tax-free allowances is being sent to the taxpayer.
The balance of the taxpayer's income is liable to tax at a rate of 24 per cent.

I would like to point out that it is a general principle of taxation that, as far as possible, income from all sources should be subject to taxation. In line with this principle the majority of social welfare payments, including unemployment benefit are, therefore, reckonable as income for tax purposes. Treating unemployment benefit as income for tax purposes is essentially a matter of equity.

The extent, if any, to which taxation will actually arise in a given case will essentially depend on the level of other income that a recipient or the recipient's spouse has in the same tax year. If there is no other income in addition to the social welfare payment, the existing exemption limits and allowances can be expected to ensure that there is no tax to be paid on the social welfare income itself.

It should also be noted that since unemployment benefit was made reckonable as income for tax purposes in 1994 the method of taxing unemployment benefit has been restructured in order to improve the position of those most adversely affected. To this end a disregard of the first £10 per week of unemployment benefit for income tax purposes has been introduced. To assist families, the child dependant additions payable with unemployment benefit were also exempted from income tax. This has been taken into account in the table already outlined.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Official Travel.

Qst.Quest: the total expenditure by each Government Department with each of the three major airlines in the 12 months ended 31 December 1997; when decisions will be taken in relation to the tendering arrangements for air travel services for civil servants and employees of public state enterprises; if his attention has been drawn to a claim by one particular airline that the Government can save up to £2 million per annum on one such route within Europe; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The information requested is not available in my Department and would have to be sought separately by the Deputy from each Department or office.

MainHeading.P: The tender arrangements for air transport, travel agency, tour operator and tourist assistance services relates to official travel by Government Departments and offices. The evaluation period is six months from the closing date for the receipt of tenders, 17 April 1998. It is expected that final decisions will be taken by the five group tender boards representing the 28 departments and offices engaged in the tender process over the next few weeks.

I am aware of a claim by one airline that they can save up to £2 million per annum on one route within Europe. In relation to air travel generally, all Departments and offices have been informed, in a travel policy statement issued by my Department, that they must ensure that, consistent with the requirements of Departments and offices, the best value for money is obtained and they must be prepared to use the services of all airlines operating out of Ireland.

In addition, all heads of Departments and offices have recently been informed, by my Department, that the operation of these arrangements will be examined annually by external auditors whose reports will be made available to the Comptroller and Auditor General. The purpose of these audits is to ensure that the obligations of both the successful tenderers and the Department and offices themselves in regard to the use of all carriers and achieving value for money, as well as the other requirements of the travel policy statement, are being met effectively.

Qst.Quest: when the scheme in relation to handicapped drivers regarding the provision of free motor tax and duty free petrol will be re-examined in view of the fact that it appears the scheme in its current format is unworkable; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: I do not accept the Deputy's assertion that the Disabled Drivers and Disabled Passengers (Tax Concession) Scheme is unworkable. The scheme, which is governed by the Statutory Instrument Number 353 of 1994, provides substantial benefits to members. These benefits include exemption from the payment of VAT and vehicle registration tax on the purchase of a motor car, exemption from payment of the annual road tax, exemption from the payment of excise duty on motor fuel up to a maximum annual limit of 600 gallons per beneficiary used for the transportation of the disabled person, whether as a driver or as a passenger. The scheme is estimated to cost the Exchequer in the region of £15 million this year. There are, of course, constant demands that these substantial benefits be extended to other categories and individuals not within the scheme. These requests are considered in the context of the budget.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - EU Conventions Ratification.

Qst.Quest: the reasons Ireland has not yet ratified the Council of Europe Convention on Cloning; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: The additional protocol to the European Convention on Human Rights and Biomedicine on the prohibition of the cloning of human beings is only open for signature to those states which have signed the Covention on Human Rights and Biomedicine. Ireland is not a signatory to the convention and we are therefore not in a position to be able to sign the additional protocol. The reason Ireland is not a signatory to the convention is that there are difficulties with some articles which have implications for unused embryos.

MainHeading.P: Ireland is supportive of measures presently being taken at a number of international forums to prohibit the cloning of human beings. In particular, Ireland supported the decision of heads of state and government, meeting at the Second
Summit of the Council of Europe in Strasbourg on 10-11 October 1997 “to prohibit all use of cloning techniques aimed at creating genetically identical human beings”.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he will take to address the serious difficulties which people with a disability have in competing for employment; his views on whether difficulties often arise from prejudice on the part of insufficiently informed employers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: The fundamental aim of social inclusion is clearly stated in the Government programme, An Action Programme for the Millennium. This includes equal opportunities for people with disabilities.

The strategy is carried through in the commitments made in Partnership 2000 and endorsed more recently in Ireland's Employment Action Plan published by the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment in April 1998.

In addition the Employment Equality Act 1998 prohibits discrimination in relation to employment on a number of distinct grounds, including disability. The process of bringing the Act into operation will commence as soon as the new equality infrastructure — the Equality Authority and Office of Equality Investigations — has been put in place; this is scheduled to occur during the first half of 1999.

The Report of the Commission on the Status of People with a Disability which was published in November 1996 also set out a strategy for people with a disability. The Government has made a number of fundamental policy decisions, arising from the Commission's report, which should lead, inter alia, to an increased level of employment and vocational training opportunities for people with disabilities. One key decision is the proposed transfer of responsibility for vocational training and employment for people with disabilities from the Department of
Health and Children to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

Undoubtedly from time to time difficulties will arise from prejudices among uninformed employers and others in society when dealing with persons with a disability. However, the National Rehabilitation Board and other organisations have made considerable inroads into lessening such unwarranted prejudice through various awareness training schemes for employers, which are carried out with the collaboration of employers' organisations.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Higgins (Dublin West) Mr. Higgins (Dublin West)
Qst.Quest: if the Eurostat database and register has released any information about congenital abnormalities in the vicinity of existing or closed rubbish dumps and landfills.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I presume the Deputy is referring to “EUROCAT” which is an EU project for the epidemiologic surveillance of congenital anomalies. It has operated in Ireland since 1979 and covers the Eastern Health Board region and Galway County. More recently, EUROCAT has been extended to the Southern Health Board and will also soon become operational in the North-Eastern Health Board. The EUROCAT system is managed by the Department of Public Health at the Eastern Health Board.

A project to measure the risk of congenital anomalies near hazardous-waste landfill sites in Europe, the EUROHAZCON study, has recently been completed. The study was based on EUROCAT data from five countries. Ireland was not a participant. The reason Ireland was not included in the study was that none of the landfill sites met the definition of “toxic waste dump” specified in the project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Long-stay and Respite Care.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that there are no long-stay or respite beds available on Dublin's northside for persons with a physical disability; and if he will make provision for the development of this facility in view of the substantial waiting lists which exist in the Eastern Health Board.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: Long stay and respite care facilities for people with physical disabilities are provided in the Eastern Health Board area by the board and through grant aided voluntary organisations. The board currently provides long stay facilities at Cherry Orchard Hospital, 22 beds, Cuan Aoibheann, Phoenix Park, 46 beds and Peamount Hospital, Newcastle, 25 beds. Respite beds are provided at Cherry Orchard Hospital, 2 and the M.S. Care Centre provides eight respite places in Bushy Park, Rathgar. There are five Cheshire Homes in the Eastern Health Board region providing long stay and respite care for more than 100 persons with physical disabilities. These facilities accept referrals from all areas of the Eastern Health Board's jurisdiction.

The provision of respite care has been identified in the report of the Review Group “Towards an Independent Future” as one of the priority areas for development in services for people with physical and sensory disabilities. Priorities for the allocation of funding available for the development of these services are decided by the health boards in consultation with the local co-ordinating committees for services to people with physical and sensory disabilities. The voluntary agencies providing services in this sector are represented on these co-ordinating committees.

The Eastern Health Board was allocated £1.080 million for the development of physical and sensory disability services in its functional area in 1998. I understand that the board, in consultation with its local co-ordinating committee, has decided to allocate £200,000 of this funding towards the provision of long-stay and respite bed facilities for people with physical and sensory disabilities in its catchment area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Teenage Pregnancies.

Qst.Quest: whether there has been a consistent increase in the number of teenage pregnancies in Ireland in recent years; his views in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

his views on the weight of evidence which suggests that providing sex and contraceptive education to teenagers does not lead to an increase in sexual activity or to an increase in the incidence of pregnancy among teenagers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if his attention has been drawn to a discussion document drawn up by a public health specialist in the South-Eastern Health Board area which suggests that strategies to counter teenage pregnancies based on abstinence have not been found to delay sexual activity or to reduce the number of pregnancies among teenagers; his views on whether, in view of this finding, the costs of providing contraceptive and counselling services to young people would be less than the costs currently incurred by the health and social services in dealing with unplanned pregnancies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 441, 444 and 445 together.

The number of births to teenage mothers has not increased consistently in recent years. However, the proportion of births which are to teenage mothers has grown. The following table illustrates the position during the period 1987-97:

row.entry: Births to under-20s as % of total births

MainHeading.P: * Provisional figures.

I am aware of the discussion document prepared by the Department of Public Health of the South-Eastern Health Board and to which the Deputy refers. International evidence shows that the provision of sexuality and contraceptive education does not lead to an increase in the incidence of pregnancy among teenagers. Irish policy in this regard is to provide appropriate sexuality and relationships education so as to encourage responsible decision-making by teenagers. My Department's Health Promotion Unit assisted the Department of Education and Science in the preparation of the Relationships and Sexuality Education Programme, which was introduced into both primary and second level schools in 1997.

It is not possible to quantify the cost to the health and social services of dealing with unplanned pregnancies. Health boards, voluntary agencies and general practitioners provide a range of family planning and counselling services. My Department has provided significant additional funding in recent years to enable these services to be developed. Family planning services are available as part of the General Medical Service and, in addition to the provision of education and advice, a range of contraceptives may be provided. Following the publication of the “Women and Crisis Pregnancy” study earlier this year, my Department requested the health boards to review the adequacy of the family planning pregnancy counselling services in their areas, having regard to the study's findings, and to indicate what further service developments they may consider appropriate.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I am aware from reports of scientific reseach being carried out by this biotechnology company in the field of xenotransplantation. I understand that international research into xenotransplantation has been ongoing for some years and has concentrated on the development of transgenic animals, primarily pigs with human genes, and on measures to combat the risk of infection and organ rejection. Clinical interest in this option has been prompted mainly because of the shortage of human donor organs worldwide.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Antibiotic Resistant Infections.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the measures that are in place to counter the threat to the health of hospital patients caused by the virus known as MRSA; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if his Department is routinely notified about incidences of antibiotic resistant infections in hospitals and about deaths attributed to such infections; if this information is made available; and the number of incidences of such infections and the number of deaths caused in 1997.
his views on the incidence of antibiotic resistant infections, including those known as MRSA, in hospitals; and the measures proposed to combat this danger to patients undergoing surgery.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 449, 476 and 477 together.

MainHeading.P: My Department has taken steps to ensure that all necessary measures are taken to control and reduce the prevalance of MRSA and I am glad to inform the Deputies that significant measures have been taken in this area. In September 1993 a committee on the control of MRSA comprising representatives from the Department of Health and Children, Consultant Microbiologists, Specialists in Public Health Medicine, General Practice, and the Infection Control Nurses Association was established to identify the extent to which MRSA was a problem in the Irish health system and to establish priorities for its control. The committee recommended a comprehensive set of guidelines covering procedures for the management of MRSA in acute hospitals and other health care settings. The committee also produced guidelines and information for patients and health care staff. The guidelines were published in 1995.

These national guidelines were endorsed by a wide range of professional bodies involved in the control of MRSA and were widely circulated throughout the country. The guidelines are an important step in promoting awareness of MRSA and the measures for its control and will ensure an even safer environment for the care of the sick both in the community and in hospital, including persons undergoing surgery.

A study of the prevalence of MRSA in Irish hospitals was carried out on behalf of the committee on the control of MRSA and I am committed to ensuring that future trends in the prevalence of MRSA will be closely monitored and, in this regard a follow up national survey on MRSA is currently being planned by the Eastern Health Board and will take place in early 1999. I am pleased to inform the Deputies that a national disease surveillance unit is currently being established. This unit will build on the reporting systems which have been developed in some regions and will assist in the control of all communicable diseases, including hospital acquired infections such as MRSA.

The EU Council of Health Ministers, on 20 July 1998, adopted a proposal at EU level which seeks to create a network for surveillance and control of communicable diseases in the European Community. The network will operate through a system of close co-operation and effective co-ordination between member states. The disease categories to be covered by the proposed network includes hospital acquired infections of which MRSA is one.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - National Alcohol Policy.

Qst.Quest: whether his Department has a policy of seeking to dissuade people from the excessive use of alcohol or to promote moderation in terms of alcohol intake; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: The National Alcohol Policy was launched in September 1996. The main thrust of the policy is directed at reducing the prevalence of alcohol related problems through an emphasis on moderation in alcohol consumption. Because alcohol problems are multidimensional the policy sets out multisectoral solutions requiring both environmental and individual strategies.

MainHeading.P: Since the publication of the policy, a number of elements of the action plan have been put in place. The most significant of these are: the National Alcohol Surveillance Project has been established; a national lifestyle survey is being undertaken which includes items on alcohol consumption and alcohol related problems; a National Alcohol Awareness Campaign was launched on 20 April 1998. The overall message of the campaign is “Control your drinking before it controls you”. The campaign materials consist of four posters and two radio messages which are designed to make people think about their drinking habits. The campaign ran for an initial period of three weeks and the second phase is currently in operation.

Work is ongoing on a number of the longer term elements of the action plan, including: developing the school curriculum to include a significant level of health education, based on a lifeskills approach; development of policies in relation to health promoting schools, hospitals, workplaces and campuses which would include policies in relation to alcohol use; discussions with the drinks industry on their response to the policy, with particular emphasis on the development of server training programmes.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Child Care Services.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to introduce legislation in relation to the provision of proper advice, training and supports to child care workers, the establishment of a register of qualified child care workers, the provision for inspections in respect of premises where children are cared for away from their own homes and the extension of the present scheme being drawn up by health boards to police pre-school facilities to include childminders, having regarding to the comments of a person (details supplied); and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey) Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey)
Speaker.P: Pursuant to Part VII of the Child Care Act, 1991, the Childcare (Pre-School Services) Regulations, 1996 were introduced by my Department. The purpose of the regulations is to build on the existing good standards in our pre-school services and gradually improve standards throughout the sector to secure the health, safety and welfare of pre-school children and to promote the development of children attending pre-school services.

These regulations apply to pre-schools, play groups, day nurseries, cre ches, childminders looking after more than three children and other similar services, which cater for children under six years of age. The regulations require pre-school providers to notify their local health board that they are carrying on or proposing to carry on a pre-school service. Subsequent to receiving a notification the health board provides relevant information to the applicant and will make arrangements for an inspection to be carried out by an authorising person. In view of the large numbers involved health boards have until mid 1999 to complete the first inspection of all the pre-school services concerned.

MainHeading.P: The Expert Working Group on Childcare, established under Partnership 2000 to devise a national framework for the development of the childcare sector, is considering the issues raised by the Deputy in relation to the regulation of the childcare and childminding industry and will be making recommendations in the matter. The expert group, under the auspices of the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform is expected to issue its report in December, 1998. In addition, it is intended to review the Childcare (Pre-School Services) Regulations, 1996 after three years, with a view to effecting any change considered necessary at that stage. I have no plans at present to introduce changes to the existing legal framework pending the outcome of these reviews.

I might add, that the question of establishing a system of statutory registration for designated health and social professions has been under consideration by my Department for some time. The groups concerned are physiotherapists, social workers, radiographers, chiropodists, childcare workers, speech and language therapists, occupational therapists, dieticians, environmental health officers, medical laboratory technicians and psychologists. However, despite various initiatives over recent years, great difficulties still remain in devising a scheme which would meet all the requirements of the various professions and which would provide for a system of self-financing self-regulation. This issue is once again being examined within my Department at present, with other models for statutory registration being investigated in an effort to overcome the difficulties in question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Medicinal Products Regulations.

Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to reports linking the prescription drug Roaccutane with depression, which in one case led to a suicide; if he has any proposals to limit or qualify the availability of this particular drug or of other pharmacological preparations based on the same ingredients; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I am aware of recent reports suggesting possible linkages betweeen the product Roaccutane and depression.

Roaccutane (isotretinoin) in a vitamin A derivative used in the treatment of acne. In Ireland, it is authorised by the Irish Medicines Board for the treatment of severe acne, unresponsive to other treatments. Its availability is limited in that it must be prescribed and its use monitored by a specialist dermatologist.

MainHeading.P: The Irish Medicines Board has, on an ongoing basis, been actively monitoring data on Roaccutane which it has reviewed both internally with experts and with the other European regulatory agencies. In addition, the board has also recently reviewed the terms of the product authorisation with the company. As a result of this, revised wording for inclusion in the prescribing information for the product, outlining the current position regarding its use and warnings related to the possible development of psychiatric reactions were agreed. The warnings refer to possible side effects including depression, pyschotic symptoms and of rare reports of suicide associated with Roaccutane.

The revised warnings have been incorporated into the authorisation documents for the product and the company has circularised all physicians and pharmacists outlining the new warnings regarding the use of Roaccutane.

As with all medicines, it is important that patients should read carefully any information and follow any instructions provided with the medication and consult with their physicians in relation to any problems, side effects or uncertainties they may encounter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Care of the Disabled.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the steps that are in hand in his Department to advance the desegregation of services to people with a disability and in particular to address the serious shortage of residential care places for people being cared for by elderly frail parents; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I assume by the “desegregation of services to people with disabilities” the Deputy is referring to the Government's decision of 27 July 1998 to reorganise institutional responsibility for the delivery of certain services for people with a disability.

That decision followed on from the consideration and acceptance of the recommendations contained in the report “Building a Future Together” which was prepared by the Establishment Group for the National Disability Authority and Disability Support Service. The Establishment Group, or Inter-Departmental Committee, is under the aegis of the Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform.

MainHeading.P: The Government agreed to the continuation of the Establishment Group to carry out the task of implementing the report and that work is ongoing. My Department will continue to participate fully in the work of the group which involves the collaboration of other relevant Government Departments and State agencies.

I am conscious of the concerns of parents in relation to the provision of additional residential services to meet the needs of those who have been assessed as requiring these services. This is particularly the case in relation to persons with a mental handicap. The availability of detailed information from the National Intellectual Disability Database, which was launched last year, enabled my Department to publish in 1997, for the first time, a comprehensive assessment of the current and future needs of persons with a mental handicap. This report, An Assessment of Need for Services to Persons with a Mental Handicap 1997-2001, shows that there are now more adults with a mental handicap than at any other time in our history and that there is an ageing population in the more severe range of disability. This has major implications for service planning and will, in particular, mean increased pressure on residential services for this age group.

The Government is committed to meeting the needs which have been identified in the Assessment of Need over the period in question. Within the last twelve months, I have made additional funding amounting to £25 million available to the services to assist in meeting these needs. This included the first phase of a four year national £30 million capital programme for the services which I put in place late last year and which will run in tandem with the development of services as outlined in the Assessment of Need.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Mental Health Legislation.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to provide in the forthcoming mental health Bill or otherwise for the making of advance directives whereby individuals may provide for health care decisions to be made on their behalf by a nominated person in the event of the incapacitation of the nominator; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the proposals, if any, he has to consult with medical professionals, affected families and other interested parties in advance of the publication of the mental health Bill to clarify the provision in that Bill for circumstances where a patient cannot consent to treatment but where a doctor or the family concerned may be anxious that treatment be afforded; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 466 and 467 together.

MainHeading.P: A comprehensive process of consultation with all interested parties relating to the proposed content of new mental health legislation began with the publication of the Green Paper on Mental Health in June 1992. The Green Paper contained proposals relating to a patient's capacity to consent to treatment including circumstances where a patient is unable or unwilling to give such consent but, based on clinical advice, treatment may be necessary in the interests of the patient. The consent to treatment proposals, which will be contained in the new mental health Bill, have been drafted following widespread consultations with interested parties and will be broadly based on proposals contained in the White Paper, “A New Mental Health Act”, published in July 1995. The measures which I intend to incorporate in new legislation will be designed to ensure that patients who are incapable of expressing consent in such circumstances receive necessary treatment while at the same time have their interests fully protected. The making of health care decisions by a nominated person on behalf of an incapacitated person has complex medico-legal implications and the provisions of the mental health Bill which I have outlined above should adequately protect the interests of such persons. It is my intention to publish this Bill at the earliest possible date.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Complementary Medicines and Therapies.

Qst.Quest: the changes, if any, he proposes to make to the general medical services scheme to make complementary medicines and therapies more widely available to medical card holders; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will itemise those complementary and homeopathic therapies, not involving the prescription of pharmaceutical preparations, which are available to medical card holders; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 468 and 469 together.

In accordance with the Health Act, 1970, health boards are required, under the general medical services scheme to provide, without charge, general practitioner services, drugs, medicines and appliances to persons with full eligibility i.e. medical card holders.

Under the GMS scheme, general practitioner services are provided by doctors who are registered with the Medical Council under the statutory provisions of the Medical Practitioner Act, 1978, while drugs and medicines are dispensed by pharmacists registered with the Pharmaceutical Society of Ireland under the provisions of the Pharmacy Acts, 1875 to 1977.

MainHeading.P: Drugs and medicines which are considered necessary for any persons receiving services under the scheme must be examined and accredited by the Irish Medicines Board and covered by a current product authorisation. The granting of such an authorisation ensures that the medicinal products concerned have satisfied certain minimum standards regarding their quality, safety and efficacy before they are placed on the market. The position is that complementary and homeopathic therapies are not the subject of such authorisations. Accordingly, the minimum standards of quality, safety and efficacy have not been established for these products.
The position, therefore, remains that complementary and homeopathic therapies are not eligible for reimbursement under the GMS scheme and I have no plans to change the current arrangements in place.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the prevalence of skin cancers among the population generally; if he will outline the measures that are in place, by way of public education or otherwise, to address this significant public health issue; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I am very much aware of the prevalence of skin cancers in this country. Skin cancers are the most common form of cancer in Ireland today and my Department is actively involved in promoting greater awareness of this disease.

The health promotion unit of my Department works closely with the European Commission and the Irish Cancer Society on the Europe Against Cancer Week campaign each year. This is a European wide campaign which elaborates upon the ten point European Code Against Cancer by focusing on a single element of that code each year and concentrating effort on that area in particular. In 1996 the campaign focused on skin cancers and for that campaign the Health Promotion Unit, in association with the Irish Cancer Society and the European Commission, produced a wide range of materials related to skin cancer which were disseminated nationally.

The Health Promotion Unit has also provided support and funding for an awareness campaign by the Construction Employees Health Trust —“Keep Your Shirt On”— which outlined the dangers of over exposure to the sun and addressed the particular concerns of skin cancer for those working in the construction industry.

The Health Promotion Unit also produces and disseminates nationally a skin cancer prevention leaflet entitled “The Sun Seekers Guide to Health”. In addition the Health Promotion Unit continues to support the work of the Irish Cancer Society which produces a range of information materials on skin cancers including leaflets designed to highlight the dangers for particular groups including families and agricultural workers. This year the focus of the Irish Cancer Society's skin cancer awareness campaign is on people involved in sport.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Dr. Moffatt) Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Dr. Moffatt)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Dr. Moffatt)
Speaker.P: The Health (Nursing Homes) Act, 1990 gives powers to the health boards to enforce high standards of accommodation and care in nursing homes. The Act also introduced a new system of nursing home subventions, so that dependent people most in need of nursing care would have access to such care. if, because of lack of resources in the area, the Eastern Health Board currently has a waiting time of over 18 months for the assessment of couples for suitability to adopt abroad; the proposals, if any, he has to meet the resource needs in this area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the proposals, if any, he has to co-ordinate the assessment and vetting of procedures of the Adoption Board and the various health boards in relation to assessing the suitability of a couple to adopt abroad, particularly regarding second and subsequent adoptions; his views on whether the current administrative processes, which are cumbersome and involve considerable duplication, are appropriate; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey) Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Health and Children (Mr. Fahey)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 501, 502, 503 and 504 together.

The Adoption Act, 1991 imposed a statutory duty on health boards to carry out, as soon as practicable, assessments for foreign adoptions. In carrying out this function, the boards must have regard to the competing demands in other areas of the child care services, particularly in relation to the protection of children from abuse and neglect, which takes priority over all other work. Under the Act, it is also open to an applicant to request a registered adoption society to carry out an assessment. However, there is no obligation on a registered adoption society to carry out such an assessment.

I am aware that there are different timescales for the completion of the assessment process in the different health boards. This difference arises principally from the greater volume of applications in some areas, particularly in the Eastern Health Board. Arising from the additional funding approved to the Eastern Health Board for child care services in 1998 the board has appointed three new social workers to its adoption service. This will facilitate a speedier assessment of applicants who wish to adopt children abroad. I understand that the current waiting time prior to assessment in the Eastern Health Board is nine months: a reduction of five months on 1997.

My Department does not hold information on the average number of hours it takes to carry out assessments in each health board area and has not issued guidelines to health boards concerning the assessment process. However, as regards second assessments, I would point out that while such assessments may not take as long as a first assessment there are a number of additional matters, including the progress of the first adoption, which must be taken into account and they cannot simply be considered an addendum to a previous assessment.

MainHeading.P: I have received a large volume of representations concerning both delays in commencing assessments and perceived differences between health boards in the assessment process itself. I am not convinced that simply assigning more social workers to deal with an ever expanding case load is the most efficient way of dealing with this situation particularly when one considers the other areas of pressing need in our child care services. It is also necessary to consider how health boards can best utilise existing resources to manage cases and whether or not legislative change is required to assist them in this regard. I have therefore decided to commission an independent consultancy to review the foreign adoption assessment procedures in the eight health boards with the aim of ensuring that an efficient and standardised assessment procedure which accords with best practice in the field operates across the country while at the same time having regard to the priority that must be attached to other areas of the child care services. The terms of reference of the consultancy are as follows: (i) to review the current assessment procedures in health boards in consultation with relevant interests — this review should encompass both social work practice and service management; (ii) to provide an overview of the current assessment procedures in health boards which identifies any particular issues which need to be addressed; (iii) to propose a standardised framework for the carrying out of future assessments which accords with best practice in the field and delivers the service in the most efficient and sensitive manner possible. Within this standardised framework, health boards should be able to exercise a degree of flexibility in the management of the service and in the detail of its delivery so that they can adapt it to the particular circumstances prevailing in their functional area; (iv) to estimate the resource implications (on current application rates for assessment) of this proposed standardised framework (this estimate to include staffing levels, management and administrative requirements etc.). The feasibility of introducing charges for assessments should also be examined in this context and (v) to highlight any areas in which legislative or administrative change would improve the quality of the assessment process.

I have set up a small advisory committee comprising representatives of my Department, the health boards, the Adoption Board and the Council of Irish Adoption Agencies to oversee this consultancy. This committee held its first meeting yesterday, Tuesday 29 September, and it is intended to put the consultancy out to tender within the next week. Any proposals for legislative change arising from the consultancy will be considered in the context of the Bill to ratify the Hague Covention on the Protection of Children and Co-operation in Respect of Intercountry Adoption, 1993, which is currently being prepared in my Department.

As an additional measure to tackle delays in commencing assessments I am at present exploring the legal position and the feasibility of one or more registered adoption societies carrying out assessments on the basis that the costs of these assessments will be borne by the applicants.
