MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Psychiatric Nursing.

Qst.Quest: the reason no student nurses from this year's intake have been allocated to the psychiatric nursing school at Waterford Institute of Technology; the schools of psychiatric nursing that students have been allocated to; the criteria used for selecting these centres; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he will designate the school of psychiatric nursing, Waterford Institute of Technology, as the pilot school for psychiatric post-graduate nursing studies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 514 and 515 together.

MainHeading.P: I wish to inform the Deputy that an insufficient number of applicants for the 1998 psychiatric nursing registration-diploma programme who successfully came through the selection processes of the Nursing Applications Centre accepted offers of places at the schools of psychiatric nursing in the Mid-Western, North-Western and South-Eastern Health Boards. The number of acceptances for each of the three schools was, in fact, in single figures. To proceed with the programme this year in the three schools would, therefore, not have been viable.

In all the circumstances, my Department was left with no alternative but to shelve plans for an intake of psychiatric nursing students to the three schools in the current year. I would stress that this decision was not taken lightly and that I share the deep disappointment of the nursing personnel involved in the schools who put so much work into preparing for the programme.

The immediate concern was to try to find alternative places for the 20 applicants who had accepted places at the three schools. Each of them was notified by the Nursing Applications Centre of the situation and offered a place in any of the other schools of psychiatric nursing that will be providing the registration/diploma programme to first year psychiatric nursing students this year. These schools are operated by the Eastern, Southern and Western Health Boards, St. John of God Hospital, Dublin, St. Patrick's Hospital, Dublin, and St. Vincent's Hospital, Fairview, Dublin.

The approved 1998 intake for the South-Eastern Health Board school of psychiatric nursing was 25 students. In the event, the school would only have had a class of eight first year nursing students. Seven of the eight applicants affected have opted to avail of training places at the following schools: Southern Health Board (3), St. Patrick's Hospital (2), Eastern Health Board (1) and St. John of God Hospital (1). The other applicant has been granted a deferral of the offer of a place on the programme until next year.

I would like to clarify that none of the three schools concerned has been closed. The actual position is that they are not proceeding with an intake of first year nursing students in the current year. It would be my firm intention that training places in the three schools would be advertised next year as part of the arrangements for the 1999 intake of students to the psychiatric nursing registration/diploma programme.

In the meantime, in the light of the disappointing uptake of places in psychiatric nursing training this year, my Department is examining the feasibility of putting in place a post-graduate training programme in the spring of 1999. The question of the South-Eastern Health Board School providing such a programme will fall to be considered in that context.
I might add that my Department is arranging to meet representatives of all of the schools of psychiatric nursing next month to review this year's recruitment process.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the entitlements of a person in long-term care in a health board institution for pocket money to meet their personal needs; the procedure in place for processing claims for this payment; and when this system and the payment were last reviewed to ensure that they are meeting the needs of patients.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: Patients' private property is the term used to describe an allowance granted by health boards to patients in long-term care. This allowance, in a majority of cases, is the residual amount of patients' incomes, derived mainly from old age pensions, after deductions by the health boards of hospital maintenance charges. These charges are governed by the Institutional Assistance Regulations 1954 and 1965 and the Health (Charges for In-Patient Services) Regulations 1976 and 1987. The charge under the regulations is set out in the 1976 regulations at a rate not exceeding the income of the person, less a sum of £2.50 a week or less such larger sum as may be determined by the chief executive officer of the appropriate health board having regard to the circumstances of the case.
The amount of the allowance payable to individual patients is determined on the basis of an assessment of needs which is undertaken periodically in respect of each individual patient.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: his policy in relation to the right of learner drivers to drive without the supervision of a qualified or experienced driver; the plans, if any, the Government has to change the law in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: Under regulations in operation since 1989 all provisional licence holders, with the exception of those who hold: (a) a second provisional licence in respect of category B vehicles (cars); or (b) a provisional licence to drive vehicles in categories A1, A or W (motorcycles or tractors-work vehicles), must be accompanied by a qualified driver while driving. A qualified driver is a person who holds a full driving licence in respect of the vehicle category being driven.

The recently published Government Strategy for Road Safety 1998-2002 has prioritised action against speeding, alcohol and non-seatbelt wearing as having the greatest and most immediate potential to achieve the gains in road safety targeted by the strategy. In addition, the new strategy proposes a range of measures designed to improve the formation and training of drivers. These include assisting the Driver Instructor Register towards quality certification; the introduction of a theory test separate from the driving test; the possibility of a new training initiative for motor cyclists and a longer term significant reduction in the number of drivers relying on a provisional licence.

By giving advance notice of the polling day at these elections greater awareness of next year's elections has been generated. I also intend to publicise the facility of the supplement to the register of electors whereby people can make late applications up to mid-May 1999 to be registered to vote at the June 1999 elections.

Under electoral law it is the responsibility of the returning officer to select the buildings to be used as polling stations at an election or referendum. In selecting polling stations they endeavour to use buildings which provide reasonable facilities to enable persons to exercise their right to vote. It would be a matter for individual returning officers to decide whether a shopping centre would be a suitable location as a polling station having regard to all the local circumstances involved.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: Article 16.1.2º of the Constitution provides that all Irish citizens and such other persons in the State as may be determined by law shall have the right to vote at Dáil elections. Section 8 of the Electoral Act, 1992, extends the right to vote at Dáil elections to resident British citizens. It also provides for extending Dáil franchise to nationals of other EU member states on a reciprocal basis. The United Kingdom is the only member state which has extended the right to vote at parliamentary elections to resident Irish citizens. As there have been no approaches by any other member state expressing an interest in having reciprocal voting rights with Ireland, I do not propose to initiate discussions with other member states on the matter.

In accordance with the provisions of Part V of the Local Government Act, 1991, which was brought into operation in 1996, it is open at any time to an individual local authority to adopt a proposal to alter its boundary for administrative purposes. Such a proposal must specify the boundary proposed which could be in accordance with the 1994 electoral revisions or otherwise. I have not received an application in this respect in relation to the Borough of Kilkenny.

MainHeading.P: With regard to town boundary alterations generally the report of the Reorganisation Commission “Towards cohesive local government — town and county” pointed to the implications cumulatively of a major programme of such alterations given the complex financial and other interrelationships between county and town authorities; and the need, inter alia, to avoid increased costs for the public either locally or nationally arising from such organisational change.

At present a Bill is being prepared in my Department which will provide a modern comprehensive legislative framework for the local government system and address, inter alia, some of the interrelationships and other issues involved and provide a new context within which the question of local authority boundary alterations can be considered.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the total number of residential dwellings repossessed by lending institutions in 1997 and in each of the three previous years; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The overall trend in repossessions has declined in recent years. Data published by the Irish Mortgage and Savings Association — which represents the main lending institutions other than the retail banking sector — shows the number of repossessions as 215 in 1994, 193 in 1995, 178 in 1996 and 143 in 1997. These figures include both residential and commercial properties and also properties which have been surrendered voluntarily or abandoned by the borrower. Accordingly, the number of residential dwellings actually repossessed would have been lower.

The Irish Bankers Federation, which represents the retail banking sector, have indicated that during the five year period 1990-94 the number of properties repossessed by its member institutions was 18. It is understood that the federation have not formally compiled statistics on repossessions since 1994 because the information it receives from its members indicates the repossession level has reduced even further since then.

Speaker.P: The management, maintenance and improvement of their existing dwellings, including the installation of central heating, is the responsibility of local authorities to be defrayed from their own resources. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Road Traffic Offences.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to introduce a penalty points system, fixed penalty tickets and unlimited fines for road traffic offences; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to increase the use of on-the-spot fines in relation to traffic offences; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 543 and 544 together.

MainHeading.P: The Government Strategy for Road Safety, 1998-2002 sets out ambitious targets for improved road safety performance. The strategy also sets out key new policies and actions in support of these targets, including the extension of on-the-spot fines to a number of additional road traffic offences and the development of a penalty points system which would trigger disqualification from driving following repeated driving offences.
The preparation of the regulations necessary for the extension of the on-the-spot fine system is already in hand in my Department with a view to making them shortly.

The development of a penalty points system is a more complex task. Its design will need careful consideration in Irish circumstances because of the exclusive constitutional role of the courts in the administration of justice. New primary legislation will be needed and this will involve examining the scope of the infractions to be covered by the system, as well as the mechanisms whereby thresholds will be triggered for the courts to consider the imposition of a driving disqualification.
I have no immediate proposals to amend the fines applicable for road traffic offences; some of these have been recently reviewed by the Oireachtas in the context of the Road Traffic Act, 1994.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Planning Information.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to bring access to information on planning matters in line with the less restrictive regime applying to information requesters under the Freedom of Information Act, 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to bring access to files and registers on planning matters into line with the less restrictive regime applying to information requesters under the Freedom of Information Act, 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 545 and 554 together.

The Freedom of Information Act, 1997, will apply to local authorities from 21 October this year. The provisions of the Freedom of Information Act will apply to information where access is not already provided for by other legislation. Therefore, where information concerning planning matters is not already accessible the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act will apply to such information.

It should be noted that the planning and development code provides very open access to planning files and registers. The planning register must be available for inspection during office hours and copies may be taken of any entries in the register on payment of the prescribed fee.

MainHeading.P: Save in the case of a refusal on a planning application, planning application files held by a planning authority must be made readily available for inspection to the general public for five years after the decision has been made. The planning application and any submissions made in respect of the application must also be available for inspection while the application is being considered by the planning authority. Internal planning authority reports are not made available for inspection until after the application has been determined. Where an application has been refused the file must be made available for inspection for one month after the decision. However, planning authorities would generally facilitate access after that period. My Department has also requested by circular letter that planning authorities should make available to the public copies of documents held on a planning application file — other than plans, drawings or photographs.
An Bord Pleanála planning appeal files must also be made available for inspection, and copies may be taken of such files, from the third working day after the board's decision.

In effect the above access to planning files represents a more ready form of access than is available under the Freedom of Information Act, which envisages a formal written procedure and a one month period for the provision of information. The provisions regarding the availability of documents under the planning code are being considered as part of the current review of planning legislation.

In addition to the above, any person may make a request under the Access to Environmental Information Regulations in respect of information in relation to the environment. The provisions of these regulations could also be of relevance in the cases of planning matters.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if 30 per cent of Irish carbon dioxide, CO2, emissions have their sources in domestic heating arrangements; the policy proposals, if any, currently being considered by his Department to address this phenomenon in view of the Government's commitment to generally contain CO2 emissions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: whether his Department is on schedule to meet the national objective of limiting growth in carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases to 15 per cent above 1990 levels by 2010; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: whether his Department is pursuing measures to effect the limitation and reduction of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions in Ireland; if so, whether these measures are sufficient to meet the various targets that have been laid down in this area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that the National Roads Needs Study, which argues that the road network needs to be improved in order to cater for projected demand, is compatible with the analysis and recommendations of a study (details supplied) into greenhouse gas abatement in relation to transport, which explicitly points out that increasing capacity generates additional demand for road transportation; if he will outline his Department's response to both studies on this question; and if he will make a statement confirming his intention to follow the recommendations on the reduction of greenhouse gases.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 547, 562, 564 and 580 together.

The Kyoto Protocol to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change sets a legally binding target for the European Community and its member states to reduce, as a whole, their emissions of a basket of six greenhouse gases together — carbon dioxide (CO2), methane (CH4), nitrous oxide (N2O), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), perfluorocarbons (PFCs) and sulphur hexafluoride (SF6) — by 8 per cent below 1990 levels in the period 2008-2012. As part of the agreed contribution of member states towards this reduction target, Ireland is committed to limiting the increase in net emissions of the basket of gases to 13 per cent above 1990 levels in the period 2008-2012.

With a view to identifying and putting in place the necessary policies and measures to ensure that Ireland meets its commitments under the Protocol, I have announced the preparation of a national greenhouse gas abatement strategy, to be approved by Government after widespread consultation, to address all gases referred to in the Kyoto Protocol and all relevant sectors of the economy including the agricultural, commercial, energy, industry, residential and transport sectors. As part of the preparation for development of this strategy, a consultancy report on the “Limitation and Reduction of CO2 and Other Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Ireland” was jointly published last June by my Department and the Department of Public Enterprise. This examined a broad range of possible policies and measures in all sectors and for all gases.
Existing policies and measurements put in place to meet commitments under the FCCC are set out in “Ireland's Second National Communication” under the convention.

MainHeading.P: Official greenhouse gas inventories, which are compiled by the Environmental Protection Agency in accordance with the guidelines set out by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change and endorsed by the Conference of the Parties to the FCCC, do not disaggregate data to show specific emissions from domestic heating. The inventories indicate that approximately one-quarter of CO2 emissions results directly from fuel consumption in the residential, commercial and institutional sector, when emissions related to electricity generation are compiled separately under the energy and transformation sector. However, the above-mentioned consultancy report estimated that if emissions associated with electricity generation consumed by the residential sector are included with emissions related to fuels directly used in the residential sector, then emissions from this sector would correspond to 30 per cent of national CO2 emissions. There are insufficient data to suggest that this level of emissions results solely from domestic heating arrangements as emissions associated, for example, with the use of appliances such as refrigeration, lighting, hot water, and cooking are also included.

Since the introduction of the Building Regulations in 1992, energy use in new buildings has been reduced by an estimated 20 per cent, resulting in a 2 per cent reduction of CO2 emissions by the year 2000. In December 1997, I launched a revised and upgraded building control package which included a set of 12 revised technical guidance documents. This revised package will result in an energy saving in space heating estimated at up to 10 per cent. Work has also commenced in my Department on the next review of Part L — Conservation of Fuel and Energy to take account of Ireland's obligations under the Kyoto Protocol. The above-mentioned consultancy report also specifically identifies a number of possible policies and measures in the residential sector for consideration in the context of the development of the national strategy referred to above.

The National Roads Needs Study, published by the National Roads Authority last July, is a detailed assessment of the current condition of the national road network and of the work which remains to be done to complete the network. The study recognises that, in developing the network, full account will have to be taken of environmental sustainability. The study on the Limitation and Reduction of CO2 and Other Greenhouse Gas Emissions in Ireland recognises the economic importance of an improved national road network and analyses a number of specific measures towards the minimisation of the long-term trend towards increased emissions of greenhouse gas from the transport sector. Elaboration of the national strategy will involve appropriate actions in the transport sector as well as all other relevant sectors.
Copies of the consultancy studies and the Second National Communication referred to are available in the Library.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he can confirm that there are some 750,000 houses in the country which were built before the implementation of building regulations and which, to date, have not been audited in terms of their energy usage; his views on whether there is likely to be significant wasteful energy costs incurred on this account; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: My Department estimates that about 1 million of the current housing stock of 1.2 million dwellings were built prior to 1 June 1992 when the Building Regulations, 1991, came into operation.

Last December, I published revised technical guidance on the consolidated Building Regulations, 1997. The revised technical guidance provides for voluntary energy rating of new houses. Energy rating calculations will be faciliated by a software package developed for the design professions by UCD, on a consultancy basis for the Irish Energy Centre.

My hope would be that developers would highlight the energy rating in marketing new houses; and that house purchasers would take these ratings into account when selecting the house of their choice. I have publicly signalled that I intend to consider making energy rating of new houses mandatory, within the next five years, in the light of practical experience with the voluntary system.

The poor energy conservation standards of existing buildings, including houses, is a major problem throughout the EU and one for which there is no easy solution. It is primarily for the owners of buildings to commission energy audits of their property; and to take remedial action in the light of the results. In April 1996, my Department requested local authorities to give greater priority to the need to improve energy efficiency in their existing stock of about 100,000 rented dwellings.

Ireland must limit the increase in greenhouse gas emissions to 13 per cent above 1990 levels by the period 2008-2012 in accordance with the Kyoto Protocol. As part of the development of a national greenhouse gas abatement strategy, a consultancy report examining possible policies and measures was jointly published by the Departments of the Environment and Local Government and Public Enterprise and a public consultation process launched. This report examined a range of policies and measures in, inter alia, the residential sector — including policies that could be applied to the existing housing stock to improve energy conservation. These measures will be considered as part of the consultative process in the elaboration of the national strategy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Roads Projects.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the work of the traffic research unit at University College Cork; his views on whether investment in road projects, tunnels, town by-passes, networks, light rail, underground trains and so on will not yield the required returns without effective traffic management strategies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to produce a White Paper on transport policy which would help prepare the way, in policy terms, for the likely falloff in EU funding available for transport infrastructure in future years and would also deal with the huge impacts on the quality of life from traffic congestion and the deteriorating urban air quality that arise from the operation of current transport policies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to tax traffic congestion through toll charges, thereby creating a pool of revenue for investment in quality public transport systems; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 549, 560 and 589 together.

Growth in transport demand in recent years, which has been closely following economic performance, presents an obvious challenge for sustainable development in Ireland. Policy responses must be based on an integrated approach to transport requirements, including increased investment in road infrastructure but also improvements in public transport, management of road transport demand, promotion of alternative transport modes, better co-ordination of transport and land use planning, and improved traffic management. These matters and the environmental impacts of transport are being addressed through the Operational Programme for Transport 1994-99 and Sustainable Development: A Strategy for Ireland; in urban transport initiatives such as the DTI; and in the planning work under way in Departments and agencies for the transport elements of the National Development Plan for the period 2000-06. This integrated approach will be increasingly relevant to transport policy in the years ahead and will be fully reflected in the transport investment programme to be drawn up following completion of the NDP.

MainHeading.P: In the context of the mid-term review of the current Community Support Framework, it was agreed at the request of the European Commission that a study of road pricing and related issues, with reference to practice across the EU, would be carried out. This study is now under way and is expected to be completed by the end of this year. In the meantime, the National Roads Authority has made a tolling scheme designed to facilitate traffic management of the purposed Dublin Port Tunnel. This will be submitted for my determination following completion of the public consultative process which has now commenced.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Services for People with Disabilities.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the initiative of the East Cork Area Development Group, the East Cork Wheelchair Association and Midleton Urban District Council to make Midleton a disability friendly town; whether this initiative is receiving support from his Department as part of the Government's commitment to mainstreaming services for people with a disability; his views on whether lessons learned from this process in Midleton could be applied in towns in other local authority areas; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: I am aware of the Midleton initiative. I welcome any initiative which is aimed at improving the quality of life for people with disabilities. Many local authorities are improving the accessibility of their areas and my Department regularly reminds local authorities of the need for more action both in relation to access generally and in relation to access to their own buildings and facilities.

My Department has taken many measures to improve levels of accessibility for people with disabilities. My reply to Question No. 203 of 3 June 1998, outlines the measures the Departartment has enacted in recent years relating to people with disabilities. Other measures taken include furnishing advice to local authorities on the dishing of footpaths which, on national roads, is financed by the National Roads Authority, and, on non-national roads, is part-financed by my Department, a review of the public library service to examine all aspects of this service including services to people with disabilities and, most recently, the issuing of a draft code of practice for the employment of people with disabilities in the local authority service on which comments have been invited. It is also my intention to amend “Technical Guidance Document M — Access for Disabled Persons”— associated with the Building Regulations, 1997, to require all new houses being built on or after 1 January 2000, to be accessible to people with disabilities.

In addition, under a wide-ranging review of the Tidy Towns Competition, now administered by my Department, criteria relating to accessibility were incorporated in the marking scheme for judging the competition; a special inclusive environment access award, sponsored by the National Rehabilitation Board and the Irish Wheelchair Association, is also given each year to the town or village which makes the best contribution to improving facilities for people with disabilities.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)

I also refer to the reply to Question No. 21 of 11 June 1998 in regard to wider arrangements for implementation and review of the strategy.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he can confirm that plans to cut road deaths by up to 20 per cent over the next five years do not include measures to introduce random breath testing in view of the fact that estimates consistently show that alcohol is a factor in as many as one in three of all road deaths; the reason for omitting this element from the strategy; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The Government Strategy for Road Safety 1998-2002 sets out an extensive analysis of the alcohol factor in Irish road safety. It establishes the specific target of reducing by at least 20 per cent the number of fatal road accidents — commonly drink-related — occurring during the hours of darkness; and it undertakes, or proposes for further consideration, a number of new counter-measures. These include the introduction and extension countrywide, beginning in 1999, of evidential breath testing; possible selective application of random breath testing; and possible wider availability of information from coroner's reports about the blood alcohol level of road accident victims. These and the many other policies and actions co-ordinated by the strategy will be progressed urgently with a view to attaining the improved road safety performance targeted by the strategy.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to the findings published in the European Environment Agency publication, Europe's Environment: The Second Assessment, which highlighted the fact that, in the areas of climate change, troposopheric ozone, chemicals, biodiversity, inland waters, marine and coastal environment and urban environment, there has been insufficient policy development to deal with the problems articulated in The Dobris Assessment in 1995; whether the Irish record in this regard is in line with the poor performance generally in western Europe; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: whether his attention has been drawn to the European Environment Agency publication, Europe's Environment: The Second Assessment, which reports that, in the areas of waste management and soil degradation, there has been little development or unfavourable development in the period since 1990 to 1992; whether the Irish record in these areas is better or worse than the other countries in the western Europe grouping; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 557 and 558 together.

The report in question presents the results of a second assessment by the European Environment Agency of the state of the environment at a pan-European level. It includes an overall summary assessment of progress over the period 1990-95 in respect of 12 key European environmental problems evaluated in the report, by reference to policy developments and the overall state of the environment.

I am aware of the concerns, on a European level, which arise from the second assessment. However, the report does not set out systematically to compare or evaluate the performance of individual European countries in relation to environmental protection, and it would not be meaningful to attempt any such comparison based on its findings.

In the case of Ireland, the most recent state of the environment report, prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency in 1996, supported the view that Ireland continues to enjoy a relatively unspoilt environment, but with increasing pressures associated with economic development. A further state of the environment report is now being prepared by the agency. I am confident that Government policy, building on the analysis contained in Sustainable Development: A Strategy for Ireland, is providing a framework within which necessary growth can be maintained in an environmentally sustainable manner.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.P: Under the Sofia Protocol ratified in 1994, Ireland was required to stabilise NOx emissions at their 1987 level, estimated to be 105,400 tonnes per annumn, by the end of 1994. The latest national emission figure was 114,420 tonnes for 1996.

Transport is the largest source of NOx, with vehicles accounting for over 40 per cent of national emissions. The power generation sector is the other major source but emissions in that sector are being addressed by the introduction at all major generating stations of low NOx producing burners, and emissions have fallen over 5,000 tonnes between 1994 and 1997 from large combustion plants due mainly to the installation of NOx abatement technology in power stations.

The challenge to date in meeting Sofia Protocol requirements is significantly attributable to transport growth in recent years. However, successively more stringent vehicle emission controls, notably the fitting of catalytic converters, are expected to bring about significant NOx reductions over time. Ireland supports the further tightening of vehicle emission controls agreed in June 1998 under the auto oil programme. These cleaner fuels required under the programme, together with local traffic management strategies for major urban areas, increasing emphasis on public transport and alternatives to private car use will also facilitate controls on NOx emissions from vehicles.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he will outline his Department's policy in the area of integrating waste incineration with energy recovery; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. D. Wallace)
Speaker.P: Waste to energy incineration, carried on in accordance with high environmental standards, is regarded as environmentally preferable to the disposal of waste by landfill, and plays a major part in municipal waste management in many EU countries, and further afield. Where technically and economically feasible, and subject to appropriate attention to materials recycling, incineration with energy recovery or other advanced thermochemical processes are among the treatment options which should be considered in an integrated waste management strategy. Publication of a substantive policy statement on waste management options is imminent.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to reintroduce the pre-1940 grant for the refurbishment of houses which would help to alleviate the pressure on the housing market and on spiralling house prices and would be a major boost to rural regions where family homes which have been closed could provide good starter homes for young people; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: While I recognise that a general house improvement grant scheme would help to promote the conservation and improvement of the housing stock, I am also conscious of the cost of the previous scheme and the fact that the construction industry is operating at a very high level of demand. At this stage, therefore, I have no proposals to reintroduce a general house improvement grant scheme or a grant scheme specifically directed at houses constructed before 1940.

I am, however, in the context of the Government action programme for the millennium, examining, on an ongoing basis, possible options to extend the range of measures currently available to assist low income households in securing necessary improvement works to their housing.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Burial Grounds.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the controls or regulations which have been introduced under section 177 of the Public Health Act, 1879 and section 160 of the Public Health Act, 1878, to provide that local authorities carry out maintenance and upkeep on burial grounds; whether any system is in place at his Department to oversee expenditure by local authorities in this area; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the maintenance on burial grounds in other EU countries is far superior to Ireland; the plans, if any, he has to amend the relevant public health legislation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: Local authorities, acting in their capacity as burial boards, are responsible for the management and maintenance of burial grounds provided by them, and it is their responsibility to determine expenditure priorities within the limits of the available resources.

MainHeading.P: There is no specific monitoring by my Department of local authority expenditure on burial ground maintenance and I have no proposals, at present, to amend the relevant legislation.

I might add that, in recent years, functions in relation to burial grounds have been devolved from central government to local authorities with the result that virtually all such functions are now exercised locally.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Housing Grants.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the efforts, if any, he is making to reduce house prices for first-time buyers, particularly in the Dublin area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The Government responded quickly and decisively to the Bacon report on house prices with a comprehensive package of measures announced in its Action on House Prices published on 23 April last. The package involves a three pronged approach to increase the potential supply of housing, address factors causing overheating or distortions in the market, and improve the position of prospective first time buyers.

MainHeading.P: Measures to assist first-time buyers form a key element of the package including an increase in the income limits for the local authority shared ownership scheme; removal of fiscal incentives to investors who were pricing low income buyers out of the market; significant reductions in stamp duty rates, particularly at lower price levels; measures to boost housing supply such as special Exchequer funding of £35 million for water, sewerage and roads infrastructure to open up substantial extra land for housing, promotion of increased densities at appropriate locations, and a temporary reduction of capital gains tax on disposal of serviced land to encourage faster release for residential development.

The full effect of many of the measures, particularly those designed to promote housing supply, will only be seen in the medium term. However, positive effects have already been reported by market sources, including signs of some easing of the house prices situation, first-time buyers reclaiming the starter home market, which had been increasingly dominated by investors, and increase in the number of second hand houses coming on the market as a result of stamp duty reductions. Housing output in 1998 is set to exceed last year's record level and this trend should be reinforced significantly as the measures taken by the Government to boost housing supply begin to be reflected in terms of output. Certain of these measures, for example, those to reduce investor demand and secure higher densities in residential developments have particular relevance and impact in the Dublin area.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made to alter the regulations under the Road Traffic Acts to allow all buses which carry passengers to be able to use dedicated bus lanes; and if he will change regulations in order that cars containing three or more passengers be allowed to use bus lanes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The Road Traffic (Traffic and Parking) Regulations at present reserve the use of bus lanes to omnibuses, that is large public service vehicles operating on a definite route for the carriage of passengers at separate fares and picked up and set down along the route on request or at fixed stopping places. Pedal cycles and taxis may also use with-flow bus lanes.

I have recently received a number of different proposals, including one from the Dublin Taxi Forum and the Dublin Transportation Office, to allow other classes of vehicles to use bus lanes. I will be consulting with relevant parties in relation to these proposals.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: further to Parliamentary Question No. 518 of 21 April 1998 the date on which the decision was reached in his Department that a tenant purchase scheme for rental subsidy housing would not be feasible; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: : From the introduction of the rental subsidy scheme in May 1991, there was no provision for the purchase of individual houses by tenants. This position was reviewed again prior to the publication of Social Housing — The Way Ahead in 1995 when it was found that a tenant purchase scheme for rental subsidy houses would not be feasible as the sale of individual houses would undermine the capacity and resources of voluntary housing bodies to manage and maintain their estates and to continue to provide further housing projects.

As previously indicated, residents of rental subsidy houses of more than one year's duration may, on surrendering houses to the approved body, qualify for the following benefits available to local authority tenants surrendering houses to the authority: special mortgage allowance of £4,500 over five years to assist with mortgage repayments; the shared ownership system without having to satisfy the income elegibility criteria; improvement works-in-lieu; affordable housing sites; and exemption from the income limit for local authority housing loans.
Full details of these options are available from the local authorities who are responsible for administering the rental subsidy scheme in their areas.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that tenants of voluntary housing agencies under the rental subsidy scheme can pay much higher rents than tenants with similar incomes under differential rent schemes operated by local authorities; the proposals, if any, he has to remedy this situation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The rent payable to the voluntary housing body under the terms of the rental subsidy scheme is income related and standard throughout the country. The scheme was reviewed last November when reductions were made in the rent payable on both household and subsidiary income and a maximum was introduced to the rent payable in respect of subsidiary income. As local authorities are responsible for the determination of the rents of their own dwellings, rents payable by their tenants may vary depending on the local authority area in which the house is located.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: whether he has received, from the Dublin Transportation Office, a detailed short-term action plan for traffic in Dublin; if so, the action he intends to take on it; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: The DTO Transportation Review and Short-Term Action Plan has now been published and the Government has already endorsed the early implementation of most of its proposed measures, for which moreover substantial funding totalling some £145 million has been provided. Measures requiring the provision of additional funding viz. proposals relating to the purchase of 100 additional buses, additional subventions to support enhanced bus and rail services, and the provision of additional resources for the Garda traffic division will be considered by the Government in the context of the 1999 Estimates and budget.

The short-term action plan is designed to accelerate the implementation of those elements of the DTI strategy that can be completed in the period up to 2000. It focuses therefore on public transport enhancement, traffic management, parking policy and the provision of cycling facilities. In addition to the measures proposed in the plan work is continuing on progressing the major infrastructural projects provided for in the DTI strategy, including the completion of the remaining elements of the Dublin C-ring and LUAS.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the number of new house grants being denied because a material (details supplied) was not certified by the National Standard Advisory Institute; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the meetings, if any, held between officials from his Department and officials from the European Commission in relation to alleged breaches of section 30 of the Treaty of Rome in the context of the failure to accredit a building material (details supplied).

Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he proposes to take to resolve the problem of outstanding new house grants for persons who used a building material (details supplied).

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 577, 578 and 579 together.

MainHeading.P: A new house grant is payable only where a house meets the conditions and the standards specified by my Department and set out in the explanatory memorandum on new house grants supplied to each applicant for a grant. In particular, construction of the house must be in compliance with the requirements of the Building Regulations. The suitability of new materials, products or components must be demonstrated through certification by a competent body, such as the National Standards Authority of Ireland/Irish Agrement Board. In the case of this particular product, the certification required is not available in respect of the use of the product for hot water or central heating systems. As a consequence, 44 applications for new house grants have not been paid to date and the applicants have been notified accordingly.
The Irish distributor of this building material has made a formal complaint to the EU Commission, alleging breaches of the Treaty of Rome, against the Department.

The distributor of this product has also initiated judicial review proceedings in the High Court over the refusal of the NSAI-IAB to issue an agreement certificate of approval for this product for hot water-central heating purposes and the consequent refusal of my Department to pay grants for new houses incorporating the product where it has been used for such purposes. The High Court proceedings are against the NSAI, the Minister, Ireland and the Attorney General.

An EU Commission official had a meeting with officials of my Department on 14 September 1998 to discuss EU Commission proposals to improve the Competitiveness of the Construction Industry and the EU Construction Products Directive (89/106/EEC). The relevant complaint and judicial review proceedings were not on the formal agenda. However, the EU Commission official informally adverted to the complaint at the outset of the meeting. It was explained that the details of the complaint could not be discussed because of the danger of prejudicing the judicial review proceedings in this jurisdiction. However, the officials of my Department offered to supply the EU Commission official with a copy of the Statement of Opposition by the State to the judicial review application lodged with the High Court. The EU Commission official accepted a copy of the legal document involved.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Kitt Mr. M. Kitt
Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to improve road safety; if education programmes on road safety will be included in these plans; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The Government Strategy for Road Safety 1998-2002 proposes a comprehensive and coordinated set of policies and measures designed to reduce both road fatalities and serious injuries by a minimum of 20 per cent by 2002. This strategy prioritises improvements in the key areas of speeding, alcohol use and seat belt wearing, but also emphasises the importance of education and other instruments for improving road safety.

The strategy recognises the vital importance of children learning good road safety habits from the earliest possible age and underlines the role of parents in this process. Educational measures proposed include the development of a teachers' resource pack on road, fire and water safety by the National Safety Council. This will form part of the social, personal, health and education programme of the new primary school curriculum. The pack will be distributed to all 3,300 primary schools.

Second level schools have traditionally received less attention in terms of road safety education. There is therefore ground to be made up in developing the skills of secondary school children as the adult road users for the future. The National Safety Council will develop special material/programmes for the post-primary sector. This will focus both on safe road use by teenagers and the future responsibilities of young people as drivers.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Water and Sewerage Schemes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the town sewerage in Skibbereen consists mainly of a network of old stone box culverts constructed in the 1840s through which raw effluent is discharged; his views on whether there is an urgent need for a new sewerage system for the town; whether a new scheme is held up pending the appointment of a consultant by Cork County Council on the overall sludge situation in south and west Cork; and if he will ensure that the appropriate approval for the appointment of the consultant is forthcoming.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: A preliminary report for the Skibbereen sewerage scheme has been submitted to my Department. However, following submission of the preliminary report, the national sludge strategy study identified Skibbereen as a hub-centre for the west Cork region and Cork County Council was advised that the implications of this would have to be taken into account in the design of the Skibbereen treatment works.

The council subsequently indicated that, before undertaking the preparation of a revised preliminary report for Skibbereen, it proposed to review sludge strategy for the county as a whole. The council has recently submitted a brief for the appointment of consultants to undertake this review and my Department is in correspondence with it about this. The council's response to this correspondence is awaited.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: his views on the need to have funding made available to the Skibbereen Urban District Council for the provision of a link road, car parking and pedestrian link bridges in view of the fact that the National Roads Authority is now to proceed with the Skibbereen relief road; and if he will ensure that the appropriate funding is made available to coincide with the development of the relief road.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey) Noel Dempsey
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Dempsey)
Speaker.P: The maintenance-improvement of non-national roads in its area is a matter for Skibbereen Urban District Council, to be funded from its own resources, supplemented by State grants. Skibbereen UDC was allocated a grant of £50,000 in 1998, an increase of 14 per cent on 1997. All non-national road grants for 1998 have now been allocated and there are no funds at the disposal of my Department from which a further grant could be made available to the council in the current year.

Grant-aid is also provided to local authorities, under the EU funded Urban and Village Renewal Sub-programme of the Operational Programme for Local Urban and Rural Development, for a range of environmental improvements to be undertaken in towns and villages throughout the country in the period 1994-99. The improvements which are being assisted under the sub-programme are designed to promote sustainable physical, social and economic revitalisation of centres ranging from the smaller villages to the larger cities. Where car parking forms part of an environmental improvement scheme it could be considered for funding under this sub-programme. It would be a matter for Cork
County Council to determine the individual towns and villages to benefit and the scope of works to be carried out under the sub-programme having regard to the annual allocation of funding.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.askee: Minister for the Environment and Local Government
Qst.Quest: if he will clarify the regulations in relation to the period of time within which successful applicants for driving test can apply for their licence; if he will change the two year rule to three years or reduce the period of a provisional licence below two years; if he will introduce discretion into the system for applicants who arrive at motor taxation offices within a few days of expiration of their certificate of competency which they receive on passing a driving test; and if he will make a statement on the hardship and confusion of the current system with applicants having to repeat the test for being one or two days late.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment and Local Government (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The holder of a certificate of competency, issued following a successful driving test, is allowed a period of two years within which to obtain a full driving licence. This requirement is explained when the certificate of competency is issued by the driving tester and is also clearly specified on the certificate.

The period of two years allows a successful driving test applicant, if he or she wishes, fully to use up the period of their provisional licence. At the same time, it establishes a reasonable period of closure within which drivers should move from provisional to full driving licence status.

I do not consider that changing this period of closure would avoid the unfortunate occurrence of a small number of people, through inadvertence or otherwise, failing to apply for the full driving licence within the prescribed period. I do not therefore propose to amend present regulations on this matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the reason students who partake in vocational training opportunities scheme courses are ineligible to work part-time without losing pound for pound such secondary benefits as the Eastern Health Board rent allowance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Dr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Dr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Persons participating in a vocational training opportunities scheme, back to education allowance schemes or the part-time education initiative scheme may continue to receive their full weekly payment and retain any secondary benefits, such as rent supplement under the SWA scheme, which they may have been receiving prior to participating on one of these schemes.

Vocational training opportunities scheme conditions were brought into line with those payable under the back to education schemes with effect from June 1998. Participants receive the equivalent of the maximum standard rate of unemployment benefit. They are also now paid for the full duration of their course including holiday periods. While earnings from part-time employment or summer holiday work do not affect the basic rate in payment, they are assessable for rent supplement purposes.

Entitlement to a supplement is determined by the health boards. Supplements are normally calculated to ensure that the person, after payment of rent or mortgage interest, has an income equal to the rate of SWA appropriate to their family circumstances, less £6. This £6 represents the minimum contribution which recipients are required to pay from their own resources. In addition to the minimum contribution, applicants are required to contribute any assessable means in excess of the appropriate SWA rate.
At current SWA rates the basic needs of an adult is taken to be £68.40 weekly. Any increase in income over and above that rate will result in a decrease in the rent supplement rate payable.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if he will classify twins as a multiple birth for the purposes of child income support; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The range of enhancements to the child benefits scheme which were announced in the 1998 budget came into effect earlier this month.

These enhancements included the introduction of a new payment of 150 per cent of the normal child benefit rate for twins and increases in the monthly rate of child benefit of £1.50 for the first two children and £3 for all subsequent children, bringing the monthly rates to £31.50 and £42, respectively.

Finally, the grants payable on the birth of three or more children have been increased to bring them into line with the existing arrangements for twins in this regard. Where three or more children are born together, a grant of £500 is payable and where such children reach four and 12 years of age, further grants of £500 are now also payable.
Any further enhancement of the child benefit scheme will be a matter for consideration in a budgetary context.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if his Department will review the grant allocation of £8,000 which was made to an organisation (details supplied) in County Kilkenny in view of the application and details supplied which indicated a need for £25,000; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The scheme of grants to voluntary organisations providing marriage and child counselling is designed to support the provision of voluntary marriage counselling services throughout the country, to ensure that they are available and accessible to the public and to support the provision of counselling for children whose parents have separated.

This year £1.5 million has been allocated to support the provision of services — an increase of £600,000 on 1997. To date, over 150 voluntary organisations have received grant aid amounting to £1.27 million. Of this amount some £643,500 was approved for ACCORD centres throughout the country.

The following criteria are taken into consideration in allocating grants to voluntary organisations: (i) the service which is being provided must be marriage counselling and/or child counselling in relation to parental separation; (ii) the quality of service, this includes management and back-up support for the service and qualifications and training of counsellors; (iii) the demand for the service, that is the number of clients using the service in a particular area. Having regard to these criteria, a grant of £8,000 was approved for ACCORD, Kilkenny.

I have recently announced the availability of further grants to organisations providing marriage preparation courses and to organisations providing bereavement counselling and support on the death of a family member.

I have arranged for details of this grant aid to be sent to ACCORD, Kilkenny so that they may make an application for additional funding in respect of the marriage preparation programmes which they provide.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: whether the technology is available to the Government, even if not currently so deployed, to integrate and data-match information held on computer by the various Departments, the Garda, the Revenue Commissioners, the health boards and so on; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The use of electronic information and communications technology is widespread throughout Departments and is now universally employed in the delivery of services. Greater co-ordination between State agencies through sharing of information can lead to more convenient access to services, higher quality services and more effective use of resources and a level of information-sharing has existed for many years. For example in the administration of social welfare schemes my Department receives information from the Revenue Commissioners in connection with the payment of social insurance contributions by employers and employees. Similarly the Department makes information available to other agencies such as health boards and FÁS. In recognition of the need to extend these arrangements to the wider public service I introduced enabling legislation in the 1998 Social Welfare Act to promote greater sharing of information. I have also established at official level an interdepartmental group to oversee the development of appropriate systems and to co-ordinate the sharing of information where possible.

The legislation provides for a common public service identifier — the personal public service number, the associated public service card and sharing of personal information between Departments and agencies. Implementation of the personal public service number is essential to increasing information sharing among public bodies. Enhancements to the relevant computer systems in the various bodies are also required to enable them to use the PPSN. At present such sharing is possible by a relatively small number of bodies who previously used the old revenue and social insurance number. This capacity will be extended to other bodies as resources and opportunities permit.

The law also provides considerable protection for the citizen by restricting the use of the PPSN to specified bodies and only for specified transactions and restricting the use of shared information to the administration of specified schemes.
