MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Social Welfare Code.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: when regulations will be introduced to enable local authorities to deduct rent payments under the household budget scheme from all types of social welfare benefit.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Currently a local authority tenant can arrange to pay rent by means of direct deduction from certain social welfare payments.

This deduction arrangement — known as the household budgeting scheme — is available to unemployed persons paid by means of the post-draft system at Post Offices, to one parent families, to invalidity pensioners and to people in receipt of disability allowance. The latter two categories were included in the household budgeting scheme from August 1998. The household budgeting scheme is working well and there are 71 local authorities using the scheme at present with over £254,200 collected each week through the scheme. The numbers availing of the scheme have grown by about 20 per cent since August 1997 and currently stand at 14,066.

It is intended to extend the scheme to most other social welfare payments but this is dependent on computer developments on existing payment schemes which cannot be carried out until essential work to ensure year 2000 compliance is completed on all computer systems within the Department.

MainHeading.P: The Housing (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1997 amended the Social Welfare code by providing regulatory powers to deduct an amount, not exceeding the weekly rent, from the person's social welfare payments, without his or her consent, where that person has accumulated arrears of rent with the local authority. In view of the developments which have taken place and are planned under the existing arrangements, I do not propose to make regulations under the Act at this time. However, I will be keeping this matter under review and will consult with my colleague, the Minister for the Environment and Local Government, as to whether and when such regulations should be made.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the reasons an increase of £2.10 on a third level allowance or unemployment assistance as outlined in the case of a person (details supplied) is automatically deducted from his rent allowance thus disimproving his position.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Rent supplements are normally calculated to ensure that the person, after the payment of rent, has an income equal to the supplementary welfare allowance rate less £6.

This £6 represents the minimum contribution which recipients are required to pay from their own resources. In addition to the minimum contribution, recipients are required to contribute any assessable means in excess of the appropriate supplementary welfare allowance rate.

The current SWA rate for an adult is £68.40 per week. Any increase in income over and above that rate will result in a decrease of that amount in the rent supplement rate payable. As the current unemployment assistance and third level allowance rate is £70.50 per week, the personal contribution is increased by £2.10 to £8.10 weekly.

In the particular case raised by the Deputy, the person concerned had been receiving an incorrect rate of rent supplement up to the end of July last because of an error in the original calculation made by the health board. As a result, a minimum contribution of £6 was assessed instead of £8.10. The position was subsequently rectified.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if his Department will examine the case of a person (details supplied) in Dublin 8, and other similar cases, who has nine stamped contributions on average but who falls below the required ten contributions to quality for a pro rata pension; the reason ten contributions is treated as the cut-off point; the reason those without this level of contributions, as highlighted in this case, receive no pension; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The rate of an old age contributory pension payable to any person is related to the average of full-rate contributions, paid or credited over their lifetime of insurable employment. To qualify, a person must: have entered insurance before age 56; have the equivalent of at least 156 weeks' paid contributions; and have a minimum yearly average of 20 contributions paid or credited since 1953 or the time they entered insurable employment.

As a minimum qualifying condition, a person is required to have entered insurance at least ten years before pension age. This has been a feature of the scheme since its introduction in 1961. Applying to all insured people, its purpose is to link entitlement to a pension with a reasonable level of contributions to the social insurance fund during the course of a person's career.

Special arrangements have been made in recent years in recognition of the difficulties faced by people whose yearly average of contributions is diluted due to gaps in their insurance records. For instance, as in the case of the person concerned, where there are insufficient contributions to achieve a yearly average of 20, provision has been made for a reduction in the yearly average to ten to 19 contributions which would entitle a person to a pro rata pension. A minimum yearly average of ten is considered to be a reasonable level of contributions.

The person concerned unsuccessfully applied for an old age contributory pension in the normal course in February 1988. His yearly average of eight contributions was insufficient for this pension under the then prevailing conditions.

In November 1991, a ‘mixed-insurance’pro rata pension was introduced which enabled those with a mixture of full and modified rate insurance contributions to qualify for a pro rata pension for averages of less than 20 full rate contributions. The rate payable is in proportion to the periods of insurance completed at the rate appropriate for old-age retirement pensions. In addition, those qualifying for this pension also became entitled to ancillary benefits such as the free schemes, which would not, otherwise, have been available to them. In the case of the person concerned, he was awarded this pension with effect from 29 November 1991, now payable at the current weekly rate of £32.50, including a qualified adult allowance in respect of his wife.

The new pro rata pension which was introduced in November 1997 extended entitlement to those whose yearly average, based on full rate contributions, ranged from ten to 19. As the Deputy will be aware, a yearly average of between 15 and 19 contributions gives a pension of 75 per cent of the maximum rate, while an average of between 10 and 14 results in a pension of 50 per cent of the maximum. The person concerned does not qualify for this pension as his yearly average, based on his full rate contributions, remains unchanged at eight.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the current average waiting period for an oral hearing following an appeal to the social welfare appeals office; the comparative average waiting time in 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The average processing time for appeals which are determined following an oral hearing is at present 30 weeks. The average waiting time for such appeals in 1997 was 32 weeks.

In some cases appeals can be dealt with on the basis of the particulars supplied by the appellant and by the deciding officer, without the need for an oral hearing, and these are cleared more quickly. The average time for appeals summarily dealt with in August 1998 was just under 13 weeks. When an oral hearing is required, however, additional delay is unavoidable.

The social welfare appeals system is quasi-judicial and the procedures are designed to ensure that every appellant's case receives full and adequate consideration. There is an inevitable time-lag in such a process. In some cases delay may be due to material from the appellant being awaited by the appeals officer before a decision can be made. Delay can also occur when the grounds advanced by the appellant in support of the appeal require further investigation or, in sickness related cases, where arrangements are made for a further examination by a medical assessor. Oral hearings arranged by the appeals office may also have to be postponed at the request of the appellant or his/her legal representatives, because of other commitments by them or because more time is sought by them in order to prepare their case.

The provision of a prompt service is a major objective of the social welfare appeals office. At all times, however, it is necessary to ensure that progress in this regard is achieved in a manner which is fully consistent with the demands of justice and the requirement that the appeal of every person who has recourse to the office is fully investigated and examined on all its merits.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Family Support Services.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to provide grant assistance of £40,000 for a project (details supplied) in County Sligo, which is vital for the excellent programme, which includes family visitation, parent development and child development staff training, to continue; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that the service will close without funding; if his attention has further been drawn to the fact that this application was put on hold because the Department of Health is funding a programme for 7-15 year olds in the east ward which is a separate programme and where there will no duplication of services between the two programmes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Under the family and community services resource centre programme operated by my Department, funding is provided for local resource centres which aim to combat disadvantage by improving the functioning of the family unit.

Local centres are funded under this programme to undertake a wide range of activities designed to improve the functioning of the family unit, that is by providing special services for lone parent families, young mothers and others considered in need of extra support and can act as a first step to community participation and social inclusion for the most vulnerable and marginalised families.

MainHeading.P: These centres may also be concerned with initiatives to enhance the role of young fathers in the lives of their children and to enhance their parenting skills and initiatives to promote the greater involvement of young men in the life of the community. Activities provided by these centres are aimed at enhancing the self-esteem and potential of individuals in order to increase the capacity of local communities to become self-reliant and self-directed. Programmes are based on the principles of personal development, adult education and community empowerment.

The focus of this programme is on assisting adults in developing the capacity to participate fully in their communities, and on doing this through the provision of a supportive structure, that is family resource centres. Many of the adults assisted through these centres participate in adult education classes and activities that contribute overall to their personal development and which may, indirectly, contribute to an improvement in their family circumstances.

My Department received an application from the group indicated in the Deputy's question. This application was considered in relation to the criteria applying to the programme. While the group's proposal included some initiatives aimed at providing supports and training opportunties for parents the main focus of the group's activity is the provision of programmes aimed specifically at children in the 0-5 year age group including a visitation programme where parents are offered individual advice on parenting issues, again to deal with mainly pre-school children. The direct child-centred focus of the group, as indicated by the Deputy, is not within the remit of my Department's programme and would be more appropriate to the health board.

In addition, the Department also received an application from a second group in Sligo who were also seeking inclusion in the programme and a third project based in the same area has secured funding from the health board for a pilot initiative for children at risk. I understand that the intention is that the health board project will also provide broader family supports that would be appropriate to my Department's programme. For all these reasons — and to minimise duplication of funding between State agencies — it is not considered appropriate to offer funding in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in County Kildare was deemed ineligible for one parent family allowance when it has been illustrated that the applicant is not co-habiting; if his Department will define part-time co-habiting in the context of social welfare law; if he has satisfied himself that the landlord of an applicant should be summoned for a social welfare appeal given that he has made a written submission; and if he will make a statement on the matter. -

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: This person concerned was in receipt of a one-parent family payment — formerly lone parent's allowance — for some years. Following investigations by a local officer of the Department, it was decided that she was no longer entitled to the allowance with effect from 29 January 1998 as she was co-habiting with another person as husband and wife.

The person concerned appealed this decision. An appeals officer, after two oral hearings on the matter on 14 May and 23 July 1998, decided that she was disqualified from receiving a one-parent family payment as she and another person were co-habiting as husband and wife. Her landlord attended the first appeals hearing but declined to attend the second. It was a matter for the appeals officer to decide whether the landlord's evidence was relevant and whether he should be summoned to attend the hearing or not.

The appeals officer's decision on the claim is final and conclusive, and can only be reviewed in the light of new facts or fresh evidence. No such new facts or evidence have been submitted to my Department since the appeals officer's decision.

Cohabitation exists where two persons are living together as husband and wife. The concept of part-time cohabitation does not exist in social welfare law. The criteria for assessing cohabitation include whether the couple reside in and constitute a single household, the stability of this relationship and the social and sexual nature of the relationship. There is no single factor by which the existence of a cohabitation can be established and in the final analysis, the deciding officer or appeals officer must form a judgment on whether the circumstances of a case are sufficiently similar to those of a married couple to establish that the client concerned and another person are cohabiting as husband and wife.

He was advised in that letter that failure to comply with the request may result in a disallowance of his payment. Inquiries in the case are continuing.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to review the carer's allowance with a view to increasing the income guideline threshold to ensure that more women who stay at home, who have no PRSI contributions and whose husbands are working, qualify; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The carer's allowance is a social assistance scheme which provides an income maintenance payment to people who are providing elderly or incapacitated pensioners or certain persons with disabilities with full-time care and attention, and whose incomes fall below certain limits. At the end of June 1998 there were 11,000 carers in receipt of a carer's allowance at an estimated cost of £45 million in 1998.

In An Action Programme for the Millennium the Government is committed to progressively relaxing the qualifying criteria for the carer's allowance to ensure that more carers can get the benefit; and increasing the value of the allowance in real terms.

In line with these commitments, an overall review of the carer's allowance has been carried out within my Department and will be published shortly. Any changes in the scheme, such as the relaxation of the means testing arrangements, will be considered in the light of the review and in a budgetary context.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the amounts of money paid in rent supplements in respect of tenancies in a property (details supplied) for each of the years from 1996 to date; and the checks, if any, made to ensure that conditions there comply with all fire, safety, health, planning and building regulations.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy in relation to rent supplements paid to a specified address is not available.

Responsibility for housing policy lies with the Department of Environment and Local Government and with local authorities. This includes any matters relating to standards of accommodation, planning permission, registration of landlords, housing regulations and fire safety. The Department of the Environment and Local Government has published a “Charter for Rented Housing” in that regard.

The supplementary welfare allowance system cannot discriminate against an individual or confine or restrict a person's freedom of choice regarding the accommodation or the location where they chose to reside.

If, however, a health board feels that a premises where a rent supplement is being paid is not up to an acceptable fire-safety standard, then the matter is brought to the attention of the local authority.

MainHeading.P: The Eastern Health Board has been contacted regarding the building in question and has stated that while there were problems in the past with a previous landlord arising from the poor standard of accommodation he provided, they are not aware of any such problems with the current landlord.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if he will increase the free fuel allowance for the winter months in view of the extremely bad summer.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The aim of the national fuel scheme is to assist householders who are on long-term social welfare or health board payments and who are unable to provide for their own heating needs. A payment of £5 per week — £8 per week in smokeless zones — is paid to eligible households for 26 weeks from mid-October to mid-April.

Expenditure on the national fuel scheme has increased by approximately 20 per cent in the last five years from £37.5 million in 1993 to £45 million in 1997. This year a sum of £45.2 million has been provided in the Estimates for the scheme.

It is estimated that increasing the basic allowance by £1 per week would cost £7.6 million. Any increase in the rate of payment would have significant cost implications and could only be considered in a budgetary context, taking increases in primary weekly payment rates into account.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Summer Jobs Scheme.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the number of applications received for the 1998 student summer job scheme; the number of applications approved; and the amount of money paid out to applicants including details on a county to county basis.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the number of applications for the 1998 student summer job scheme which were received late.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: the number of applications for the 1998 student summer job scheme which were refused; and if he will give a breakdown of this figure according to the reasons for refusal.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: It is proposed to take Question Nos. 618, 619 and 620 together.

The purpose of the student summer jobs scheme is to provide income support during the summer holiday period for less well off third level students who are disqualified from receiving unemployment assistance and are unable to obtain summer work.

MainHeading.P: The information requested by the Deputy is as follows: A total of 20,930 applications were received for the 1998 scheme and 16,100 students were approved to participate. To date, £2.4 million has been paid to 1,343 sponsors in respect of 4,256 students. A breakdown by county of this amount is not available at present.
Some 423 applications were received after the closing date of 26 June and were rejected as late claims.

Some 4,326 applications were refused for the following reasons: 2,238 had completed course and were eligible to claim unemployment assistance; in 1,386 cases the means exceeded the limit; 69 were in receipt of other welfare payment; 22 were leaving certificate students, not third level students; 20 were mature student eligible to claim unemployment assistance; 19 were not 18 years of age; 423 were late applications; and in the case of 149 there were other reasons the course was not recognised.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The person concerned applied for unemployment assistance in June 1998. She has been assessed with means of £40 per week, being the value of the benefit of living with her parents.

The person concerned has appealed against this decision to the independent Social Welfare Appeals Office. Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: It is a requirement of the back to work allowance scheme that an applicant must apply prior to taking up employment. The person concerned commenced employment on 25 May 1998. Her application was refused on the grounds that her claim was late and that she was in a position to return to the workforce without the need for the financial support which the scheme provides.
